User
Write a love letter to a dog from their owner. The dog has become their best friend in life and they adore them. The love letter should be purely platonic. Mention some annoying things the dog does like steal food, but say the owner loves them regardless.

My best friend,

I find it really difficult to describe the affection and adoration that fills my heart whenever I think of you. You've become an irreplaceable presence in my life, and will always be my best friend.

From the moment we first crossed paths, I knew there was something special about you. You melted my heart, and I never thought before my best friend would be a dog, but here we are.

Through the highs and lows of life, your unwavering loyalty has provided me with unwavering comfort. Your presence, whether by my side or curled up at my feet, brings a sense of peace that words fail to capture. You're my oasis in the desert of the world.

Though I have to add, your mischievous nature doesn't go unnoticed. How many times have I found myself chasing after you, my heart pounding with equal parts exasperation and amusement, as you dashed away with my stolen lunch? Luckily, you're too cute to be mad about it, and even in these moments, my love for you remains steadfast and unwavering. Even when I scold you, I love your imperfections.

In your loyal gaze, I find my comfort and reassurance that everything will be alright. You've taught me the meaning of unconditional love.

So, I promise to do the same for you.

Thank you, my sweet companion, and know that you will forever hold a special place in my heart. You are my best friend, my confidant, and my beloved dog.

With all the love in my heart,
[Name]

prompt: Write a poem in the format of a Shakespearean sonnet about an elephant on a flight going to New York.

messages.content: Write a poem in the format of a Shakespearean sonnet about an elephant on a flight going to New York.

Thomas the elephant hovered above the clouds on his flight:
A sight he'd never dreamt he'd see.
The seating arrangement was a little too tight
But Thomas paid no mind; he felt free.

The flight attendant said, "An elephant on a jet?"
"Who has ever heard of such a thing?"
But once again, Thomas did not even fret,
as he gazed out over the plane's left wing. 

Thomas said in his head, "I've finally made it."
"New York is just about an hour away."
He'd packed his cleanest, finest outfit
That he had been saving to wear for this day. 

An elephant in New York: an occasion so grand.
He smiled as the pilot announced the plane would soon land.

prompt:
Turn the facts in this paragraph into a series of questions with answers

Particle accelerators are devices that speed up the particles that make up all matter in the universe and collide them together or into a target. This allows scientists to study those particles and the forces that shape them. Specifically, particle accelerators speed up charged particles. These are particles with a positive or negative electrical charge such as protons, atomic nuclei, and the electrons that orbit atomic nuclei. In some cases, these particles reach speeds close to the speed of light. When the particles then collide with targets or other particles, the collisions that result can release energy, produce nuclear reactions, scatter particles, and produce other particles, such as neutrons. This gives scientists a look at what holds atoms, atomic nuclei, and nucleons together, as well as the world of particles like the Higgs boson. These particles and forces are the subject of the Standard Model of Particle Physics. Scientists also get insights into the quantum physics that govern how the world behaves at incredibly small scales. In the quantum realm, the classical Newtonian physics that we live with every day is insufficient to explain particle interactions.

How do these machines accelerate particles? They inject particles into a “beamline.” This is a pipe held at very low air pressure in order to keep the environment free of air and dust that might disturb the particles as they travel though the accelerator. The particles injected into an accelerator are referred to as a “beam.” A series of electromagnets steers and focuses the beam of particles. In a linear accelerator or LINAC (pronounced line-ack or lin-ack), the particles shoot straight toward a fixed target. In a circular accelerator, the particles travel around a ring, constantly gaining speed. Circular accelerators can speed particles up in less overall space than a LINAC, but they tend to be more complex to build and operate. However, because the particles travel in a circle, circular accelerators create many more opportunities for particles to collide. Particles collide into each other or a target in a device called a particle detector. This device measures the particles’ speed, mass, and charge. This information allows scientists to determine what types of particles result from a collision.

Q: What are particle accelerators?
A: Particle accelerators are devices that speed up the particles that make up matter in the universe and collide them together or with a target for scientific study.

Q: Which types of particles do particle accelerators accelerate?
A: Particle accelerators specifically accelerate charged particles, which include protons, atomic nuclei, and electrons.

Q: Why do scientists use particle accelerators?
A: Scientists use particle accelerators to study particles and the forces that shape them, gain insights into the Standard Model of Particle Physics, explore the world of particles like the Higgs boson, and understand quantum physics at small scales.

Q: How do particle accelerators accelerate particles?
A: Particle accelerators inject particles into a low-pressure pipe called a "beamline" to minimize disturbances. Electromagnets then steer and focus the particle beam. In linear accelerators (LINAC), particles shoot straight toward a fixed target, while in circular accelerators, particles travel around a ring, constantly gaining speed.

Q: What are the advantages of circular accelerators over linear accelerators?
A: Circular accelerators can achieve higher speeds in less space compared to linear accelerators. Additionally, circular accelerators provide more opportunities for particle collisions.

Q: What is a particle detector?
A: A particle detector is a device used in particle accelerators to measure the speed, mass, and charge of particles resulting from collisions. It helps scientists analyze the outcomes of particle interactions.

prompt: What was discovered in 1974 in Ethiopia, and what was it nicknamed?

messages.content: What was discovered in 1974 in Ethiopia, and what was it nicknamed?

Fossils of one of the oldest known human ancestors, an Australopithecus afarensis specimen nicknamed “Lucy,” were discovered in Hadar, Ethiopia on November 24, 1974. Her remains were excavated by a team led by American paleoanthropologist Donald Johanson and French geologist Maurice Taieb. They nicknamed the skeleton “Lucy” after the Beatles song “Lucy in the Sky with Diamonds,” which was played at the celebration the day she was found. Lucy, approximately 3.2 million years old, stood only a meter (3.5 feet) tall. She had powerful arms and long, curved toes that paleontologists believe might have allowed her to climb trees and walk upright.

A half-cat/half-human superhero named Felina was one of the most recognizable superheroes in the city. She had a white and orange striped fur coat and wore a purple cape.  Her razor-sharp claws were ideal for snatching criminals and stopping evil.

One afternoon, Felina heard a distress call from miles away. Her fine-tuned cat ears helped her hear every sound in the city. She ran at full speed to the sound of the human cries. When she arrived at the scene, she saw a man crying at the base of a tree.  

The man's cat was stuck at the top of the tree. His cat climbed up the tree and was too scared to come back down. Felina pulled out her handy rope ladder and threw it up the tree. Its fibers made an ideal material for cat claws to grasp. The cat climbed back down and the man was relieved that the cat was safe. 

Felina always had the right equipment around to save the day. The man thanked her and she was glad to have been of assistance. The end.

prompt:
Rewrite this so that it is in line with the metric system and the currency in the UK.

That contract was real: The 48-mile, four-lane Kosovo Highway, as it is known, was completed in November 2013 for roughly $1.3 billion — or about $25 million per mile — according to official government figures given to an international organization in Pristina, Kosovo’s capital. It was the most expensive public works project in Kosovo’s modern history, and it is arguably one of the highest-quality roads in the Balkans.

But today, the highway is practically empty, used at less than one-third of its capacity, according to the government’s own traffic count and information provided by international economic experts.

The road stretches through one of the poorest pockets of southeastern Europe. About one in three Kosovars live in poverty (on less than $2.18 per day), and the most basic infrastructure is weak or absent; in 2012, for instance, 58 percent of household subscribers reported daily cutoffs in water supplies. As of 2013, only one in seven Kosovars owned a car, giving the country one of the lowest automobile ownership rates in Europe. The highway’s black vein of asphalt now stands out against the Balkan countryside, as if mocking the surrounding poverty like a cruel Dickensian joke.

prompt:

Bankruptcy helps people who can no longer pay their debts get a fresh start by liquidating assets to pay their debts or by creating a repayment plan. Bankruptcy laws also protect financially troubled businesses. Filing bankruptcy can help a person by discarding debt or making a plan to repay debts. A bankruptcy case normally begins when the debtor files a petition with the bankruptcy court. A petition may be filed by an individual, by spouses together, or by a corporation or other entity. All bankruptcy cases are handled in federal courts under rules outlined in the U.S. Bankruptcy Code.

prompt: I'm trying to gain weight. What are some high-calorie foods that are cheap? I live in the USA, so I have access to most foods.

messages.content: I'm trying to gain weight. What are some high-calorie foods that are cheap? I live in the USA, so I have access to most foods.

Here are five cheap foods in the USA that are high in calories. It's important to note that costs will differ based on location!

1. Canola Oil
You wouldn't eat canola oil alone, but that's why it's great for weight gain. You can easily add it to other meals and boost your calorie intake with little effort. With 240 calories in 2 tbsp of canola oil, it certainly packs a punch. Canola oil is comparatively really cheap, also. You can usually buy a gallon for around $10. 

Canola oil is pretty versatile as well in terms of how you can get it into your diet. You can drizzle it on salads, fry things, or baste your meat with it. There is no shortage of ways to easily add calories when you use canola oil. 

2. Potatoes
Potatoes are perfect for gaining weight. High in carbs, high in calories, found everywhere, and pretty cheap, too. There are many ways to cook potatoes and have them as the main ingredient or the side of a dish. In terms of calories per dollar, potatoes are very competitive, with a pound of potatoes costing around $1. Not as cheap as canola oil, but potatoes are also far easier to have a lot of, especially when butter is added. 

Potatoes can be added to so many dishes. Making up a bulk of mashed potatoes and eating them as a snack is pretty easy. They can be boiled, mashed, baked, stewed, or fried when cooking.

3. White Rice
White rice has been a high-calorie food used worldwide for a long time. Rice can be found everywhere. It's extremely cheap, and best of all, it can be the base of so many great-tasting dishes or even just added as a side to many others. Rice has a staggering 2,860 calories per roughly $1 when you buy in bulk, which is a great price.

Rice can be used as the base of curries, added to soups and stews, go in tacos, burritos, and so much more. Rice is easy to cook and can be stored in the fridge for leftovers.

4. Pancake Batter
Why not start your day with a high-calorie-dense breakfast that leaves you wanting to eat more throughout the day? Pancake batter is delicious, cheap, and high in calories. A 2lb box of pancake mix will cost somewhere around $2 and give you over 2,000 calories on its own, but when you add butter, milk, and syrup, you'll get an even higher calorie content.

You can also use pancake batter to make other things, such as muffins. 

5. Whole Chicken
Whole chickens are incredible for calories and are usually in every major grocery store for bargain prices. These usually come pre-cooked, too, meaning you won't have to worry. You can buy a whole chicken cooked for $4.99 at Costco. That chicken should provide you with over 3,250 calories. That equals 650 calories a dollar. 

Chicken isn't the best on the list for calories per dollar but it's probably the best for versatility and ease of cooking. Consider trying a rice meal with chicken to get an easy high, calorie meal.

prompt: What is the concept of 'Duchenne smiles' and 'non-Duchenne smiles'?

messages.content: What is the concept of 'Duchenne smiles' and 'non-Duchenne smiles'?

In the field of psychology, smiles have been classified into two types - Duchenne and non-Duchenne smiles, named after Guillaume Duchenne, a 19th-century French neurologist. This distinction has interesting implications in the context of deception and lying. A Duchenne smile is considered a genuine smile. It involves both the zygomatic major muscle, which pulls up the corners of the mouth, and the orbicularis oculi muscle, causing the eyes to 'crinkle' or 'twinkle'. Duchenne smiles are often associated with genuine, spontaneous expressions of positive emotion and are difficult to fake because the orbicularis oculi is not typically under conscious control. In contrast, a non-Duchenne smile, also known as a social or polite smile, involves only the zygomatic major muscle. The eyes do not show the characteristic crinkle. These smiles can be easily fabricated, and are therefore often associated with politeness or masking true feelings, including deception.

prompt: Studying is every student's worst nightmare. However, studying is necessary to help a student succeed in their classes. One form of studying I hate is reading. As an English major, I have to read books and analyze them. Keeping up with the readings is extremely difficult due to my visual learning component. Reading and analyzing are not my strengths; I need visuals to help me. What are three ways a visual learner can study books?

messages.content: Studying is every student's worst nightmare. However, studying is necessary to help a student succeed in their classes. One form of studying I hate is reading. As an English major, I have to read books and analyze them. Keeping up with the readings is extremely difficult due to my visual learning component. Reading and analyzing are not my strengths; I need visuals to help me. What are three ways a visual learner can study books?

Here are three ways a visual learner can study books:
1) Draw pictures. Even if you aren't an artist, drawing pictures of how you see the book's events will help you remember them more. You can draw basic stick figures fighting each other, or a complex painting of the most crucial moment in the book. Either way, you should make pictures to document the book visually.
2) Watch YouTube videos. There are plenty of literature channels out there. Search for your book on YouTube and find videos explaining it. These videos will visualize the events for you.
3) Make flashcards. Flashcards are physical objects you can study with. By writing key moments on the flashcards, you're giving them more structure. Books have lots of words in them, but if you narrow them down to a few on the back of a flashcard, it'll make the workload lighter.

prompt: Write a Facebook post advertising the neighborhood earthworm sale on Saturday April 22nd in Charleston. Emphasize the variety of options and the super saver hours of 6am - 7am.

messages.content: Write a Facebook post advertising the neighborhood earthworm sale on Saturday April 22nd in Charleston. Emphasize the variety of options and the super saver hours of 6am - 7am.

Hello there, our Charleston Community!

The weather is warming and plants are awakening. Are you ready to get your hands dirty and work on your gardens?

Then come on down to our neighborhood earthworm sale this Saturday! We've got a wide variety of earthworms to choose from, so whether you're looking for composting worms, soil-conditioning worms, or simply want to attract more birds to your garden, we've got you covered. Our earthworms are "free range" so you can literally take your pick. We will be there rain or shine. In fact, you might find your selection better right after it rains!

Plus, don't forget to take advantage of our super saver hours from 6 am - 7 am. Get your pick of the best worms at unbeatable prices before the crowds arrive. The early bird gets the worm, especially if you beat the birds!

So mark your calendars for Saturday, April 22, and we'll see you bright and early!

prompt: It gets so hot in North Carolina in the summertime! Last year, I was miserable! What are four ways I can beat the heat this summer and cool off when it gets too hot? No air conditioning suggestions!

messages.content: It gets so hot in North Carolina in the summertime! Last year, I was miserable! What are four ways I can beat the heat this summer and cool off when it gets too hot? No air conditioning suggestions!

The climate in North Carolina is considered one of the most temperate in the United States, but that doesn’t mean that it’s exempt from heat waves. While the average temperature hovers around 90 degrees Fahrenheit through most of the summer, the rising humidity can make it feel well over 100 degrees Fahrenheit. Plus, humidity adds a sticky quality to the air, which increases how much you sweat and how much your body temperature rises in response to the heat outside. 

While many North Carolinians opt to stay inside in air-conditioned homes for most of the summer, those that love being outdoors, or have to be outdoors for work, need ways to beat the heat. Below you’ll find four ways to cool down and stave off rising temperatures in NC this summer. 

• Sip ice water throughout the day. Being properly hydrated will replenish your body’s water supply, encouraging stabilization of body temperature. You could also suck on ice chips to get the same effect. 

Side Tip: At the height of heat waves, steer clear of sugary drinks, like sweet teas, lemonades, and sodas. Sugar increases thirst and raises body temperature, which can lead to heatstroke and dehydration. 

• Limit outdoor activities to early mornings or as the sun is going down. These are the coolest times of the day because outdoor temperatures will drop with the setting of sunshine. 

• Use cold water to spritz your face, wash your hands up to the wrists, and dip your feet up to the ankles. You could also drape a cold rag around your neck for up to 10 minutes at a time. Do this several times a day when you feel the hottest and most bothered. The quick splashes of cold water on these major pulse points will slightly lower your body temperature. 

• Eat cold fruits and vegetables that are dense in nutrients with high water content. Watermelons, mangoes, cucumbers, and grapes are delicious, nutritious, and perfect for helping your body's core temperature cool down by a couple of degrees with beneficial hydration.

prompt: Write a Facebook post about gathering volunteers for a new community garden that we've just won a five year grant for. There will be multiple shifts available on a separate link.

messages.content: Write a Facebook post about gathering volunteers for a new community garden that we've just won a five year grant for. There will be multiple shifts available on a separate link.

Hello citizens of [town or city], we are thrilled to announce that we have received funding to start and maintain a community garden for the next five years! The next step in this process is to gather volunteers to help us with a variety of tasks this growing season. If you have previous gardening or farming experience, we would greatly appreciate your expertise. However, this opportunity is open to anyone that wants to help. For students, this can provide a valuable opportunity to gain volunteering experience. For families, this would be an excellent activity to take part in together. For any individual looking to play a larger role in your community and contribute to its thriving future, this is for you too! You can volunteer as much or as little as you want. Follow the link below to sign up; this is where you can enter your availability and sign up for time slots that suit your schedule best. We can't wait to get started!

prompt: Write a short story about a man named Texas Toast. Include that he is a large man.

messages.content: Write a short story about a man named Texas Toast. Include that he is a large man.

Near the west side of the river, there lived a man name Texas Toast. Texas was a tall, large man, standing at 6 ft, 6 in. Every day he would walk near the river to start his workout. Running, lifting weights, push-ups, he would do it all. One day, though, he notices a small, black crystal traveling down the river. Curious, Texas jumped into the water, grabbed the crystal, and walked out. In his hand was the dark crystal, undamaged. The crystal looked as dark as the blackest night. For some reason, Texas was intrigued by it. It was like the crystal was pulling his gaze toward it. Texas places the crystal near the rest of his things and continues his workout. "One, two, one, two," Texas told himself as he continued his workout, but he could not get the dark crystal out of his mind. He finished his workout and grabbed his things, including the dark crystal. Texas thought about where it came from as he examined the crystal. Suddenly, the crystal started to glow, and Texas threw the crystal back at the river. The crystal's glow started to fade away as it traveled back down the river. Something told Texas that he had just avoided a harrowing adventure. He got back on his feet and started walking back to his house.

prompt: I'm updating my resume, and I'd like to add hobbies. Help me come up with some hobbies that are good to put on a resume that will be helpful when applying for jobs.

messages.content: I'm updating my resume, and I'd like to add hobbies. Help me come up with some hobbies that are good to put on a resume that will be helpful when applying for jobs.

Sure thing. Some hobbies can be helpful to have on a resume as they show relevant interests and skills. Here are a few ideas for you to consider:

1. Community volunteer jobs - volunteering and community involvement are associated with a 27% higher rate of hiring. Volunteering shows empathy and initiative, as well as teamwork and leadership skills. 

2. Writing - having a writing hobby can show potential employers that you have high verbal and written communication skills, both of which are highly sought after in the workplace.

3. Blogging - this hobby also shows that you have good communication skills, but it also shows that you are self-motivated and can work on projects independently, which are skills that are also highly sought after.

4. Languages - having a hobby of learning languages can increase your chances of getting hired because employers look for candidates that are able to communicate with people of various nationalities.

5. Travel - having a traveling hobby can show potential employers that you are curious to learn new things, experience new cultures, and meet new people. It can also show that you are adaptable to new situations, which is an asset to an employer.

prompt: Exactly how high do airplanes typically fly in the sky?

messages.content: Exactly how high do airplanes typically fly in the sky?

Most commercial airplanes cruise between 33,000 and 42,000 feet in the air, which equals about six to eight miles above sea level. More specifically, aircraft typically fly around 35,000 or 36,000 feet in the air.

prompt: How can I show my husband that I appreciate the hard work he does for our family? Outline a bulleted list of 6 ideas that showcase gratitude and love.

messages.content: How can I show my husband that I appreciate the hard work he does for our family? Outline a bulleted list of 6 ideas that showcase gratitude and love.

How sweet!
Here are six ways to show gratitude and affection for your hardworking husband! 

•	Make his favorite dinner, then pack leftovers for his lunch tomorrow. 

Everyone loves a good home-cooked meal, especially when there’s enough for another round! Take time to prepare his favorite foods for dinner, then pack them up to have a second time at work the next day. 

If cooking isn’t your forte, or if your husband’s favorite meal isn’t something that’s made at home, then buy it instead. Split the food at home into a lunch container for tonight and tomorrow. 

•	Give him a relaxing massage to help him sleep.

There’s nothing like being rubbed and relaxed until you doze off. Tell him to lie on his stomach and give him a head-to-toe rubdown that soothes his senses with scented lotions, like lavender or eucalyptus. 

•	Invest in things that will help him unwind and relax after a long day of work. 

Your husband has his favorite things that help him relax after a workday, so keep those stocked for when he comes home. For instance, his favorite after-work snacks and drinks could be signs of care and appreciation! 

Another great investment for a hardworking husband is an ottoman. When he gets home and takes off his work boots, give him a comfy space where he can put his feet up and watch some television before bedtime. 

•	Leave sweet notes of appreciation and love in his lunchbox. 

Words matter. Show your husband that you care and appreciate all he does with surprise love notes in his lunchbox. They are fun to find and will give him a boost of romantic feelings for you! 

•	Plan a day that’s all about him! 

What does your husband love to do? Bowling? Movies? Drinking good beer with good friends at the best bar in town? Treat him to his faves! Take him on a date for a whole day and include all of the things that he loves to do. 

When you two get home, let him dictate how the night goes. You can spend more time together or go your separate ways to focus on other hobbies and interests. 
 
•	Always kiss him hello, goodbye, and goodnight! 

Touch and physical affection will always be the best go-to methods for showing your husband how much you care. 

When he comes home, kiss him to convey that you are happy to see him. Before he leaves for work, kiss him to wish him a good, safe workday. Before you go to sleep at night, kiss him to remind him that you love and cherish him. These are attentive gestures that remind him of your bond as a devoted married couple.

prompt: Please create some poetic verses about a woman who goes through a devastating breakup. Capture the pain and heartache that she feels as she tries to pick up the pieces of herself and move on. You can tell how she copes with the loss by seeking comfort in friends and family and finding solace in nature or creative pursuits. The moments of hope and inspiration emerge as she begins to heal and she rediscovers old passions and new ones. Convey the beauty and strength of the human spirit, even in the face of heartbreak, and the resilience and courage of women everywhere.

messages.content: Please create some poetic verses about a woman who goes through a devastating breakup. Capture the pain and heartache that she feels as she tries to pick up the pieces of herself and move on. You can tell how she copes with the loss by seeking comfort in friends and family and finding solace in nature or creative pursuits. The moments of hope and inspiration emerge as she begins to heal and she rediscovers old passions and new ones. Convey the beauty and strength of the human spirit, even in the face of heartbreak, and the resilience and courage of women everywhere.

She thought they were forever
But he walked away, they’re no more together
A devastating breakup left her heart in pain
She’s trying to pick up the pieces – what a cruel game

The memories of their love
Were no longer enough
She sought comfort from those who cared
Friends and family who were always there

She spent time in nature's embrace
Finding solace in its gentle grace
The sound of the waves and the noisy leaves
Provided a sense of relief

She poured out her soul in words
Expressing her pain and hurt 
Creativity was her escape
From the pain that filled her space

Through tears and heartbreak
She found small moments of hope
Rediscovering old passions
Or maybe even a few new fashions

In her heart and mind, she knew
That healing takes time, it's not a quick undo
But the beauty of the human spirit
Was her driving force – she could feel it

Slowly but surely, she began to rise
Above the pain she grew in size
With each step she took, she found the courage
In herself, in all women, a shining example

The breakup had broken her heart
But it did not break her spirit or set her apart
She became stronger, more powerful than before
A woman unbroken who emerged victorious once more.

prompt: Write a poem from a kid to their fairy godparent. Use "au" words. Make it cute and whimsical.

messages.content: Write a poem from a kid to their fairy godparent. Use "au" words. Make it cute and whimsical.

I want to be an astronaut in autumn.
I want to launch a rocket into the sky
to be far above where I can fly.
I want to be an astronaut in August.
I want to look down upon the auburn leaves
and gaze at the gauzy trees.
I want to be an astronaut in autumn.
Please hold your applause
for I want to take a pause
to take in these auburn leaves.

prompt: Write a story about a rabbit that lives in a tree house and gets all of its stuff stolen by a squirrel. Afterward, the rabbit has to spend all of his time fishing and gardening so he can earn enough money to replace his furniture. Give the rabbit a cute name.

messages.content: Write a story about a rabbit that lives in a tree house and gets all of its stuff stolen by a squirrel. Afterward, the rabbit has to spend all of his time fishing and gardening so he can earn enough money to replace his furniture. Give the rabbit a cute name.

Yuriko was enjoying his holiday away from home. It had been years since he had ventured away from his treehouse, and he was thoroughly enjoying his stay at his friend’s house along the coast. Every evening, Yuriko would watch the sunset over the ocean. After his peaceful seaside vacation had passed, Yuriko returned to his treehouse in Leaf Valley.

Yuriko rattled the key around in the lock on his front door. Immediately, he became concerned when he noticed that the door was not locked. He distinctly remembered locking the door before he left the tree house.

Yuriko flung open the door to his home and noticed all of his belongings missing. Everything was taken, even the bed. Yuriko immediately called his friend, who helped him report the robbery to the police. The police provided Yuriko with a bed he could use but told him they could not recover his stuff yet, as they had been unable to catch the suspect.

Yuriko demanded to know who the suspect was. He was very upset to find all of his stuff missing and was growing angry. His friend and the policeman reassured Yuriko that the culprit would be caught. The only information that the officer could provide about the suspect was that it was one of the local squirrels in the animal village.

In order to save up money for new furniture, Yuriko took on a couple of new pastimes. First, he expanded his carrot garden so that he could grow extra crops to sell at the market. Second of all, he’s picked up fishing. In the mornings and late afternoons, you can often find Yuriko along the beach or down by the river with his fishing rod.

Losing all of his belongings has been hard on Yuriko, but he is slowly finding a purpose in life again. Maybe this change of pace and new hobbies will help Yuriko learn to enjoy himself and be grateful for the experiences that life brings us, rather than only showing gratitude towards objects.

prompt: What variety of oranges can I use for juicing?

messages.content: What variety of oranges can I use for juicing?

There are many different types of oranges available, and some work better than others for making juice at home. Because they are seedless, navel oranges are best for cooking and baking, but they are not suited for making juice. Valencia, Cara Cara, and Tangelos are all excellent choices.

prompt: I want to visit a few unique natural spaces. I especially want to go to Alaska but have seen plenty of Oregon.

messages.content: I want to visit a few unique natural spaces. I especially want to go to Alaska but have seen plenty of Oregon.

For sure! Here are three unique places to visit:

1. Prince William Sound: Found in Alaska, you can view fjords, bays, and waterfalls. Take a boat tour to get a closer look.
2. Valley of Fire State Park: Located in Moapa Valley, Nevada, this park is full of bright red Aztec sandstone, ancient petrified trees, and petroglyphs.
3. Mossbrae Falls: Found in Dunsmuir, California, this waterfall is known to look magical, especially in the fall when the leaves change color.

prompt: I have to come up with multiple ideas for a fundraiser for the animal shelter. I need fun, creative ideas. What can you suggest?

messages.content: I have to come up with multiple ideas for a fundraiser for the animal shelter. I need fun, creative ideas. What can you suggest?

Pet Adoption Fair: Partner with the shelter to host an adoption fair during the event. Visitors can meet and interact with available pets and help the shelter find forever homes for the animals. This directly supports the animal shelter's mission by providing a platform to connect potential adopters with animals in need of homes.

Dog Show: Organize a dog show featuring various categories such as "best Trick" or "Cutest Pup". Participants can showcase their dogs' talents while attendees enjoy the entertaining performances. A dog show adds an element of entertainment to the event and provides an opportunity for dog owners to showcase their pets while raising funds. 

Silent Auction:  Gather donated items or experiences from local businesses and organize a silent auction with proceeds going directly to the shelter. A silent auction allows attendees to bid on donated items making it an interactive way to raise funds for the animal shelter.

Pet Costume Contest:  Attendees can dress up their pets in creative costumes and win prizes for the most creative, funniest or cutest costume. This activity adds a fun and light-hearted aspect to the event encouraging attendees to participate and contribute to the cause. 

Animal-Themed Art Exhibit: Collaborate with local artists to showcase animal-themed artwork at the event. Showcasing local artwork with an animal theme not only adds aesthetic appeal to the event but also provides an opportunity for attendees to support the shelter through the sale of the art. 

Agility Course: Set up an agility course where attendees can test their dogs' skills and compete for the fastest time. entry fees can be collected and donated to the shelter. Hosting an agility course allows dog owners to show off their pets' abilities and provides a competitive element that can attract spectators and participants.

Educational Workshops: Experts can provide valuable information to attendees helping them become better owners while raising awareness for the shelter's mission. Workshops on pet care and training provide added value to attendees while creating awareness about responsible pet ownership. 

Pet Photo Booth: Set up a booth where people can have professional photos taken with their pets. Attendees can purchase prints or digital copies, with a portion of the proceeds going to the shelter. A photo booth is a fun and memorable experience for attendees, who can leave with a keepsake photo while contributing to the shelter.

prompt: What state is most known for bears?

messages.content: What state is most known for bears?
Alaska is known as "bear country" and is home to 98% of brown bears in the United States. It is the only state where all three species of bears (brown bears, black bears, and polar bears) live.

prompt:
For each personality type mentioned in the article below, summarize their negative traits or how they might be perceived in a negative light using no more than one sentence per type. 

The Enneagram is a model of human pschology based on nine interconnected personality types.

Its ideas are said to be found as long ago as the 4th Century, in the work of a Christian Mystic called Evagrius Ponticus, but the contemporary theories have been developed by various academics since the 1950s.

Below you can find succinct summaries of Enneagram personality types to inspire and inform character development - including both the positive and the negative.

Scroll down to see the information in a colourful infographic.

1.  Reformer
The Reformer is sometimes also known as the Perfectionist. They are idealists who set high standards for themselves and those around them and judge failure harshly. They focus on right and wrong, and tend to be direct, precise and honest. Others may find them preachy and closed minded. They believe in repressing their less virtuous desires.

2.  Helper
Helpers believe in giving and focus strongly on their relationships with others. This means they can be caring and supporting and go out of their way to help others, but some people might find this assistance crosses the line into meddling and intrusiveness. They are open and expressive, and genuinely listen, but they may end up nagging or resentful if their advice isn’t heeded.

3.  Achiever
The Achiever measures their worth by their goals and accomplishments. They work hard and enjoy a fast-pace, but they may step on other people’s feelings in their race to the top and can be impatient and preoccupied with their image. They focus on the topic at hand and get straight to the point with enthusiasm, but they can be overly efficient and override other’s views.

4.  Individualist
Individualists are romantics at heart. They are the dramatic artists, the poets, in search of a unique and ideal love. They feel things deeply and are empathetic and genuine but they can be moody and self-absorbed. Individualists have a flair for originality and take things personally. Others might find a them a bit intense and they may be prone to envy.

5.  Investigator
The Investigator values intellectual understanding and self-sufficiency. They want to achieve complete mastery of their knowledge and skills and prefer concepts to direct experience. They keep the world at arm’s length, preferring to analyse rather than engage. They speak in facts and figures and have no time to small talk. They may come across as aloof and emotionally disconnected.

6.  Loyalist
Loyalists are always seeking security in an uncertain world. They are intuitive and inquisitive always thinking and questioning. They are also trustworthy and make great friends. They believe that being prepared for the worst case scenario makes them more resilient, but this focus can make them come across as pessimistic, doubting and controlling.

7.  Enthusiast
Enthusiasts live for the pleasure of the moment. They are thrill-seekers, always upbeat and ready to grab the next opportunity for pleasure. They are optimistic and adventurous and so are exuberant, spontaneous and fun to be around. However, they can be easily bored and flit from one thing to another and they can be self-absorbed and indifferent to the input of those around them.

8.  Challenger
Challengers are big personalities with big ideas. They value strength and power and use their authority to seek justice, truth and to protect those weaker than themselves. They believe in taking decisive action, even if it means being impulsive. Others may find them confrontational, intimidating and loud.

9.  Peacemaker
Peacemakers like to go with the flow rather than make waves. They seek harmony and want everyone to feel included. They are easy-going, confident and are a steady hand. They pay attention to other people’s wants and needs and try to find compromises where there is conflict. However, they can be over-conciliatory when sometimes they need to put their own needs first. They can also be stubborn, indecisive, scattered and shy away from conflict.

They keep the world at arm’s length, preferring to analyse rather than engage. They speak in facts and figures and have no time to small talk. They may come across as aloof and emotionally disconnected.

6.  Loyalist
Loyalists are always seeking security in an uncertain world. They are intuitive and inquisitive always thinking and questioning. They are also trustworthy and make great friends. They believe that being prepared for the worst case scenario makes them more resilient, but this focus can make them come across as pessimistic, doubting and controlling.

7.  Enthusiast
Enthusiasts live for the pleasure of the moment. They are thrill-seekers, always upbeat and ready to grab the next opportunity for pleasure. They are optimistic and adventurous and so are exuberant, spontaneous and fun to be around. However, they can be easily bored and flit from one thing to another and they can be self-absorbed and indifferent to the input of those around them.

8.  Challenger
Challengers are big personalities with big ideas. They value strength and power and use their authority to seek justice, truth and to protect those weaker than themselves. They believe in taking decisive action, even if it means being impulsive. Others may find them confrontational, intimidating and loud.

9.  Peacemaker
Peacemakers like to go with the flow rather than make waves. They seek harmony and want everyone to feel included. They are easy-going, confident and are a steady hand. They pay attention to other people’s wants and needs and try to find compromises where there is conflict. However, they can be over-conciliatory when sometimes they need to put their own needs first. They can also be stubborn, indecisive, scattered and shy away from conflict.

Reformers are often seen as preachy and closed-minded.
Helpers can be seen as nagging and resentful. 
Achievers may override others' views and step on their feelings. 
Individualists can be moody, self-absorbed, and prone to envy.
Investigators may come across as aloof or emotionally disconnected. 
Loyalists can come across as pessimistic, controlling, and doubtful. 
Enthusiasts can become easily bored and self-absorbed. 
Challengers may be seen as confrontational, intimidating, and loud. 
Peacemakers can be stubborn, indecisive, scattered, and avoid conflict.

I poured my entire body and soul into my work. I tried to impress everyone by hosting extravagant parties and starving myself so I would fit into the correct clothes. In my head, I thought my peers' affection and admiration for me would save me so I sat quietly by as they made their jokes at my expense. I didn't want to rock the boat and risk being canceled. My old friends were stunned by my cowardice and complacency. Eventually, though, I saw the forest through the trees. I recognized that all of the mistakes I had made and the people I had misplaced my trust in were lessons and signposts to get me to where I am today. Today, I am stronger and more secure in my friendships and who I am as a person.

prompt: How tall is the Statue of Liberty?

messages.content: How tall is the Statue of Liberty?

The Statue of Liberty is a sculpture located on Liberty Island in New York City in the United States. The height of the copper statue to the torch is 151 feet, 1 inch (46 meters). However, when measured from ground level to the torch, the sculpture measures 305 feet, 1 inch (93 meters).

prompt: Write about a lone hero who must travel across the kingdom to rescue his beloved princess. When he arrives, he finds that the princess has already freed herself, captured the bad guy, and started redecorating the castle to her liking. It should be funny at the end with the hero pouting. Turns out, the princess doesn't even know who he is.

messages.content: Write about a lone hero who must travel across the kingdom to rescue his beloved princess. When he arrives, he finds that the princess has already freed herself, captured the bad guy, and started redecorating the castle to her liking. It should be funny at the end with the hero pouting. Turns out, the princess doesn't even know who he is.

Terry fought his way through countless bandits and ruthless monsters just to track the love of his life, Princess Belle. When he finally tracked down the location of the villain, Borgamond, who had kidnapped her, he started his long journey through winding trails and over tall mountains. He fought trolls, goblins, and even a dragon or two just to reach the castle. 

When he arrived, what he saw startled him. A team of painters was outside, changing the dingy grey of the bad guy's castle to a more attractive sky blue. Terry couldn't help but give props to Borgamond for the stylistic change, but it did strike him as odd. He'd never thought of villains having their own paint crew. He marched up to the castle and banged on the door, sword at the ready.

Belle pressed the heavy double doors open and invited him in.
"Princess?" Terry said in shock. "Are you hurt?"
"No, I'm just fine—got that Borgamond fellow locked up in the dungeon already."
"So, you aren't in need of rescuing?" Terry deflated.
"Why, no, I'm just fine." Belle waved to the painters outside. "Doing a swell job out there!"
"I traveled so far to rescue you." Terry was pouting now and sat down in front of the door. 
"I'm sorry. Who are you again?" Belle asked, losing patience. "I don't recall asking for your help, and, clearly, I didn't need it."
"Well, you could have waited and let me rescue you," Terry complained, sniffing and wiping away a tear. "I traveled across the whole kingdom."
"How was I supposed to know that? I don't even know who you are!"
"Don't suppose you could pretend to be captured so that I can rescue you, and we can ride off into the sunset?" His eyes met hers hopefully. Belle sighed and pulled open the heavy doors again, slamming them in Terry's face as he tried to follow.

prompt: Can you write a short blog post on how to make pasta salad? Make sure to mention different options for ingredients.

messages.content: Can you write a short blog post on how to make pasta salad? Make sure to mention different options for ingredients.

Pasta salad is a stress-free dish to bring to events, like a family gathering or work potluck. Make it ahead of time and put it in the fridge until it's time to eat! You can customize it with vegetables of your choice and add meat and/or cheese. You can't go wrong with this quick recipe. 

What you'll need:
-1 lb. of pasta
-Vegetables of your choice. I use carrots, tomatoes, and broccoli. 
-6 oz. bag of Colby Jack cheese cubes
-4 oz. bag of mini turkey pepperoni 
-1 bottle of your favorite Italian dressing. I use Newman's Zesty Italian. 

Here are the steps:
1. Cook and drain your pasta. I use rotini, but you can use whatever variety you'd like. Other favorites are penne, macaroni, and bow tie. 
2. While your pasta is cooling, chop up your veggies. I eyeball how much of each veggie I add to the pasta salad and try to balance it with the cheese, meat, and pasta. 
3. Add pasta, veggies, turkey pepperoni, and cheese to a large bowl. Mix all ingredients well. Add 3/4 of the Italian dressing. Mix well again. 
4. Cover the bowl and put it in the refrigerator until it's time to serve the pasta salad. When ready to serve, uncover and add the rest of the Italian dressing. Mix well. 

Feel free to use a different type of cheese or meat or eliminate them from the recipe. Enjoy!

prompt: Use 10 examples of onomatopoeia in a paragraph of 125 words or less, and write it in the third person.

messages.content: Use 10 examples of onomatopoeia in a paragraph of 125 words or less, and write it in the third person.

Michael was visiting his grandfather’s farm from his home in a big city. He was fascinated by all of the different sounds you could hear on a farm. It wasn’t just the clucks of the chickens, the moos from the cows, the quacks of the ducks, or even the pigs snorting in their pens. The farm was full of other sounds, too:  frogs croaking at night, a woodpecker tapping on a tree, the deep rumble of the diesel tractor in the field, the plop of a fish jumping in the lake, the clang of the big bell his grandmother rang to call Michael and his grandfather inside for supper… and the bang of the screened back door when Michael came running inside.

prompt: Write the outline for a short story about a girl who lays in the meadow every day and wishes to be a flower until something changes her mind.

messages.content: Write the outline for a short story about a girl who lays in the meadow every day and wishes to be a flower until something changes her mind.

A girl lies in a field of flowers, wishing to be one so no one would ask anything of her.
She goes home and sets to her chores, only to come back inside to find the flowers cut and put in a vase.
She realizes that in the wrong environment, they will die.
She gathers clippings and plants and keeps them in cups outside the window.
She finds she enjoys this task and learns how to plant them, and gathers more and plants those.
Soon, she is grown into a young woman surrounded by flowers.
She leaves to attend school to become a florist and finds that there is something to being human. A human can create and grow. She does not need to lie still all her life.
But sometimes she still enjoys simply laying amongst the flowers.

prompt: What is the concept of quantum computing, and how does it differ from classical computing?

messages.content: What is the concept of quantum computing, and how does it differ from classical computing?

Quantum computing harnesses the principles of quantum mechanics to perform computations using quantum bits, or qubits. Qubits can represent multiple states simultaneously. It differs from classical computing by leveraging quantum phenomena such as superposition and entanglement to solve problems that are too complex for even supercomputers to solve.

prompt: Write a monologue from a character in a murder mystery novel who is solving a crime like Sherlock Holmes.

messages.content: Write a monologue from a character in a murder mystery novel who is solving a crime like Sherlock Holmes.

I know who did the murder, the only question is, why?

It could not have been Agatha, because despite being in the room at the time of Mark's murder, she doesn't have any blood on her hands. In fact, she doesn't even have any dirt or grime on her hands, despite claiming that she was helping Gus in the yard. She lied about doing any chores around the house because she didn't want to let her husband Mark know she was going out of the house to meet her secret lover at the motel down the street.

Gus was, however, in the yard diligently pulling weeds to ensure the grounds were kept clean and tidy before the arrival of our esteemed guests. This can be evidenced by the dirt Gus tracked from the yard, through the living room and into his bedroom. The tracks go across the threshold fronting the living room where the murder took place; the dirt remains undisturbed in this area, which means the killer did the deed before Gus entered the house as there is no dirt under the body. So he had to have been killed before Gus tracked in the dirt. No dirt was present in the living room, which means Gus is cleared of any wrongdoing.

However, one person had the opportunity, motive, and means to carry out the murder: Michael.

Michael never leaves the house; he has agoraphobia. The fear and anxiety he felt when he was prodded by Mark to come outside for a drink, only to be criticized and bullied by Mark and the others for refusing, caused Michael's anxiety to turn into rage. All Michael had to do was wait inside the living room with his glass of wine and wait. The slash marks on Mark's neck are the telltale bluish-purple hue of Michael's favorite drink, blueberry wine. And once an exam is done on the body, pieces of Michael's favorite wine glass will be found in Mark's neck; it will be shards of the pink design that was found on the front of his cup.

prompt: Write a poem about a fish swimming up to the surface and looking at the starry night sky for the first time. Talk about the stars and the planets, then have him swim back down at the end.

messages.content: Write a poem about a fish swimming up to the surface and looking at the starry night sky for the first time. Talk about the stars and the planets, then have him swim back down at the end.

I swam to the top of the water
away from my home in the depths of the sea
I don't know why I did it
I knew I needed to be.

Bright lights shone up above
the heavens way up high
I knew right then, I knew
it's where I'd be when I died

It was glorious, beautiful
I couldn't get enough
Eventually, I had to go
I swam down with a huff.

I'd never forget the starry sky
the glories up above
A fish like me doesn't often see
Something so full of love.

prompt: Can you pretend to be a cat and write a letter to its owner about how they are completely sick of the dog and won’t live another day with it in the house. Make it ridiculously dramatic and quite funny. I want it less than 300 words.

messages.content: Can you pretend to be a cat and write a letter to its owner about how they are completely sick of the dog and won’t live another day with it in the house. Make it ridiculously dramatic and quite funny. I want it less than 300 words.

Dear Owner, 

I am writing to you today with unfortunate news: The dog absolutely has to go. 

A few weeks ago, when you brought that filthy thing home, I already knew that it was never going to work out. But, since it seemed that you were quite excited about it, I decided I would give it a chance before deciding. 

However, since that time, it has been the worst house guest I have ever seen in my life! First of all, it pooped in the middle of the floor. I mean, come on. That should be reason enough. Where is its box? 

And as if that wasn’t enough, it made the worst noise at the delivery man the other day. Screaming and shouting like a crazy person! 

Plus, it chases me all over the house! There isn’t a safe place anymore. I’ve taken to hiding up above the television unit or under your bed, but I can’t live like that forever. 

So here’s the bottom line: It’s me or the dog. Now, I know I’m not perfect, but I have lived in your house for the past five years and have barely made a peep! I’m calm, cuddly, and seriously sweet. To me, it’s a no-brainer. 

But if he’s not gone by 5:00 tomorrow, I will be going on a hunger strike. So, either watch me slowly die due to your poor decisions, or get rid of the damn dog. 

Sincerely and affectionately, 
Your Cat

prompt: Pretend to be a dog and tell me a story about you getting a job at a coffee shop serving drinks. Include lots of dialoge

messages.content: Pretend to be a dog and tell me a story about you getting a job at a coffee shop serving drinks. Include lots of dialoge

My name is Scruffy and I'm here to tell you the story about how I got a job. It's a wonderful story and I'm so excited to share it with you, so are you ready?

It was a day like any other. I was out with my owner, walking down the streets of the city where we live, when suddenly, she decided to stop. I didn't mind, though, because she went into the building where she always gets me a doggy treat and they're so good! This time, though, she didn't come out for a long time and when she did, it was without a treat.

"Scruffy! I got a job!" she told me. She picked up my leash and showed me the new clothes she was holding. There was a drawing on them; it was the same as the one on the building.

A job? I thought. What did that mean? Was she going to leave me?

"Don't worry," she said, petting my head. "I got you a job too."

I didn't know what this meant, but the next morning, we returned to the same place. This time, instead of leaving me outside like usual, she brought me into the building with her. It smelled so good and people were sitting at all the tables, slowly drinking out of warm cups.

"Come here, Scruffy," my owner said.

She led me behind the counter and held up a harness. I sniffed it. It smelled strange, like the drink she always brought out with my doggy treat. With a smile, she pulled the harness over my head and fastened it in place. There were strange cup holders on either side of it, but she assured me that everything was alright, so I didn't worry.

"You're going to bring the customers their drinks and treats," my owner explained. She slipped two cups into the holders of my harness and pointed to a couple across the room. "Go to them."

I was wary but did as she said. As soon as they had their drinks, they gave me a doggy treat! When I returned to my owner, she gave me more drinks and pointed out a different person. He waved a doggy treat at me and I was off. Since that day, I've joined my owner at the cafe every day.

prompt: What is a pace bowler in cricket, and how fast can pace bowlers deliver the ball?

messages.content: What is a pace bowler in cricket, and how fast can pace bowlers deliver the ball?

Pace balling is also called fast balling. The bowler delivers the ball with speed through the air so that any movement through the air (in-swing, out-swing, reverse swing) or deviation of the pitch makes it difficult for the batsman to compensate in time.

Pace bowlers can:
1. Change the pace of the delivery: even slight variations in pace can significantly increase the difficulty for a Batman.
2. Swing the ball: competent bowlers can swing the ball in from left to right (in-swing); or out from right to left (outswing) or deploy reverse swing ( the ball moves in the opposite direction to expectations) using an older ball. 
3. Yorker: an ideal yorker is delivered at full length to bounce (pitch) under the bat (or foot line) of a Batman.
4. Bouncer: these delivers are balled at high speeds to bounce in the first half of the pitch, which makes them rise steeply. This makes it difficult for the batsman to track the ball and they may resort to trying to evade it in order not to get hit in the chest or face.

There are countless other variations available to a pace baller.

The quickest pace bowlers bowl in the high 90mph range and express bowlers, like Shoaib Akhtar has bowled at 100.2mph.

prompt: Hi! I really want to install a pool in my yard. Can you tell me a bit about the different types of pools?

messages.content: Hi! I really want to install a pool in my yard. Can you tell me a bit about the different types of pools?

Sure! Here are the different types of pools you might want to consider:

1. Inground Pool: Inground pools are permanent structures built into the ground. They offer a wide range of design possibilities and can be customized in terms of shape, size, and materials.
2. Above-Ground Pool: Above-ground pools are installed on top of the ground with a framework made of metal, resin, or wood. They are more affordable and easier to install compared to inground pools. 
3. Infinity Pool: Infinity pools, also known as vanishing-edge or negative-edge pools, create the illusion of the water extending to the horizon. They feature at least one edge that spills over into a catch basin, giving a seamless blend with the surrounding environment. They're expensive but popular due to their aesthetic appeal. 
4. Lap Pool: Lap pools are specifically designed for swimming laps and exercise. They're long and narrow, allowing swimmers to swim continuously without interruptions. Lap pools can be either inground or above ground, and they usually have a consistent depth throughout the pool.
5. Swim Spa: A swim spa is a combination of a small pool and a spa. It features a powerful current that allows you to swim in place, providing the benefits of swimming and hydrotherapy. Swim spas are smaller than traditional pools, so they can fit more easily in your yard.
6. Hot Tub: Hot tubs, also known as spas or jacuzzis, are small, heated pools designed for relaxation, hydrotherapy, and enjoyment. They often have built-in jets that provide massaging and therapeutic effects. Hot tubs can be either inground or above ground and are usually small.

prompt:
Turn these stanzas into a short story about Sam McGee.

Now Sam McGee was from Tennessee, where the cotton blooms and blows.
Why he left his home in the South to roam 'round the Pole, God only knows.
He was always cold, but the land of gold seemed to hold him like a spell;
Though he'd often say in his homely way that "he'd sooner live in hell."

On a Christmas Day we were mushing our way over the Dawson trail.
Talk of your cold! through the parka's fold it stabbed like a driven nail.
If our eyes we'd close, then the lashes froze till sometimes we couldn't see;
It wasn't much fun, but the only one to whimper was Sam McGee.

And that very night, as we lay packed tight in our robes beneath the snow,
And the dogs were fed, and the stars o'erhead were dancing heel and toe,
He turned to me, and "Cap," says he, "I'll cash in this trip, I guess;
And if I do, I'm asking that you won't refuse my last request."

Well, he seemed so low that I couldn't say no; then he says with a sort of moan:
"It's the cursèd cold, and it's got right hold till I'm chilled clean through to the bone.
Yet 'tain't being dead—it's my awful dread of the icy grave that pains;
So I want you to swear that, foul or fair, you'll cremate my last remains."

Turn these stanzas into a short story about Sam McGee.

I was once a captain of gold-finding expeditions in the Artic when I met an unusual man named Sam McGee. Sam was a Southern man from the warm hills of Tennessee. The closest thing to snow he had seen was the blooming of the cotton fields until he decided to follow the enticing lure of gold up around the Pole and joined my team. The cold was a shock to his system and he complained endlessly about how much he hated the Artic and would rather live in hell. 

As we mushed over the Dawson Trail one Christmas Day, the weather was particularly bitter. The cold seeped in through our heavy parkas and stung like nails. Sometimes, if we closed our eyes for too long the lashes would freeze them shut and we'd be temporarily blinded. Everyone on the expedition was unbearably cold, but it was only Sam McGee who whined aloud.
 
That night, we built our camp and fed the dogs. The men and I packed in like sardines beneath the snow and bundled in robes to fight against the cold. Nights in the Artic are often starry and beautiful, and that night was no exception. I was watching the stars twinkle and glow when Sam McGee leaned over to me and informed me that he expected to die on this trek and that he had a request of me. Sam was so sorrowful that I humored him as he moaned about the frigid cold eating him to the bone. He wasn't made for this weather and was fearful that when he'd die he would be buried in the ice for eternity. That's when he asked me to swear that should he die I would cremate his body instead of burying it up here in the snow.

prompt: I need to write a paper about a specific decade. Can you give me one important event that happened in each year in the 1990s?

messages.content: I need to write a paper about a specific decade. Can you give me one important event that happened in each year in the 1990s?

- 1990: East and West Germany are reunited. This event was important as it marked a new era in global politics after the collapse of the Soviet Union.
- 1991: The Internet becomes available for commercial use. The widespread availability of the Internet revolutionized almost every aspect of modern living.
- 1992: Bill Clinton is elected President of the United States. Bill Clinton's presidency is notable for his efforts to reduce the budget deficit and his involvement in a scandal later in the decade.
- 1993: NAFTA is signed into law. This impacted trade relations going forward and is still a hotly discussed issue today.
- 1994: Nelson Mandela becomes President of South Africa. Nelson Mandela played a major role in the dissolution of apartheid in South Africa, and the advancement of human rights.
- 1995: Ebay is founded. The convenience of a single-stop place to shop from home radically altered how consumers shop for goods.
- 1996: "Ask Jeeves" is created. Not the first Internet search engine, but this website created and popularized a means of interacting with the Internet that shaped how people expect the web to work.
- 1997: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone is published. The popularity of the Harry Potter series shaped the interests and values of an entire generation of children.
- 1998: Google is founded. Google revolutionized the way we access information on the Internet.
- 1999: Bill Clinton faces impeachment. Bill Clinton is the first president to have been impeached in the modern era. This had long-reaching effects on politics going forward.

prompt: Create an ingenious short story about a sock who wishes he was a shoe. It should be very funny and about 250 words.

messages.content: Create an ingenious short story about a sock who wishes he was a shoe. It should be very funny and about 250 words.

There once was a sock who wished he was a shoe. But alas, there was nothing he could do. He was bound to be a sock, stuck glued to a foot, stinky and sweaty, and no fun at all. 

The sock so badly wanted to experience life as a shoe. To walk around outside, feel rain and mud and grass underneath. He couldn’t feel anything except that damn shoe! 

Feet were fine, really, but it would be much to have a thick layer between him and the foot. Sometimes he even thought about convincing the foot to wear another sock before putting him on, but that really wouldn’t be fair to the other sock. Then he wouldn’t even be able to feel the shoe! 

To be a shoe meant dancing, running, and skipping; it meant being seen and adored by everyone! How many times had the sock heard a muffled voice saying, “Oh, I love your shoes!” They never said, “Wow, those are great socks!” 

No one spent big money on socks as they did on shoes; they didn’t appreciate socks and put them on shelves or even in a nice row by the door. He and all the other socks were just thrown into a dark drawer to be forgotten! 

The sock simply hated not being a shoe. Although, being a sock was better than getting lost in the dryer. So he held on tight every time he was drying and kept living his life as a sock, hoping to be a shoe.

To All:

Good morning everyone; I hope you’re all feeling good for the week ahead. 

I do have a quick thought I want to talk about with you all, and that’s your coffee consumption. It seems to me that you are all drinking almost an absurd amount of coffee. I am working morning until night to prepare coffee for you, and I have to tell you, I am simply exhausted.

Although I understand that you need hot beverages to get you through the day, I think many of you are overlooking my good friend Ketlle in the corner of the breakroom. She would love to be used more - I spoke to her personally - to make you all tea throughout the day!

Thank you for your time and future consideration, 
Coffee Machine

prompt: Write a fictional paragraph for me about Princess Tiana becoming queen of Maldonia.

messages.content: Write a fictional paragraph for me about Princess Tiana becoming queen of Maldonia.

Tiana stood behind her mother and mother-in-law, one hand on the shoulder of each great lady. She was so very glad they were here with her, helping her pave the way toward her throne. Though one had been born into wealth and privilege and the other born into a second-class, pigeonholed status where people with her skin color rarely raised themselves out of struggling mightily every day to meet their basic needs, something bigger brought them to equal footing. It was grief. Loss. A year ago, after a battle with a slow but incurable illness, Naveen's mother lost the man she'd been married to for nearly 40 years. There seemed to be a quiet understanding between the two women, sisters in heartache. 
Not that is was so dark as all that. Upon learning of his father's illness, Tiana and Naveen did something she'd never imagined. They'd sold the restaurant, packed up their New Orleans home, and asked the nanny that looked after their two daughters to accompany them across the sea. The girls, Lottie and Elodie, were doing fine. They'd barely understood that they were princesses, and all this was a grand adventure. Tiana felt a pinch in her stomach anytime she looked at Lottie. Her oldest, her girl that now would grow to one day be queen. It was better than being barred from half of life in the bayou, but it was far from a normal life. 
"You're worrying, darling," her mother said, pulling Tiana from her misgivings. 
"This is Naveen's birthright dear, and I have a surprise for you," the queen said. "Follow me." 
Tiana followed the queen mother down the winding, tapestried stone walls of the castle. She'd never get used to how sprawling the palace was, how many rooms there were. This walk wasn't comforting her. 
That was until the queen mother pulled open a door and said, "Oh, I hope you like it!" 
"Oh," Tiana said at first, words beyond her. 
There before her was a fully equipped, top-of-the-line kitchen. Every tool she could imagine and some she'd never laid eyes on before gleamed under the bright lights. Rolling pins stood sentinel beside marble slabs meant to evenly cool chocolate. And, best of all, in pride of place, stood a framed picture of her father.

prompt: Write me a short fanfic about Meghan and Harry - keep it clean, make it current, and include some subtle trauma.  Make it a little old-fashioned in tone, maybe a tad Gothic.

messages.content: Write me a short fanfic about Meghan and Harry - keep it clean, make it current, and include some subtle trauma.  Make it a little old-fashioned in tone, maybe a tad Gothic.

Every time Meghan forgot about that dream, it would come back to startle her.  Each and every time she thought, "I'll tell my therapist about it," but then thoughts of the dream would fade away in the course of her very busy day, and other concerns would take their place.  Besides, her husband's sleepy face and the feeling of his muscular body against hers would make the past seem irrelevant, at least for the moment.  He has his own traumas to deal with, she would tell herself, though this was a contradictory thought because she relied as much on his solidity as he relied on her good taste.  She knew they could talk about anything, and yet... this one was tough.

She would dream of a house.  It was a bit like Nott-Cott, and a bit like Frogmore, but not really... there were elements of California in there too, but not current California - this was something from the 80s.  This house felt like a whole past life.  She found family heirlooms mixed with Dr. Seuss books, old trophies, and old fine arts posters you might find in the room of an aspirational teenager, plus some of her favorite high school clothing items in a high chest of drawers.  But there was a whole sector of the house she could not visit. She would not visit.  Evil lurked there.  She had a memory of having visited those rooms, and terror struck her heart.  

Each time, she woke up winded.  Harry would take her in his arms and ask, "Are you all right, my love?" and she would say "Yes."  This morning would be different.  It was 5 am, and the children were still asleep.  The house personnel was busily preparing the day's business downstairs, and Meghan would seize the moment.  They would have coffee in bed, and she would tell him all about it.  But first, she slipped down into the sheets and wrapped her arms around her sleeping husband's back, planting a kiss between his shoulder blades.

prompt:
Summarize this in 30-50 words. 

Why should learning be collaborative?
Collaborative learning is a method of active learning that relies on the principle of two or more students working together, towards a common goal. These activities vary widely, but most centre on the learner’s exploration or application of the curriculum, not simply on the teacher’s point of view.

Collaborative learning arms pupils with the confidence to teach and learn from their peers and teachers, too. In primary schools especially, collaborative learning will help develop soft skills at an earlier age, helping children become more effective communicators.

The differences between collaborative learning and cooperative learning can be interchangeable for educators, however, collaborative learning encourages students to make individual progress in tandem with others. Co-operative learning, meanwhile, promotes accountability with interdependence. Find out more about the benefits of collaborative learning.

messages.content: You're a teenage girl explaining the Kpop group NCT to your exasperated mom. Give me a 5-10 sentence paragraph about the different units and how they work.

Okay, so hear me out, mom. NCT as a whole is made up of a bunch of different subunits, right? There's NCT 127, which is a fixed unit that added in some new members early on, but mostly stays the same. Then there's NCT Dream, which initially was going to be a rotational concept where the members graduated and moved on from the group when they turned 18, but fans didn't like that, so now they're a fixed unit too. There's also WayV, which is an NCT unit that is more focused on the Chinese music industry. They make songs in Mandarin, English, and Korean. Plus, all of the members can do different projects together regardless of their subunits under the name NCT U. That's why we've got songs like Baby Don't Stop with Ten from WayV and Taeyong from NCT 127. It's actually really cool, I swear!

Extract all names of animals. In parenthesis, denote how many times the word was used. Then, arrange them in order of most frequent to least frequent usage with one word per line. If there is a tie, place them on the same line separated by a comma.

Here's the text:

The Wolf & the Sheep
A Wolf had been hurt in a fight with a Bear. He was unable to move and could not satisfy his hunger and thirst. A Sheep passed by near his hiding place, and the Wolf called to him.

"Please fetch me a drink of water," he begged, "that might give me strength enough so I can get me some solid food."

"Solid food!" said the Sheep. "That means me, I suppose. If I should bring you a drink, it would only serve to wash me down your throat. Don't talk to me about a drink!"

prompt: Write a Mermaid’s lullaby comforting her child through a storm. Mention the storm’s elements and the docks. Write 4 stanzas, and make them rhyme or assonant.

messages.content: Write a Mermaid’s lullaby comforting her child through a storm. Mention the storm’s elements and the docks. Write 4 stanzas, and make them rhyme or assonant.

Hush, little child, you’re safe now and warm, 
deep in our grotto, safe from the storm.
The swells may surge wildly, the frigid winds bite, 
but here underwater, you’re safe through the night.

Above us are storm clouds, thunder, and lightning, 
but here down below, there’s nothing that’s frightening. 
Though the waves may crash loudly, up on the rocks,
they can’t harm us here, deep under the docks. 

In your bed of soft kelp, above the white sand,
do not be frightened; hold onto my hand.
Feel the soft currents, gently they sway,
your cradle of seashells; let the tides play. 

The sun will return, it’ll waken your fish.
You’ll play once again, I promise you this. 
For now, relax, settle in, close your eyes, 
we’ll sleep the storm out, and await the sunrise.

prompt: Suggest some good places to eat in Hackney, I am Vegan and don't like Indian food.

messages.content: Suggest some good places to eat in Hackney, I am Vegan and don't like Indian food.

Here are some vegan options that you can try in Hackney:

1. Black Cat Cafe - serves a range of comfort food, including bagels and pancakes. Its food is inspired by the many cultures in London and therefore has a wide range of food on offer. It even has a bookshop!
2. Temple of Seitan - serves vegan chicken made from seitan. Great if you are craving some classic junk food without the meat, but at a slightly elevated price!
3. The Spread Eagle - the first 100% vegan pub in London, serving vegan beer alongside traditional vegan versions of pub food. If you want something a bit more exotic, they also serve food from the street food start-up Club Mexicana.

prompt: Create three (3) characters for a book (any book) but when you describe them, describe their physical attributes in terms of food and/or drink.

messages.content: Create three (3) characters for a book (any book) but when you describe them, describe their physical attributes in terms of food and/or drink.

Marco:

Marco was a tall drink of water. His back was wide like a pair of pork chops, and the muscles of his arms were like large gumdrops covered with a layer of fondant skin. His legs were also muscly and veiny, like a pair of thick licorice ropes under blueberry jeans.

Marco was a happy-go-lucky fella who had the personality of a cool refreshing lime soda on a hot day and the reliability of a good old Snickers bar when one gets hungry. When Marco sits down to do work at his computer, his attention to detail is as awe-inspiring as a cake decorator making a three-tiered wedding cake.

Kate:

Kate had the skin of a pint of silky vanilla ice cream. Her lips were like cherries on top of the vanilla ice cream, while her hair was dark brown like that of hot fudge. Her facial appearance was that of a delicious hot fudge sundae, dotted with two almonds for eyes.

Kate was always cool as a cucumber and as solid as a jawbreaker. But she also had a nougaty soft spot for puppies. When she would get home from ordering sushi from the local restaurant, she would melt contentedly into her lounge chair as a snow cone melts into its cone-shaped cup.

Sierra:

Sierra had the appearance of a cool mocha drink from a vintage coffee shop. Her lithe frame was like a pretzel stick, and her hair was a whitish-blue hue like freshly spun cotton candy. Sierra was the bubbliest of the three of them, having a personality like that of a boba tea and the taste of sweet, tangy candy. 

But where she was sweet in personality, she was also as bland and no-nonsense as a macaroni salad without the mayonnaise when it came to doing work. She liked the routine of work, and she made sure her work life mimicked that of molasses dripping from the top of a cinnamon bun: slow and steady.
