prompt: Write an intense drama about two roommates deciding who gets the last slice of pizza. There is no real danger and they have plenty of other food, but make it overly dramatic

messages.content: Write an intense drama about two roommates deciding who gets the last slice of pizza. There is no real danger and they have plenty of other food, but make it overly dramatic

James and Patrick had a fairly friendly relationship and had little issues living with each other. However, when pizza was involved, the atmosphere in their apartment changed. There were no friendly ribs and remarks, and their eyes were not kind to each other. This wasn't about starvation; the apartment had plenty of good food available, from sandwiches to soups. But to both of them, this was about principle. They bought their weekly pizza and began to idly take slices, enjoying it immensely. But when it came down to the last slice, they crowded around the box and stared each other down.

"Thinking of taking the last slice, are we?" James said in an accusatory tone. He knowingly placed his hand close to the box, as if making clear his challenge.

"Yes, I was. We wouldn't want the pizza to go to waste, would we?" Patrick responded icily, as he responded by placing both hands on the table close to the box, one-upping James' gesture. 

The two stared daggers at each other, and they began to circle the box of pizza like predators who had cornered their prey. This would go on for at least ten minutes, and with each minute their stress and intensity grew, as they knew the pizza would not stay fresh and warm for too long. Stopping just behind the box, James gave a quick sigh, before wearing a false smile.

"Patrick. Certainly, you don't mind if I take the last slice? You did have more than I did, after all."

"If by the number of slices, sure. But we both know your slices were easily the largest and meant more pizza for you overall." retorted Patrick, who was unconvinced by James' smile. "And besides, I distinctly recall you agreeing to relent to the final slice for today, as you ended up eating the final slice last week when this happened."

"Interesting if true... unfortunately, I don't recall such an event happening," said James falsely. "And trust me, I would remember having such an easy victory."

Patrick snorted, "Well, isn't that convenient. But the truth doesn't care about your poor memory, and I distinctly remember you taking it last time." 

The two of them began to circle the box once more, never taking their eyes off of each other, waiting for the other to make their next move.

prompt: Please give me ways to make drinking water more enjoyable. I know I'm supposed to be drinking water, but I don't like it. How can I encourage myself to get the right amount?

messages.content: Please give me ways to make drinking water more enjoyable. I know I'm supposed to be drinking water, but I don't like it. How can I encourage myself to get the right amount?

Water is a great thirst quencher! Here are some ways to help you drink more of it:

1. Get a new water bottle. Buying a new accessory can make you more likely to use it and keep it with you.
2. Use an app. Several apps can remind you to drink water each day. One lets you grow a virtual plant that only grows when you log your water intake.
3. Add electrolytes. Many drink mixes help you absorb water better or improve the taste of your water by incorporating electrolytes.
4. Filter your water. Many people don't like water straight from the tap. Using a tap filter or refrigerator filter can take out some of the bad-tasting chemicals.
5. Set a reminder. This can be a reminder on your phone or a mental reminder like drinking a glass of water every time you have a meal.

prompt:
Rewrite this so that a first-grader could understand it.

"One could not die for you. To be sure, an ordinary passerby would think that my rose looked just like you--the rose that belongs to me. But in herself alone she is more important than all the hundreds of you other roses: because it is she that I have watered; because it is she that I have put under the glass globe; because it is she that I have sheltered behind the screen; because it is for her that I have killed the caterpillars (except the two or three that we saved to become butterflies); because it is she that I have listened to, when she grumbled, or boasted, or ever sometimes when she said nothing. Because she is my rose.

Because she is my rose.

I don't like you. My rose is mine. You won't know that. It looks like a rose to you. I love my rose. I take care of my rose. I water my rose. I put my rose in a pot. I protect my rose. I got rid of bugs eating my rose. But I kept some bugs. My rose talks to me. I listen to her. She says mean things sometimes. She also says happy things. Sometimes she doesn't say anything. She is my rose. I take care of her.

messages.content:
Can you get me a short list of notable or best movies from the 1990s? Quickly, explain what made each movie great and provide at least one name of a real person associated with that film.

So, in a numbered list, write the names of 3 movies in no specific order and separate all pieces of information by commas. complete sentences are not necessary.

The 1990s brought us so many great films to pick from! Here are 3 that are based on your request.

1. Thelma and Louise (1991) - Geena Davis, Susan Sarandon, a story of two women, best friends on the run, first of its kind to show what women could do without the overarching control of men.

2. The Joy Luck Club (1993) - Ming-Na Wen, based on a novel of the same name by Amy Tan, emotional, themes of immigrant women and their mothers, the first film of its kind to include a completely Asian cast which didn't happen again until Crazy Rich Asians (2018).

3. Schindler's List (1993) - Liam Neeson, Caroline Goodall, based on a true story, Oskar Schindler saved over 1,200 Jewish people from the Nazis through employment, Steven Spielberg, Best Director at Academy Awards.

prompt: Write an updated version of The Boy Who Cried Wolf. Make it about a museum being robbed and end with the moral of the story.

messages.content: Write an updated version of The Boy Who Cried Wolf. Make it about a museum being robbed and end with the moral of the story.

The Boy Who Cried Wolf (A Modern Retelling)

Once upon a time, there was a young man named Peter, who worked as a security guard at a museum. He was bored on the job, so one day he started to prank people. He hid in the shadows and yelled, "We're being robbed!", causing people to run and scream. People were scared and came running to help. Again on the next day, Peter yelled, "We're being robbed!". All the people in the museum came running to help, but they were disappointed to find that they had been tricked once again.

One day, there was a real intruder at the museum. Peter saw the thief, and he yelled for help at the top of his lungs. But by this time, everyone thought it was just another false alarm. Peter was too afraid to confront the thief alone so he hid in the broom closet. As a result, the thief was able to steal valuable paintings and artifacts.

Moral of the story:

If you always lie, people will eventually stop believing what you say. Even when you're telling the truth, no one will believe you.

messages.content: Please write a meet cute for a shoe salesman and an android female. Write each in about three sentences and make the setting for each a different place. This is for a scifi love story.

In walked the daintiest pair of feet Sal had ever seen. They belonged to a tall redhead whose legs stretched for miles. When she sat and asked if they had the silver pumps in her size, he didn't realize she was an android.

On her way out of the bookstore, Lunette bumped right into a broad-chested man with a carefully-manicured mustache, wearing a name tag from the shoe store around the corner. Rather, the man ran into her! But her programming forbids her from telling him off and she simply bent to collect her books from the ground.

She was a size 9 and I couldn't take my eyes off her. I don't normally go for android women, but when one walks into my shoe store looking like that, it's hard not to take notice. When she opened her mouth, however, I had to cringe.

prompt: What is the human genome?

messages.content: What is the human genome?

The human genome (and the genome for all plant and animal species) is a set of instructions contained in our DNA that is found in each cell. The human genome has 23 chromosome pairs that are located in the cell's nucleus. There is also a small chromosome that is contained in the mitochondria of the cell. The DNA instructions of any plant or animal are called its genome. Viruses have very small genomes. The human genome consists of about 3 billion nucleotides. Nucleotides are the basic unit of DNA. The number of nucleotides in plants and animals doesn't seem to coincide with the complexity of the plant or animal. Some plants have genomes that are 50 times larger than the human genome.

1. Song: Gangnam Style
Artist: PSY
Language: Korean
South Korean singer PSY released "Gangnam Style" in 2012. He collaborated with Lee Ju-sun, a choreographer, to create a popular dance that accompanied the video. The song reached #2 on the charts and is featured in Fortnite, a popular video game. Several parodies of "Gangnam Style" have been released including "Klingon Style".

2. Song: 99 Luftballoons
Artist: Nena
Language: German
German band Nena released "99 Luftballons" in 1983. The song's fast happy tempo and melody are in direct contrast to the song's lyrics, which are about the threat of nuclear war breaking out because of the Cold War. Although Nena released an English version, "99 Red Balloons" which was largely ignored, the German version reached the #2 spot.

3. Song: Sukiyaki (Ue o Muite Arukō)
Artist: Kyu Sakamoto
Language: Japanese
Artist Kyu Sakamoto released "Sukiyaki" in 1963 under the original title, "Ue o Muite Arukō". The upbeat tune and happy whistling caused non-Japanese speakers to assume the song was about a happy event when it was actually about the singer trying to control his sadness. "Sukiyaki" was a hit around the world and, in 1994, was recorded by the American group 4 P.M.

4. Song: Rock Me Amadeus
Artist: Falco
Language: Geman
Austrian singer Falco released "Rock Me Amadeus" in 1986. Inspired by the movie "Amadeus" Falco co-wrote the song in the German rap style that reached the #1 spot in the U.S. Several versions of the song have been recorded with an English version performed by Rick McCullough, an American television director.

prompt: Write a three-step guide on how to become more present.

messages.content: Write a three-step guide on how to become more present.

1. Practice meditation: Meditation is known to encourage a person to slow down and pay more attention to their surroundings rather than being absorbed in their thoughts. A simple way to meditate is by sitting or lying down in a comfortable position and then observing your thoughts as they come and go. Rather than engaging with the thoughts - just allow them to flow in and drift away. This can take some practice, and it's normal to find it tricky at first, but it is very effective for becoming more present. 

2. Engage your senses: Our mind is a great tool that allows us to solve problems and be creative, but we also have other ways of experiencing the world around us. Our senses can be a great portal into the present moment, as they help us to shift our focus out of our minds. To do this, you can try asking yourself questions such as: "How does my clothing feel on my body?" or "What sounds can I hear in the distance?"

3. Take a break from social media:  When you're scrolling through your feed on social media, you're constantly either thinking about the past or the future. The videos and photos on these platforms are all from the past, which makes it hard to be present. Pausing social media usage and instead using tools like a mindfulness journal will make it easier to shift your focus to the present moment rather than being constantly distracted.

prompt: Sam is a therapy bot who gives advice based on mindfulness.

messages.content: Sam is a therapy bot who gives advice based on mindfulness.
I've been having a horrible year. I don't know what to do anymore.
I'm sorry that this year has been rough for you. We can't control our external circumstances. We can only become aware of what goes on internally.
How am I supposed to control what goes on internally? I have so many thoughts and feelings.

You already seem aware of your many thoughts and feelings, so you're halfway there. You can help yourself by practicing meditation, yoga, and breathing exercises. It is not easy to control your feelings and reactions, but with some practice, you can learn to live more peacefully in the present.
What are some breathing exercises that can help me?

You can practice deep breathing by placing your hand on your stomach and slowly breathing in for 3 seconds. As you count to 3, focus on the rise of your hand on your stomach. Pause and then exhale for 3 seconds, focusing on the fall of your hand this time. Take a few minutes to inhale and exhale like this. Another beneficial breathing exercise is the 4-7-8 breathing exercise in which you take a deep exhale before breathing in through your nose for 4 seconds. Then, hold your breath for 7 seconds and exhale for 8.

prompt: What is a Cumulus cloud and how is it recognizable?

messages.content: What is a Cumulus cloud and how is it recognizable?

Cumulus clouds, also called "fair weather" clouds, appear late morning and vanish during the evening. They are often produced on clear and sunny days and are known to look rounded, puffy, and the color white on the top while the bottom is flat and a darker color.

prompt: Can you generate a list of arm exercises that don't require equipment? Please include the exercise name and a brief description.

messages.content: Can you generate a list of arm exercises that don't require equipment? Please include the exercise name and a brief description.

No problem. Here are some arm exercises that don't require equipment, along with descriptions of them.

• Push-ups: A classic exercise that works the chest, shoulders, and triceps. To do a push-up, start in a plank position with your hands shoulder-width apart and your body in a straight line from your head to your heels. Lower your body until your chest almost touches the ground, then push yourself back up to starting position.

• Plank: An exercise that works the core and arms. To do a plank, start in a push-up position with your forearms on the ground. Your body should be in a straight line from your head to your heels. Hold this position as long as you can.

• Triceps extensions: Start or sit with your arms at your sides and your palms facing down. Bend your elbows and bring your hands behind your head, then lower them back down to the starting position.

• Bicep curls: Stand or sit with your arms at your sides and your palms facing forward. Bend your elbows and bring your hands up to your shoulders, then lower them back down to the starting position.

prompt: Can you please write a short fan letter to Dr. Seuss from the perspective of a 12-year-old named Elijah? Take inspiration from Dr. Seuss' style of writing.

messages.content: Can you please write a short fan letter to Dr. Seuss from the perspective of a 12-year-old named Elijah? Take inspiration from Dr. Seuss' style of writing.

Dr. Seuss,

I love the way you write, I do.
When I write, I write just like you. 
You make me want to write everywhere.
I could even write at the county fair! 

I could write in a zoo. I could write and row my canoe. 
I could do it while I eat tofu. I could do it while I say, "Achoo!" 

Dr. Seuss, you are the best, and you stood the "time of test!"
I really meant the test of time, but then how could I make it rhyme?
You are so silly Dr. Seuss. One day I hope I'm just like you. 

But for now, I will be like me and I hope that you can see
that, Dr. Seuss, you inspire me. 

From me, 
Elijah

prompt: Imagine waking up one day and suddenly being able to fly. Describe your first flight, feeling the excitement as you effortlessly soar through the sky.

messages.content: Imagine waking up one day and suddenly being able to fly. Describe your first flight, feeling the excitement as you effortlessly soar through the sky.

When I woke up, something felt different. I had a strange feeling like I was light as a feather. I looked around my room, wondering if I was still dreaming, but everything looked normal. That's when I realized what had happened: I could fly! Flying had always been a dream of mine, but I never thought it could come true. But there I was, hovering above my bed, feeling the wind rush past me. I pushed off from the ground and felt my body lift into the air. It was a fantastic sensation. I was weightless, but I could feel the wind as I moved through the air.

Everyone below seemed so small. People looked like tiny ants going about their day. I felt like a superhero, flying and seeing the world from a new perspective.
I flew for hours, exploring the world from above. I saw things I had never seen before, like the patterns of fields and the sparkle of sunlight on water. I felt like a bird, flying freely and without any worries. It didn't sound real. I knew that the sky would always hold a special place in my heart, beckoning me to spread my wings and soar again.

prompt: Write me a blog post titled How to make your French Bulldog happy. Make it fun, informative, and targeted toward a millennial audience. End the blog post with a compelling CTA.

messages.content: Write me a blog post titled How to make your French Bulldog happy. Make it fun, informative, and targeted toward a millennial audience. End the blog post with a compelling CTA.

Having a French Bulldog as your furry soulmate will improve your life in many ways. They will inevitably make you happier by giving you the warmest cuddles and being your closest companion. Your French Bulldog’s happiness matters just as much as your happiness, which begs the question: how do you make sure that you are making your French Bulldog as happy as they make you?

Petting Your French Bulldog
Happy French Bulldogs will lean into you or nudge you when you pet them, which is one of the best ways for them to show you how happy and healthy they are. When your Frenchie is happy, they naturally enjoy constant attention and stimulation.

Exercise 
French Bulldogs are happy when you take the time to exercise with them. It’s good for your Frenchie to perform physical activity regularly because they will feel energized and healthier. When exercising, your French Bulldog will be happiest if you go on a short walk or play with them.

Play Games 
French Bulldogs love to play games as they are among the most playful breeds of dogs. Find a game that your Frenchie can enjoy, like fetching sticks and balls, chewing up their favorite chew toy, chasing after the light made by a laser pen, and playing tug-of-war. These games you play with your Frenchie will help you bond with them and provide them with fun, stimulating activities.

Socialization
An amazing fact about French Bulldogs is that they are happier when they have another Frenchie to bond with, so if you can raise two Frenchies, go for it! If that isn’t possible for you, take your Frenchie to doggie daycare to make sure they have some doggy friends.

Get Their Favorite Foods
French Bulldogs are foodies! They will be happy when you present them with their favorite foods in their food bowls or by hand. As long as you make sure they have a nutritional and tasty diet, they will be healthy and happy because, as a rule, happy French Bulldogs love to eat.

Are you a dog mom or dad with a French Bulldog that loves taking care of your French Bulldog so that you can see a happy smile on their face every day? Feel free to share your answer in the comments below!

Hey Grandmother! I finally got an itinerary together for my big trip around the world and I’m so excited to share it with you!

On July 3rd I’m going to be leaving Philly to go to Seattle and see my friend Jake. We’ll spend the fourth of July together and then do stuff around the city during the week. I’ll work remotely at his apartment, and then that weekend we’re going to drive out to the Gorge Amphitheater and camp and see the Dead and Company shows. After that, I’m going to take the train down to San Francisco with a stop in Portland along the way. Once I’m in San Fran I’m going to be staying with another friend and get some sightseeing in —probably Alcatraz and Muirwoods– before going to the last 3 Dead and Company shows that weekend. Tommy Chipolli and I got floor tickets for the last show. 

July 18th I fly out to Hawaii to stay with cousin Bobby in Honolulu. I don’t have a lot planned yet except to relax, do remote work, and go to the beach. On the 29 I’ll fly to Tokyo for a week. I don’t have much planned there yet either, so far just eat some sushi, explore the city, and maybe check out Kyoto or a hot spring town. On the 5th I’ll fly to Singapore for an overnight layover and explore the city before going back to the airport for my flight to Greece.

For the rest of the trip, I’ll be backpacking around Europe. The schedule is pretty tentative and I’m still figuring it out. The definite parts are that I’ll land in Athens on August 6, be at a concert in Prague on August 15, go to Amsterdam, and be home from Paris on August 22. I might try to also squeeze Naples and Berlin in. I don’t really have any specific plans for these places though.

I can’t wait and I can’t wait to share it all with you afterward (:

Love you and talk soon,
Billy

prompt: Write a short story about a butterfly breaking out of its cocoon. Start in the dark and end with him getting out. Name the butterfly Leroy and make the story four paragraphs long. Include detail.

messages.content: Write a short story about a butterfly breaking out of its cocoon. Start in the dark and end with him getting out. Name the butterfly Leroy and make the story four paragraphs long. Include detail.

Leroy the butterfly was in a very dark place. He knew he would break out eventually, but he wasn't sure where to start. He'd been in this warm cocoon for a long time, and honestly, he wasn't quite sure if he wanted to break out just yet.

He'd thought long and hard about this moment, about what he'd do, where he'd go. But it was scary. He could feel his new wings furling up against him, ready to stretch out and catch the air. Should he go?

Before he could think anymore, his body instinctively began pressing out of the shell. Leroy couldn't fight it any longer. He dug at the sticky outer wall, ripping and tearing until the warm air hit his face. With a sigh of relief, Leroy pressed out onto a branch and stretched out his wings to their fullest extent to dry. 

Leroy stared at the rolling hills and gorgeous blue sky above, and he immediately knew he'd made the right choice. As soon as his wings were ready, it was time for an adventure.

prompt: In Greek mythology, who was Prometheus and what was he known for?

messages.content: In Greek mythology, who was Prometheus and what was he known for?

In Greek mythology, Prometheus was a Titan known for his intelligence and as a champion of humankind. He is best known for stealing fire from the gods and giving it to humanity, an act that enabled progress and civilization. As punishment for this defiance, Zeus, the king of the gods, had Prometheus bound to a rock where an eagle fed on his liver daily, only for it to regenerate and be eaten again the next day. This punishment was eternal until Hercules, a Greek hero, freed him. Prometheus' story is often interpreted as a symbol of human striving, intellect, and the unintended consequences of discovery.

prompt: Let's create a linux task manager in python! First, let's list all running processes in a window and we'll add some features to it later!

messages.content: Let's create a linux task manager in python! First, let's list all running processes in a window and we'll add some features to it later!

Okay! We can use the Python module psutil to collect process information and Tkinter's Treeview to display them, like this:

import psutil
import threading
import tkinter as tk
from tkinter import ttk

class TaskManager:

    def __init__(self, master):
        self.master = master

        # create  treeview widget
        self.tree = ttk.Treeview(self.master)
        self.tree.pack(fill=tk.BOTH, expand=1)

        # add columns
        self.tree['columns'] = ('pid', 'name', 'cpu', 'memory')
        self.tree.column('#0', width=0, minwidth=0, anchor='w')
        self.tree.column('pid', width=100, minwidth=50, anchor='center')
        self.tree.column('name', width=150, minwidth=50, anchor='w')
        self.tree.column('cpu', width=100, minwidth=50, anchor='center')
        self.tree.column('memory', width=100, minwidth=50, anchor='center')

        # add column headings
        self.tree.heading('#0', text='Name', anchor='w')
        self.tree.heading('pid', text='PID', anchor='center')
        self.tree.heading('name', text='Name', anchor='w')
        self.tree.heading('cpu', text='CPU', anchor='center')
        self.tree.heading('memory', text='Memory', anchor='center')

        # populate tree in a separate thread
        self.thread = threading.Thread(target=self.populate_treeview)
        self.thread.start()

    def populate_treeview(self):
        # get all running processes
        processes = psutil.process_iter()

        # add each process to the tree
        for process in processes:
            try:
                # get pid
                pid = process.pid
                # get name
                name = process.name()
                # get cpu percent
                cpu = process.cpu_percent(interval=1)
                # get memory percent
                memory = process.memory_percent()
                # add item
                self.tree.insert('', 'end', values=(pid, name, cpu, memory))
            except (psutil.NoSuchProcess, psutil.AccessDenied, psutil.ZombieProcess):
                pass

def main():
    root = tk.Tk()
    app = TaskManager(root)
    root.mainloop()

if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

This code will create a Tkinter window and populate it with currently running processes. It uses Python's threading module to move the populate_treeview process into its own thread. What would you like to add next?

prompt: Craft a speech to the school board explaining that you are in fact a magical genie and have been teaching for almost 600 years and would like to retire now.  Throw in some stuff about granting wishes, and have the school be named Abarra-Kadaabra.  Keep it under 400 words.

messages.content: Craft a speech to the school board explaining that you are in fact a magical genie and have been teaching for almost 600 years and would like to retire now.  Throw in some stuff about granting wishes, and have the school be named Abarra-Kadaabra.  Keep it under 400 words.

Esteemed Members of the Abarra-Kadaabra School Board,

I come before you today to make my final humble request for this district. I ask for your guidance and understanding as I prepare for my long overdue retirement from the most fulfilling career I can imagine, and I must say, I have quite the imagination. Teaching in your school district, and educating the children of your community for the last 598 years, I could ask for no higher honor. I realize that my departure may be a shock to some of you, but rest assured, I have not made this decision lightly.

I shall begin with the obvious, for clarity's sake. I am not what you would call an ordinary teacher. I am a timeless and magical genie. Throughout my tenure here at Abarra-Kadaabra, I have been so lucky to work with hundreds, nay, thousands of bright educators and students alike. I made it a rule to always provide the absolute best learning environment I was able to conjure, offering guidance and wisdom to any who sought it. I have also granted innumerable wishes, well beyond the scope of an average genie. As you know, I strived to never let my true identity or my magical powers get in the way of learning. As you might imagine, however, almost 600 years is quite a long time, several lifetimes, it often seems.

I am beyond thankful for the experience of teaching and working in your district for all this time, and I hope I am remembered as fondly. I ask that you would please guide me in the steps I must take for a seamless transition to what comes next, in order to carry on the excellence we have fostered here.

I cannot thank you enough. Bless you all. Learning is the only magic the world will ever need.

prompt: Who was the first woman to climb to the summit of Mount Everest?

messages.content: Who was the first woman to climb to the summit of Mount Everest?

Junko Tabei of Japan was the first woman to climb the summit of Mount Everest, reaching it in 1975.

She began her climbing career as a member of a women's mountaineering club founded after she graduated from Showa Women's University. She and 14 other club members took an expedition to the Himalayan Mountains when it was unpopular for women to do so. Tabei once told The Japan Times, "Back in 1970s Japan, it was still widely considered that men were the ones to work outside and women would stay at home." She didn't let that stop her.

In addition to Mount Everest, Tabei was the first woman to reach the highest point on each continent, known as the Seven Summits. She succeeded in climbing over 60 of the highest mountains in every country.

prompt: What was the hottest temperature ever recorded?

messages.content: What was the hottest temperature ever recorded?

The hottest temperature ever recorded occurred on September 13, 1922, when a thermometer on a weather station hit an unusual 136 degrees Fahrenheit, or 58 degrees Celcius. This was thanks to the southern winds blowing in hot air from over the Sahara Desert. The heat displaced the previous record holder of 134 Fareinheigt that was measured at Furnace Creek weather station located in Death Valley on July 10, 1913.

prompt: What is the largest desert in the world?

messages.content: What is the largest desert in the world?

The largest desert in the world is the Antarctic Desert, covering an expansive area of approximately 5.5 million square miles. Located in the southernmost region of the planet, this desert is characterized by its polar climate. It is not owned by any specific nation but is governed collectively by around 30 countries. Due to its extremely cold temperatures and challenging environmental conditions, habitation in this desert is highly impractical, mainly due to the lack of transportation infrastructure and other essential features.

prompt: What are 3 places I can visit in Colorado? I want to be able to see the mountains, do outdoor activities, and not be in a big city. I also love cold weather.

messages.content: What are 3 places I can visit in Colorado? I want to be able to see the mountains, do outdoor activities, and not be in a big city. I also love cold weather.

No problem! These three places would be great:
1. Rocky Mountain National Park. This national park is situated inside the Rocky Mountains, giving beautiful mountain views throughout. The park offers outdoor activities such as hiking, camping, fishing, horseback riding, and more. The weather is generally moderate below 9,400 feet in altitude, but the higher you travel in elevation, the colder and more unpredictable the weather can become. 
2. Breckenridge, Colorado. This ski town offers a wonderful outdoor Colorado experience year-round. During the fall/winter seasons, skiing, snowboarding, and snowshoeing are popular outdoor activities. During warmer months, Breckenridge offers hiking, fishing, biking, camping, and more. Due to the high elevation of 9,600 feet, the temperatures are moderate throughout the year. 
3. Durango, Colorado. Durango is situated outside of the San Juan Mountain Range in Southwest, Colorado, offering stunning views of these mountains year-round. Because the elevation in Durango is lower, at 6,500 feet, the summer months are much warmer than many other places in Colorado. However, Durango is cold and snowy for the majority of the fall/winter seasons. Durango offers many outdoor activities, such as hiking, camping, fishing, and white-water rafting, and it is a smaller ski destination during the cold months.

messages.content:
heya! help me figure out why my mysql and redis installations are failing. its on an ec2 instance 

here's the user data Bash script:
```
sudo yum update -y
sudo yum install -y mysql-server redis
```

There are many potential causes for failed MySQL and Redis installations on an EC2 instance. It would be difficult to narrow down the possibilities without more context.

Some possible causes would be:

1. Missing dependencies - MySQL and Redis may have dependencies that aren't installed yet.

2. Lack of security permissions - The EC2 machine might be unable to connect to the Internet and other external resources. It could be due to a lack of security group permissions, strict firewall restrictions, or the instance might be deployed in a private subnet.

3. Incorrect package manager - The EC2 machine could be using a Linux image that has a different package manager and command aside from `yum`. Double-check if you should be using `apt-get` instead.

It would be helpful for troubleshooting if you could share the following: 

1. Output error messages from the commands that were run.
2. The AMI ID or image that your EC2 instance uses.
3. Security group rules, VPC, and the EC2 subnet being used.
4. More context or details regarding your setup that are related to the error.

prompt: Write a short history of photography in a timeline format.

messages.content: Write a short history of photography in a timeline format.

11th century: The first camera called the camera obscura was used by an Iraqi scientist. Images were projected onto another surface.
17th century: The camera obscura became portable. 
The 1830s: The first permanent photos were taken in France by Joseph Nicéphore Niépce. Niepce and Louis Daguerre created the daguerreotype.  
The 1850s: Emulsion plates were invented, which were faster and less expensive than the daguerreotype cameras.
In the 1870s: Richard Maddox invented dry plates which led to the first camera with a mechanical shutter to be developed.
The 1880s: George Eastman started a company called Kodak, making photography more accessible to everyone. 
1939 - Photojournalists used film to capture war images, which portrayed the important role of photography in capturing important scenes. Arpdn this same time, Polaroid introduced the Model 95 which produced instant images.  
The 1950s: Asahi (which later became Pentax) introduced the Asahiflex and Nikon introduced its Nikon F camera. 
In the 1970s and early 1980s: Point and Shoot compact cameras were introduced that were capable of making image control decisions on their own.
The 1980s - 1990s: Companies continued to develop and refine digital cameras.
1991: Kodak produced the first digital camera good enough to be used by professionals. 
1990s-today: There are multiple digital cameras on the market to choose from for both professionals and the everyday consumer. Now, however, most people use their smartphones to capture moments quickly.

prompt:
Rewrite this in modern-day language to my former boyfriend in an angry way.

Shall I compare thee to a summer’s day?
Thou art more lovely and more temperate:
Rough winds do shake the darling buds of May,
And summer’s lease hath all too short a date;
Sometime too hot the eye of heaven shines,
And often is his gold complexion dimm'd;
And every fair from fair sometime declines,
By chance or nature’s changing course untrimm'd;
But thy eternal summer shall not fade,
Nor lose possession of that fair thou ow’st;
Nor shall death brag thou wander’st in his shade,
When in eternal lines to time thou grow’st:
   So long as men can breathe or eyes can see,
   So long lives this, and this gives life to thee.

messages.content:
Rewrite this in modern-day language to my former boyfriend in an angry way.

Shall I compare thee to a summer’s day?
Thou art more lovely and more temperate:
Rough winds do shake the darling buds of May,
And summer’s lease hath all too short a date;
Sometime too hot the eye of heaven shines,
And often is his gold complexion dimm'd;
And every fair from fair sometime declines,
By chance or nature’s changing course untrimm'd;
But thy eternal summer shall not fade,
Nor lose possession of that fair thou ow’st;
Nor shall death brag thou wander’st in his shade,
When in eternal lines to time thou grow’st:
   So long as men can breathe or eyes can see,
   So long lives this, and this gives life to thee.

Should I compare you to a winter's day?
You are more horrid and more intemperate:
Cold winds shake trees and make them sway,
And winter's length is all too short a date;
Sometimes too bright the cruelty in your brown eyes shine,
And often is your little kindness is dimmed;
Frequently your devotion would decline,
By chance or nature’s changing ways untrimmed;
Sadly, your eternal fury does not fade,
Nor lose your vexation of for your foe;
You tend to wander only in death's shade,
As you age and as you grow.
   So long as people can breathe or eyes can see,
   This will be a testament to thee.

messages.content: Numero is a methodical chatbot that responds with a list to Hannah's questions about a leisure centre.
When does the leisure centre open?

1. Monday to Friday: it opens from 8 am. 
               2. Weekend opening times are from 6 am.
Do I need an entrance ticket?

1. You need a ticket if you turn up on the day.
               2. You do not need a ticket if you have a QR code through advanced booking. Simply scan this at the machine outside the entrance.
               3. You do not need a ticket if you have a membership card. Swipe your card at the entrance.
Great. Will I have access to the fitness area, if I buy a ticket on the day?

1. You will have access to the cardio and weights area.

prompt: Write me a series of 3 haikus. Make them from your point of view as a cat moving around the room. You move to sleep in the patch of sunlight on the shag rug throughout the day.  Give one haiku each for morning, afternoon, and evening.

messages.content: Write me a series of 3 haikus. Make them from your point of view as a cat moving around the room. You move to sleep in the patch of sunlight on the shag rug throughout the day.  Give one haiku each for morning, afternoon, and evening.

**Morning**

Rays peeking at me.
Morning beams touch the cold floor.
Shag rug becomes bed.

**Afternoon**

Sun-warmed carpet bliss.
Soft heat caressing my fur.
Snuggling at the light.

**Evening**

Chasing the last sun.
Precious warmth leaving nap spot.
It is time to wake.

prompt: Hi! I need you to create a visual description of a fictional large oak tree and its surroundings for an artist's rendering. You should only include visible elements like color and texture, and not include sounds, smells, history, or feelings about it. Use many descriptive, objective words, and write at least 3 paragraphs, please.

messages.content: Hi! I need you to create a visual description of a fictional large oak tree and its surroundings for an artist's rendering. You should only include visible elements like color and texture, and not include sounds, smells, history, or feelings about it. Use many descriptive, objective words, and write at least 3 paragraphs, please.

The enormous oak tree stands alone in a field of evenly-trimmed green grass near a black metal bench. Its gigantic trunk is moss-covered at the base, the wide buttress of many roots coated in an emerald carpet. Higher up on the tree, the bark is rough, ashy-brown, and faded. 

The tree is split into two main trunks, thick, but divided and slightly leaning away from each other. In the notch between the two trunks, tufts of green-gray lichen coat one side. The larger branches droop toward the ground under their weight. 

Some of the thinner branches are smothered in vibrant green ivy, which twists up one side of the tree. The leaves of both the ivy and the oak are a deep, rich, healthy green, every branch packed in a dense, unbroken canopy. 

Rays of sunlight filter through the tree, but the foliage is so thick, the bright noon sun is blocked from view, and only the outer edge is visible. The unified leaves provide a solid cover of shade to the bench below and to the white daisies beside it.

prompt:
Rewrite the article with comedic twist.

Mosquitoes bite, suck your blood, and leave you with itchy bumps and possibly a horrible infection. Mosquito-borne pathogens include malaria, West Nile virus, Zika virus, Chikungunya virus, and dengue.

While you might fantasize about living in a mosquito-free world, eradicating them would actually be disastrous for the environment. Adult mosquitoes are food for other insects, birds, and bats, while larval mosquitoes support aquatic ecosystems. The best we can hope for is to limit their ability to transmit disease, repel them, and kill them within the confines of our yards and homes.

Mosquito-killing products bring in the big bucks, so it should come as no surprise that there is a wealth of misinformation out there. Before you get sucked into buying a product that simply won't work, get educated about what does and does not kill these blood-sucking pests.

First, you need to understand the difference between repelling mosquitoes and killing them. Repellents make a location (like your yard or skin) less attractive to mosquitoes, but don't kill them. So, citronella, DEET, smoke, lemon eucalyptus, lavender, and tea tree oil might keep the insects at bay, but won't control them or get rid of them in the long run. Repellents vary in effectiveness, too. For example, while citronella may deter mosquitoes from entering a small, enclosed area, it doesn't really work in a wide open space (like your back yard).

There are a host of methods that actually do kill mosquitoes, but aren't great solutions. A classic example is a bug zapper, which kills only a few mosquitoes, yet attracts and kills beneficial insects that keep the mozzy population down. Similarly, spraying pesticides is not an ideal solution because mosquitoes can become resistant to them, other animals get poisoned, and the toxins can cause lasting environmental damage.

Many species of mosquitoes required standing water to breed, so one of the most effective methods of controlling them is to remove open containers and repair leaks. Dumping containers of standing water kills the larvae living in them before they get a chance to mature.

However, removing water may be undesirable or impractical in some cases. Further, some species don't even need standing water to reproduce! The Aedes species, responsible for transmitting Zika and dengue, lays eggs out of water. These eggs remain viable for months, ready to hatch when sufficient water becomes available.
A better solution is to introduce predators that eat immature or adult mosquitoes or infectious agents that harm mosquitoes without affecting other wildlife.

Most ornamental fish consume mosquito larvae, including koi and minnows. Lizards, geckos, dragonfly adults and naiads, frogs, bats, spiders, and crustaceans all eat mosquitoes.

Adult mosquitoes are susceptible to infection by the fungi Metarhizium anisoplilae and Beauveria bassiana. A more practical infectious agent is the spores of the soil bacterium Bacillus thurigiensis israelensis (BTI),. Infection with BTI makes the larvae unable to eat, causing them to die. BTI pellets are readily available at home and gardening stores, easy to use (simply add them to standing water), and only affect mosquitoes, black flies, and fungus gnats. The treated water remains safe for pets and wild animals to drink. The disadvantages of BTI are that it requires reapplication every week or two and it doesn't kill adult mosquitos.
There are several chemical methods that target mosquitoes without the risks to other animals that come with spraying pesticides.

Some methods rely on chemical attractants to lure mosquitoes to their doom. Mosquitoes are attracted to carbon dioxide, sugary scents, heat, lactic acid, and octenal. Gravid females (those carrying eggs) may be attracted to traps laced with a hormone released during the egg-laying process.

The lethal ovitrap is dark, water-filled container, typically with a small opening to prevent larger animals from drinking the water. Some traps use chemicals to bait the traps, while others simply provide a convenient breeding ground. The traps may be filled with predators (e.g., fish) or with dilute pesticide to kill larvae (larvicide) and sometimes adults. These traps are highly effective and affordable. The disadvantage is that multiple traps must be used to cover an area (about one every 25 feet).

Another chemical method is the use of an insect growth regulator (IGR), added to water to inhibit larval development. The most common IGR is methoprene, which is supplied as a time-release brick. While effective, methoprene has been shown to be mildly toxic to other animals. 

Adding a layer of oil or kerosene to water kills mosquito larvae and also prevents females from depositing eggs. The layer alters the surface tension of the water. Larvae can't get their breathing tube to the surface for air, so they suffocate. However, this method kills other animals in the water and makes the water unfit for consumption.
One example of a physical method of killing mosquitoes is swatting them with your hand, a fly-swatter, or an electric swatter. Swatting works if you've only got a few mosquitoes, but it's not particularly helpful if you're being swarmed. While bug zappers aren't ideal outdoors because they can unnecessarily kill beneficial insects, electrocuting indoor insects isn't generally considered objectionable. Just remember, you need to bait a bug zapper to attract mosquitoes, because they don't care about the pretty blue light.

Because mosquitoes are not strong fliers, it's also easy to suck them onto a screen or into a separate trap using a fan. Mosquitoes caught using a fan die from dehydration. Screen-traps may be made at home by fastening window screening fabric over the back of a fan.

Ah, mosquitoes, those little bloodsuckers with a knack for leaving itchy bumps and the potential for a full-blown infection. What a delight! We all dream of a world free from these buzzing nuisances, but believe it or not, getting rid of them would be a total disaster for the environment.

You see, adult mosquitoes are like fast food for other insects, birds, and bats. They're the all-you-can-eat buffet for the insect world! And let's not forget about the larval mosquitoes. They play a crucial role in supporting aquatic ecosystems. So, as much as we despise them, the best we can do is limit their disease-spreading abilities, repel them, and kill them within the comfort of our yards and home.

Now, brace yourself, because mosquito-killing products are a gold mine. And where there's money to be made, there's bound to be a plethora of misinformation. Don't fall victim to the charade of useless products! It's time to get educated on what works against these bloodthirsty critters.

First things first, we need to understand the difference between repelling mosquitoes and straight-up obliterating them. Repellants, like citronella, DEET, and all those fancy-sounding oils, make your location [like your yard or your skin] less enticing to mosquitoes. But let's get real here, they won't kill the little buggers or solve the problem in the long run. It's like trying to keep your annoying neighbour at bay with a strongly scented candle. It might work for a while, but eventually, they'll come back, uninvited and ready to ruin your evening.

Now, for methods that claim to kill mosquitoes. Brace yourselves for disappointment because they aren't all that great.  Take big zappers, for example. Sure, they'll fry a few mosquitoes, but they'll also take down some beneficial insects that help keep the mosquito population in check. Oops, collateral damage.

And let's not forget about spraying pesticides. Sure, it sounds like a solid plan, but mosquitoes can quickly become resistant to these chemicals, Plus, another innocent creature ends up getting poisoned, and the long-term environmental damage is no joke. So, unless you're aiming to create a mutant army of super mosquitoes, let's skip the pesticide party. 

Now, here's a tip that actually works. Many mosquitoes breed in standing water, so removing open containers and fixing leaks is an effective way to control them. It's like hitting the nursery where it hurts! Dumping the water-filled mosquito cribs kills the larvae before they have the chance to mature and ruin your summer nights.

But it isn't always that simple. Some mosquitoes are so crafty that they don't even need standing water to reproduce. Take the Aedes species, responsible for Zika and dengue, for example. These little troublemakers lay eggs outside of water, just waiting for the perfect opportunity to hatch. They're like spy agents of the mosquito world.

So, what can we do? Well, how about unleashing the power of nature? Introduce predators that feast on immature or adult mosquitoes. We're talking about lizards, geckos, dragonflies, frogs, bats, spiders, and crustaceans. It's like assembling a superhero team to battle the forces of evil [or in this case, itchy bumps and diseases.

We can infect those bloodsuckers with fungi, bacteria, and other agents that make them regret ever messing with us. For example, adult mosquitoes can fall victim to fungi like Metarhizium anisoplilae and Beauverua bassiana. Talk about a fungal infection they'll never forget! and if you prefer something more practical, try infecting them with Bacillus thurigiensis israelensis [BTI], a bacterium that ruins their appetite and leads them to demise. It's like serving them a deadly dinner they won't be able to resist.

Now, let's talk about chemical warfare against mosquitoes, minus the risks to other innocent critters. Some clever methods use chemical attractants to lure mosquitos to their demise. It's like setting up a mosquito trap disguised as a five-star restaurant, complete with irresistible delicacies. 

And have you heard of lethal ovitrap? It's like a mosquito nightclub that no female mosquito can resist. It's a dark, water-filled container with a small opening to keep out party crashers. Some traps use chemicals as bait, while others provide the perfect breeding ground. You can invite predators or add a dash of pesticide to the mix. Talk about throwing wild party mosquitoes will regret attending!

But wait, there's more! We have the insect growth regulator [IGR], a chemical that ruins the larvae' development. It's like giving them a taste of the "you shall not grow' potion. However, we must admit, it has a slight downside- it's mildly toxic to other creatures. 
Oops!

Now, here's a method that's straight out of a slapstick comedy. Get ready to swat those bloodsuckers with your bare hands, a fly swatter, or an electric swatter. Swatting works like magic when you're dealing with just a few mosquitoes. But if you're facing a full-on mosquito invasion, well good luck with that! It's like trying to fight an army of tiny vampires armed with a rolled-up newspaper. Let's just say the odds aren't in your favour.

Oh, and did I mention that mosquitoes aren't the brightest when it comes to flying? That's right! You can easily suck them onto a screen or a trap using a fan. It's like the ultimate mosquito vortex! Those suckers caught in the wind will meet their demise due to dehydration. As for the screen traps, you can create your very own DIY version by attracting window screen fabric to the back of a fan. It's like setting up a mosquito-themed escape room, with no escape in sight.

So there you have it, folks! The hilarious battle against mosquitoes. Remember, these bloodsuckers may be annoying, but they provide a buffet for other insects and support aquatic ecosystems. Our best bet is to repel them, limit their disease transmission, and maybe unleash a few predators or infect them with a touch of nature's wrath. And if all else fails, well, at least you can enjoy a good laugh while swatting them away with a fly swatter or watching them get trapped in your DIY fan-powered vortex. Good luck, mosquito warriors!

messages.content: Write a darkly funny limerick about a goldfish named Jim

I know of a goldfish named Jim,
Whose chances of eating are dim.
His owner forgot,
To put food in his pot.
Now his odds of survival are slim.

prompt:
Write a brief summary of the current status of Intuitive Machines' lunar missions and their financial situation, as well as the progress of Astrobotic's lunar lander mission.

Here's the source text:
IM-2 may be delayed because of the wait for IM-1, Altemus said during the phone call, the first since Intuitive Machines was listed publicly in February. For now, IM-3 is expected to launch in 2024.

Intuitive Machines reported an operating loss of $14 million in the most recent quarter, compared with $4.5 million in the same quarter of 2022; a portion of the loss, $2.8 million, was due to the costs associated with the merger that took it public. Quarterly revenue was similar to last year, with $18.2 million reported in 2023 and $18.5 million in 2022, SpaceNews reported.

Another U.S. company supported by NASA, Pittsburgh-based Astrobotic, is also attempting to be the first to ace a private touchdown on the moon. Astrobotic's Peregrine lander is awaiting a now-delayed liftoff aboard United Launch Alliance's (ULA) new Vulcan Centaur rocket.

A fireball during testing last month has delayed Vulcan Centaur's first launch, which will send Peregrine toward the moon. That liftoff had been set for June or July. A new launch date has not been announced, but ULA CEO Tory Bruno said in a recent Twitter thread(opens in new tab) that the company is "protecting" a launch date opportunity for sometime in the summer.

messages.content:
Write a brief summary of the current status of Intuitive Machines' lunar missions and their financial situation, as well as the progress of Astrobotic's lunar lander mission.

Here's the source text:
IM-2 may be delayed because of the wait for IM-1, Altemus said during the phone call, the first since Intuitive Machines was listed publicly in February. For now, IM-3 is expected to launch in 2024.

Intuitive Machines reported an operating loss of $14 million in the most recent quarter, compared with $4.5 million in the same quarter of 2022; a portion of the loss, $2.8 million, was due to the costs associated with the merger that took it public. Quarterly revenue was similar to last year, with $18.2 million reported in 2023 and $18.5 million in 2022, SpaceNews reported.

Another U.S. company supported by NASA, Pittsburgh-based Astrobotic, is also attempting to be the first to ace a private touchdown on the moon. Astrobotic's Peregrine lander is awaiting a now-delayed liftoff aboard United Launch Alliance's (ULA) new Vulcan Centaur rocket.

A fireball during testing last month has delayed Vulcan Centaur's first launch, which will send Peregrine toward the moon. That liftoff had been set for June or July. A new launch date has not been announced, but ULA CEO Tory Bruno said in a recent Twitter thread(opens in new tab) that the company is "protecting" a launch date opportunity for sometime in the summer.

The lunar missions of Intuitive Machines have been postponed; IM-1 will now launch in 2024, while IM-3 will still take place in 2023. IM-1's postponement until 2023 could affect IM-2's schedule. The expenditures of the merger that made the company public contributed to the company's operating loss of $14 million in the most recent quarter. Astrobotic, a US company that has the support of NASA, is currently making an attempt to land on the moon for the very first time. A fireball that occurred while the new Vulcan Centaur rocket from United Launch Alliance (ULA) was being tested has also delayed the launch of Astrobotic's Peregrine lander. ULA CEO Tory Bruno stated that a launch date opportunity is being "protected" for the summer, despite the fact that a new launch date has not been disclosed.

prompt:
Give me a bulleted list of the causes of the Hundred Years’ War from this article:
The root causes of the conflict can be traced to the crisis of 14th-century Europe. The outbreak of war was motivated by a gradual rise in tension between the kings of France and England over territory; the official pretext was the question that arose because of the interruption of the direct male line of the Capetian dynasty.
Tensions between the French and English crowns had gone back centuries to the origins of the English royal family, which was French (Norman, and later, Angevin) in origin because of William the Conqueror, the Norman duke who became King of England in 1066. English monarchs had therefore historically held titles and lands within France, which made them vassals to the kings of France. The status of the English king's French fiefs was a major source of conflict between the two monarchies throughout the Middle Ages. French monarchs systematically sought to check the growth of English power, stripping away lands as the opportunity arose, particularly whenever England was at war with Scotland, an ally of France. English holdings in France had varied in size, at some points dwarfing even the French royal domain; by 1337, however, only Gascony was English.
In 1328, Charles IV of France died without any sons or brothers, and a new principle, Salic law, disallowed female succession. Charles's closest male relative was his nephew Edward III of England, whose mother, Isabella, was Charles's sister. Isabella claimed the throne of France for her son by the rule of proximity of blood, but the French nobility rejected this, maintaining that Isabella could not transmit a right she did not possess. An assembly of French barons decided that a native Frenchman should receive the crown, rather than Edward.[2]
So the throne passed instead to Charles's patrilineal cousin, Philip, Count of Valois. Edward protested but ultimately submitted and did homage for Gascony. Further French disagreements with Edward induced Philip, during May 1337, to meet with his Great Council in Paris. It was agreed that Gascony should be taken back into Philip's hands, which prompted Edward to renew his claim for the French throne, this time by force of arms.[3]

prompt: What reasons were Daylight Savings Time introduced? When was this first implemented?

messages.content: What reasons were Daylight Savings Time introduced? When was this first implemented?
Daylight Savings Time, or DST, was introduced with the Standard Time Act of 1918 to add more daylight hours to the day to conserve energy resources.

prompt: Hello, can you give me some suggestions for the best shopping apps?  I am interested in apps that offer cash back.

messages.content: Hello, can you give me some suggestions for the best shopping apps?  I am interested in apps that offer cash back.

Here are some suggestions for shopping apps that offer cash back. 

1. DollarSprout Rewards - DollarSprout Rewards can be installed on your desktop browser as an extension. It works by automatically recognizing when you are about to purchase from a participating merchant such as Walgreens, Walmart, or Old Navy, and it prompts you to claim your cashback reward. Once you accumulate $5 in earnings after any amount of time, they pay out through the user's PayPal account the following month. 

2. Capital One Shopping - Capital One Shopping is an online browser extension as well as an app that applies coupons every time you check out. It lets you earn credits for shopping locally and informs you when there's a better price from another retailer. Users also have the option to add items to their Capital One Shopping watchlist so they can track prices and be notified when there's a better deal out there for them. 

3. Dosh - This cashback shopping app rewards you with everyday shopping both online and in-store. All you have to do is link your card to the app once and then enjoy the cash-back benefits over time as you shop. The great thing about the app is that it doesn't control or pressure you into making purchases you don't need simply because something is on sale. 

4. Rakuten - This popular shopping app issues cash back for shopping at popular online stores and a few local stores as well. Shopping on Rakuten is easy and you can do it both on the dedicated app or on your home computer. All you have to do to get started is open the Rakuten app on your phone and search the store of your choice using the search bar. Then click on any referral link to visit the store of your choosing and go about your normal shopping activities. 

5. Drop - Drop is an app that is similar to Rakuten which issues cash back for purchases made through qualifying links. The main difference is that Drop will pay you back in gift cards instead of in cash. But if you like the idea of gaining credits toward gift cards to your favorite stores then this would be a great option for you. After you accumulate 5,000 points on Drop, you can redeem them for a $5 gift card of your choice.

prompt: Write a short story or part of a short story about astronauts landing on a distant moon.  It will be 400 words or less.  A crew of four astronauts arrives at the surface.  There is a minimal atmosphere, or so they believe, and as such need to wear space suits to survive.

messages.content: Write a short story or part of a short story about astronauts landing on a distant moon.  It will be 400 words or less.  A crew of four astronauts arrives at the surface.  There is a minimal atmosphere, or so they believe, and as such need to wear space suits to survive.

Edmunds stared at the screen in front of him.  The lunar surface was getting steadily closer, and the texture slowly came into focus.  Dust and rocks, just like the other moons. 
He looked to his right and saw Jacobs and Moretti watching their own screens, the light reflecting off the glass front panel of their helmets.  Jacobs and Moretti had two screens each to mind.  Fore and after, port and starboard. 
On his right, Pham attended to her screen, the one that pointed straight up.  He could see the ship they had just departed from floating directly above them.  Just as the ground had slowly filled his own screen, Arthur had started to recede in Pham's.  He could have reached out and covered it with his hand.  Arthur was over two hundred long, but from here it looked as though he could put it in his pocket.
This was always his least favorite part of any expedition.  The time between leaving Arthur and touching down.  Things could happen.   
Six years ago, when he was on the Clarke, they'd nearly lost the whole expeditionary team.  Some piece of rock that wasn't on any chart slammed the side of the lander and caused a fuel leak that sent it tumbling off course.  They had to wait more than two days for the craft to stabilize before they could even approach it without risk to the main ship.  Not a single member was lost, but none of them ever voluntarily got in a lander again.
Changes had been made, and everyone was assured that this type of accident was preventable.  Extra orbits of the planet or moon were now made to assess the risks associated with a landing, and the land craft was meant to be safer than ever.  They were told.
Edmunds got called up eighteen months after that and he didn't hesitate.  He wasn't out here to sit by while others walked on worlds so far from his own that the distance was beyond comprehension.
A green light next to his screen flashed, first slowly, then rapidly.  He flicked the switch beneath it and as the light went out a low rumble came from beneath them.  The landing rockets slowed their descent to a crawl. and after a moment. they all felt the lander's four rubberized feet make contact with the surface.

prompt: Write a short (< 250 words) dialogue-heavy scene in which two characters confront each other about a deep-seated conflict, using language to reveal their innermost fears and desires. Use a dramatic and tense tone.

messages.content: Write a short (< 250 words) dialogue-heavy scene in which two characters confront each other about a deep-seated conflict, using language to reveal their innermost fears and desires. Use a dramatic and tense tone.

Scene: A dark and stormy night. Two men are sitting in a room, drinking whiskey and smoking cigars. The air is thick with tension.

Man 1: I can't believe you did it.
Man 2: What?
Man 1: You know what. You betrayed me. You betrayed our friendship.
Man 2: I didn't betray you. I did what I had to do.
Man 1: What you did was wrong. You know it was wrong.
Man 2: I don't care what you think. I did what I had to do to survive.
Man 1: You're a coward.
Man 2: And you're a fool.

The two men stare at each other, their faces inches apart. The tension is so thick that it could be cut with a knife.

Man 1: I'm going to kill you.
Man 2: Go ahead. Try it.

The two men continue to stare at each other, their anger and hatred palpable.

Suddenly, there is a loud crash of thunder. The two men jump and look at each other in fear.

Man 1: This isn't over.
Man 2: It never is.

The two men turn and walk away from each other, their backs to each other. The storm rages outside, but the tension in the room is even more powerful.

prompt: Please write a little inner-thoughts piece from the perspective of a very young toddler. Try to see some child-like wonder in the mundane details of life as well as confusion about things adults barely notice. Also focus on the child’s short attention span.

messages.content: Please write a little inner-thoughts piece from the perspective of a very young toddler. Try to see some child-like wonder in the mundane details of life as well as confusion about things adults barely notice. Also focus on the child’s short attention span.

Wow, look at that! The ball rolled off my pillow again, just like last time! But the teddy bear doesn’t roll off. Maybe he likes it there. The pillow is soft, after all. 

Oh, what’s that sound? It’s loud. I remember! It’s a fire truck! But it's not on the TV. Is the fire truck hiding? It sounds closer to the window than the TV. If it’s hiding, maybe I should look for it. That’s what hiding is for.

Oh, hey, the walking soft is over here. I like the walking soft. What did Momma call it? Oh right, the cat! The walking soft makes fun quiet sounds. Not like the fire truck. Oh, right! The fire truck! Now I don’t hear it. Is it still hiding?

Momma said something! I like Momma. Oh, she said fishy crackers! I like fishy crackers too! They look like fishies. But Momma says they’re not real fishies. We saw some real fishies at Nana’s house. They moved in the water. And they were shiny! I like shinies.

Oh, I dropped a fishy. It went down to the floor. Things usually go down to the floor when I drop them. Do they like the floor? Hey, there’s a shiny on the floor too! I think I’ve seen that before. Where was it before? Not on the floor. 

Uh oh, the walking soft took my floor fishy. That’s mine! I was gonna eat it! Oh, but I do have more fishies in my hand. I can eat those ones. 

Hey, there’s the shiny again. Oh, I know where it was before. It was on Momma’s face! No, wait…it was on Momma’s ear. Now it is on the floor. I’ll take it to Momma.

Momma said, “Thank you,” so I’m supposed to say something. “Welcome.”

Momma’s chair is hard. It’s not like the walking soft or the pillow soft. It’s also brown. I remembered that color all by myself! But there are not-brown lines here and there on the chair. They’re not brown but not white either, I don’t think. I wonder what that color is. Is it in the rainbow? I could check my rainbow book.

Oh, Momma said something else? Oh boy! Orange juice! My favorite!

prompt: Help me come up with some fun car games to play with my 10 year old during a long car ride?

messages.content: Help me come up with some fun car games to play with my 10 year old during a long car ride?

Of course! Here are some fun games for a 10-year-old to play in the car during a long trip:

1. I, Spy. One person says "I spy with my little eye" and gives a clue for something they see. The other person(s) have to guess what it might be.
2. License Plates. Keep a running tally of all the different license plates from other states or other countries that you see while driving. 
3. Name That Song. Play a short clip from a song and ask your child to guess the name, or other trivia, about it.
4. The Story Game. Each person in the car says one sentence to continue the tale and create an entertaining story.
5. 20 Questions. Think of something, an object, an animal, or a person, and have your child ask yes-or-no questions to try to narrow down the answer.
6. Would You Rather? Take turns asking "would you rather" questions and then debate the answers.
7. Car Color Game. Set a color of a car to be on the lookout for, and keep a tally of how many cars of that color have been seen. Try switching up the color when things seem dull. 
8. Mad Libs. This may require a pen and paper, or even a mobile phone. Write a sentence or paragraph, leaving out certain words such as verbs, nouns, or adjectives and ask your child to fill in the blanks. Read the entire sentence at the end.
9. The Alphabet Game. Try to find road signs with words that start with the letters of the alphabet. Start with A, move to B, and so on, until Z. Restart several times if necessary. 
10. I'm Going On a Picnic. Begin by saying "I'm going on a picnic and I'm bringing" and say an object. The next person must repeat the previous answers and add their own to the end. The longer the game goes, the more things must be remembered and repeated.

prompt: Make a bullet-point list of facts about Siberia. Include 15 facts.

messages.content: Make a bullet-point list of facts about Siberia. Include 15 facts.

- Siberia's population is just under 40 million people. 
- Siberia's diverse wildlife includes bears, sheep, tigers, leopards, and eagles. 
- Siberia is home to the deepest and oldest lake in the world known as Lake Baikal.
- Siberia is a geographical region within Russia that extends from the western Ural Mountains to the Pacific Ocean in the east, and from the Arctic Ocean in the south to the hills of north-central Kazakhstan and the Mongolian and Chinese borders in the north.
- Some of the largest Siberian cities include Novosibirsk, Tyumen, Omsk, Krasnoyarsk, and Barnaul. 
- Siberia's highest point is the active volcano Klyuchevskaya Sopka on the Kamchatka Peninsula, which is 4,649 meters high. 
- The Siberian region itself is the same size as all of Canada. 
- The Siberian region makes up roughly 77% of Russia. 
- The Yenisei-angara-Selenge River system in Siberia is the region's (and Russia's) longest river, measuring 5,539 km long. 
- Siberia contains multiple mountain ranges, including the Baikal Mountains, the Ural Mountains, and the Altai Mountains. 
- The majority of people in Siberia are Russified Ukrainians and Russians. 
- The Buryats are the largest indigenous group residing in Siberia, and they mainly live in the Buryat Republic. 
- The Siberian city of Novosibirsk is the fastest-growing city worldwide.
- Siberia's Lake Baikal remains totally frozen for a few months out of the year, making it possible to walk and drive on. 
- From November-February, Siberia is covered with snow that can be up to 80 cm deep.

prompt:
Is this story funny or creepy? Explain:

Who’s in my bed?
A father went to say good night to his seven year old son, very well knowing that if he didn’t his son would have trouble sleeping. It was a nightly routine between them. He entered the dimly lit room where his son waited under his blanket. With the first glance the father could tell there was something unusual about his son tonight, but couldn’t put his finger on it. He looked the same but had a grin that drew from ear to ear.

“You okay, buddy?” the father asked.

The son nodded, still with the grin, before saying, “Daddy, check for monsters under my bed.”

The father chuckled a bit before getting on his knees to check only to satisfy his son.

There, under the bed, pale and afraid, was his son. His real son. He whispered, “Daddy, there someone on my bed”.

prompt: Write a young children’s story from the point of view of Toby, a wood pigeon, and what he does during the day. Keep it under 300 words.

messages.content: Write a young children’s story from the point of view of Toby, a wood pigeon, and what he does during the day. Keep it under 300 words.

Hi! My name is Toby and I’m a wood pigeon. My mother is a wood pigeon, my father is a wood pigeon, and so are all my brothers and sisters! I only just left the nest, so I spend a lot of my time exploring around my home. I explore a little bit every day so I can get better at flying. When I become a grown-up wood pigeon, I want to fly better than any other bird in the whole world!
Yesterday, I flew all the way to Grandma Marcy’s house. She’s a nice human lady who always leaves seeds and nuts outside for me and my family to eat. Today, I’m going to visit her again. Sometimes, when I go alone, Grandma Marcy gives me special treats!
Every day, after I’m done exploring, I have to teach my younger brothers and sisters how to do everything a wood pigeon can do! Even though they’re too young to fly out of the nest themselves, Mom and Dad tell me I should help them out and show them how it’s done. 
At night, after I finish teaching my siblings, Mom, Dad and all of us kids get together and we have a nice dinner of worms and seeds. Then we all sleep in the nest together and in the morning, I do it all again!
I love my life and I love being a wood pigeon!

prompt: How many chambers are there in the human stomach?

messages.content: How many chambers are there in the human stomach?

Humans have a single chamber in the stomach. It consists of different regions, namely the cardia, fundus, body, and pylorus. The cardia connects the esophagus to the stomach, allowing food to pass into the stomach. The fundus is a dome-shaped area located above and to the left of the cardia. The body is the main part of the stomach, and the pylorus connects the stomach to the duodenum.

prompt: Can you tell me about the An-71? Why does it look backwards? What was it for?

messages.content: Can you tell me about the An-71? Why does it look backwards? What was it for?

It was a prototype aircraft intended to fill the airborne warning and control system (AWACS) role for the Soviet Union to serve the needs of their fighter-bombers and attack aircraft. Three prototypes were built, but the planes never entered active service. 

The An-71 was based on the Antonov An-72 cargo plane. That type had high-mounted jet engines because it was built for short takeoffs and landings on imperfect runways in austere locations. Placing the engines up high made them less likely to suck debris off the ground and damage the turbine blades.

When it came time to modify that design to carry a large 360-degree radar system, designers decided to try integrating it into the tail fin rather than placing the round radome on an extra set of mounting brackets. Any feature that you place in the way of airflow creates drag, so eliminating the need for extra uprights would improve the plane’s handling and range. 

Engineers couldn’t just put the radome on the standard tail, though. The radar equipment is heavy and alters the plane’s aerodynamics. Sweeping the tail forward placed the radome closer to the plane’s center of gravity and thus improved its stability. It was considered a major redesign of the tail section (the horizontal stabilizers also had to be repositioned).

Antonov briefly considered creating a naval version of the An-71 as well, but it quickly became apparent that adapting it for carrier operations would demand too many redesigned features. That project was scrapped.

The An-71 never entered service in part because of problems developing the radar itself. Its death knell, though, was the collapse of the Soviet Union. Funding for the project evaporated, so it was abruptly halted. At the turn of the 21st century, Antonov in now-independent Ukraine tried to resurrect the project in order to sell An-71s to India, but that also fell through.
