messages.content: Write a short conversation between two friends, Barb and Steve, about a new animated comedy "Hat on a Hat." They should discuss the participation of famous actors, as well as the show's family-friendly comedy. Create generic-sounding names for the actors and make up the details of their careers if necessary. Format the text as {NAME}: {Statement}

STEVE: Well Barb, you've been telling me about this show for weeks, and I finally checked it out last night. I have to say, what a delight.

BARB: Steve, you know I know my TV.

STEVE: You're right, but there's just so much on these days. It took some convincing for my wife to take on a new show.

BARB: Well, what did you like?

STEVE: Well right away, I was asking my wife who the voice of the main character was.

BARB: That's Garrett Brown!

STEVE: I know, that's what my wife said, and I hadn't seen or heard him in years. I thought he'd retired.

BARB: No, he's been working on this show the whole time, working with writers, getting the right actors involved. It's something of a passion project.

STEVE: Really? You don't usually see that with family-friendly comedy.

BARB: I know! But he said the voice of his hat had to be Alex Smith, and Alex has so much other work these days.

STEVE: It's just great to have something I can watch with the kids, and I guess the second hat is some sort of video game player?

BARB: That's right, Cool's Rules, I think? That's what the credits say at least.

STEVE: I looked that up, and I guess a lot of these streamers don't give out their actual names. It's so they don't get people bothering them in their personal lives.

BARB: Well, I guess they knew he was a good entertainer, that's for sure. I can't wait for next week's episode.

STEVE: Me neither.

prompt: I'm going to be getting chickens soon, and need to replan my herb garden to accommodate them. What herbs are good for chickens? Do I need to be careful where I plant them, so they don't get overharvested? Are there any I should avoid?

messages.content: I'm going to be getting chickens soon, and need to replan my herb garden to accommodate them. What herbs are good for chickens? Do I need to be careful where I plant them, so they don't get overharvested? Are there any I should avoid?

Chickens can eat almost any cooking herb that you'd commonly plant in your garden, but some are more beneficial to the chickens than others. Here are some with noted health benefits:

• Mint: Mint's powerful smell can help combat any undesirable coup fumes and also keep insects at bay. In addition, it can encourage new feather growth in chickens and has been said to have a calming effect. (Calmer hens equals more eggs!) It can even be served fresh, frozen, or dried, and obviously has many household uses, as well. Because mint is a prolific grower, it's safe to plant near the coup. If it spreads inside, the chickens can trim the excess without harming the overall supply.

• Lavender: Lavender is calming for chickens and humans alike! In addition, it has a lovely smell that mixes well with mint and other herbs. This smell helps dispel pests. Lavender is also good for the circulatory system, increasing blood flow when hens might not be moving around as much (during winter, cold snaps, or when sitting on eggs.) The seed-shaped flowers of lavender are also enjoyable for chickens to forage, providing some mental exercise.

• Oregano: Oregano's smell deters pests and mixes wonderfully with the basil and tomatoes in your garden (which chickens also love!) Oregano grows best when harvested often, so whole springs can be hung in your coup for the chickens to pick at and scavenge. It's a natural antibiotic that's full of vitamins and antioxidants. You can even add dried oregano into your feed for these benefits, although it won't be as potent as fresh sprigs. 

• Thyme: Thyme, like the others, is aromatic and mixes wonderfully with the smell of lavender. (Just check your soap scents!) Like oregano, thyme is a natural antibiotic that also aids in respiratory stability. Thyme spreads, like mint, so it's safe to plant near the coup and let the chickens control the excess. It can be hung in full sprigs like oregano or dried. 

Additionally, any of these herbs can be soaked in vinegar and used as an all-natural pest control due to their aromatics. Plant extra!

prompt:
Please answer these questions based on the given text:

1. What is the Inuktitut name of Baffin Island?
2. How did Norse explorers refer to the Island?
3. What did Martin Frobisher call the island?
4. Who is Baffin Island named for?
5. What was the name of the island before it was called Baffin Island?
6. What does Qikiqtaaluk mean in the Inuktitut language?
7. What does the Norse term Helluland mean?

The Inuktitut name for the island is Qikiqtaaluk,[6] which means "very big island" (qikiqtaq "island" + -aluk "very big") and in Inuktitut syllabics is written as ᕿᑭᖅᑖᓗᒃ. This name is used for the administrative region the island is part of (Qikiqtaaluk Region), as well as in multiple places in Nunavut and the Northwest Territories,[7] such as some smaller islands: Qikiqtaaluk in Baffin Bay and Qikiqtaaluk in Foxe Basin. Norse explorers referred to it as Helluland ("stone land").[8] In 1576, English seaman Martin Frobisher made landfall on the island, naming it "Queen Elizabeth's Foreland" and Frobisher Bay is named after him.[9] The island is named after English explorer William Baffin, who, in 1616,[10] came across the island while trying to discover the Northwest Passage.[11] It was also formerly known as James Island.[12]

Prioritize variety, I don't want 5 songs about California.

That sounds like fun! Here's a list of songs you might want to add to your road trip playlist:

1. 'New York, New York' by Frank Sinatra - This ode to Manhattan is a timeless classic full of optimism and bravado. It's sure to put your passengers in a great mood.
2. 'Viva Las Vegas' by Elvis Presley - You may find it difficult to resist making a pit stop in Sin City after listening to this tune.
3. 'Route 66' by the Rolling Stones - This legendary anthem to one of the most widely recognizable roads in America is sure to be a hit with your friends.
4. 'Sweet Home Alabama' by Lynryrd Skynyrd - This song is chock-full of love for the state of Alabama. It has an opening riff that people will recognize right away and a chorus that's perfect for belting out at the top of your lungs with the windows rolled down.
5. 'No Particular Place to Go' by Chuck Berry - While your road trip may indeed have a particular destination, the lyrics of this song are an ode to the joy of driving for fun. With its catchy riffs and infectious rhythm, you might find yourself rocking out behind the wheel while playing this tune. 
6. 'Georgia on My Mind' by Ray Charles - Ray Charles put a spin on this classic 1930 tune, making it at once a loving ode and a mournful ballad about his home state.
7. 'Do You Know the Way to San Jose' by Dionne Warwick - This song is catchy but also calming, a great choice for early morning or late night driving.
8. 'Fast Car' by Tracy Chapman - The lyrics of this song use traveling as a metaphor for escaping the past and heading towards a brighter future. With its calm, bluesy rhythm, it's also a great choice for a relaxing stretch of empty road. 
9. 'Dirty Water' by the Standells - This song is often played at Red Sox games as a classic ode to Boston. While the lyrics describe some of the city's less savory qualities, with the 'dirty water' standing as a reference to the polluted River Charles and Boston Harbor, the song is widely recognized as a prideful anthem with the chorus repeating, "Oh Boston, you're my home."
10. 'Drive My Car' by the Beatles - This is a great tune to sing along to, especially in the parts where the lyrics mimic car horns and other traffic sounds.
11. 'California Girls' by the Beach Boys - This is a great song to blast at high volume while approaching the western coastline. The lyrics extoll the virtues of women from all over the country, not just California.
12. 'Chicago' by Sufjan Stevens - You might think this song is about the city of Chicago based on its title, but the lyrics tell a story about driving all over the country, letting go of the past, and growing up.

prompt: Write me a short story about a teenage boy buying a broken car from an unpleasant man. The man is gross, older, and not very intelligent in the way he speaks. His lawn is unsightly and the teenager tries to not be rude but is highly critical of the man and his lawn. Write the story in first-person perspective from the view of the teenage boy. Title the story "The Broken Lawn Ornament".

messages.content: Write me a short story about a teenage boy buying a broken car from an unpleasant man. The man is gross, older, and not very intelligent in the way he speaks. His lawn is unsightly and the teenager tries to not be rude but is highly critical of the man and his lawn. Write the story in first-person perspective from the view of the teenage boy. Title the story "The Broken Lawn Ornament".

The Broken Lawn Ornament

"There's only one thing wrong with the car," the musty old man in the dingy and stained undershirt told me. "It don't go."
"What?" I don't know if I had misheard the crotchety old geezer who smelled of an acrid mixture of sweat, cigars, and sauerkraut or had completely missed the context of his wheezy statement.
"The car, it don't start. Engine's broke," he repeated slowly, as though he considered me to be yet another stupid young person. I asked why it was for sale then.
"Because it can get fixed. If it's fixed, it works. 'Sides, it's been cluttering up my lawn. Makes it look bad."
I looked over at the immobilized hunk of metal on tires parked in the guy's front yard like an overgrown lawn ornament. Long, scraggly patches of grass grew around the tires. The lawn itself was sparse and patchy. Weeds grew unbidden and overwhelmed the grass in several parts of the yard.
A cynical smile played on my lips. I successfully fought it off along with a raised eyebrow. The yard was hardly a bragging right since it was plagued with scattered bald patches and where the grass did grow, it was in desperate need of a cut. Peeking out from the prairie-like dumpy lawn were pieces of what I expected to be dog crap.
I shrugged, making the old man raise a graying eyebrow that was as overgrown as his lawn.
"You want it or not?"
"Yes," I pulled my wallet out of my pocket and randomly wondered how many plastic pink flamingoes and garden gnomes I could get for the price of my "new" car.

prompt: Write a short story (>250 words) about a turtle who wished he could drive.

messages.content: Write a short story (>250 words) about a turtle who wished he could drive.

Dave the turtle was pretty upset. He spent most of his day sitting by the pier watching the metal beasts go by. The cars were big and loud, and Dave wanted to drive one. At first, he thought the loud metal beasts were terrifying. He was certain one would jump in the water and swallow him whole! But as he continued to watch, he saw the walkers open the beasts and climb in and out. They didn't seem to be swallowed, and the beasts didn't seem to have a life once the walkers were outside...

Dave made his way towards a group of the beasts. They were sitting in a line next to one another, but none were moving. 

"Hello!" Dave cried. Silence. "HELLO!" he tried again. Again, he was met with silence. 

As he made his way toward a particularly large beast, a group of walkers approached him. "Oh. My. Gosh!" one of the walkers cried. She quickly picked up Dave and led him toward a smaller beast. They got inside and the walker kept a firm hand on Dave's shell. "Let's go for a ride little dude."

Suddenly, the beast roared to life and sped off. Driving. All at once, Dave knew - he needed to drive the beast himself - and he would do anything to make that happen.

prompt: Can you write a story about a kid that wears a pumpkin mask all day? It is not Halloween but the kid really loves the pumpkin mask.

messages.content: Can you write a story about a kid that wears a pumpkin mask all day? It is not Halloween but the kid really loves the pumpkin mask.

"Hey, kid! What are you doing wearing a mask like that?" One of the adults ask the kid as he was walking home. You see, the kid was gifted a pumpkin mask a long time ago. He loves the mask so much that some days, he would wear it all day. It didn't matter what day. It could be a holiday, a special occasion, or a trip with friends. It didn't matter to him. That plastic mask was special to him.

"It's a special mask!" The kid responds to the adult, then continues to walk home. It did look a little weird. A kid with shorts on, a normal t-shirt, and a school backpack just has a pumpkin mask on. He would just be a normal school kid without that. He sounded happy though. That mask makes it seem like he was a different kid sometimes. It's a little creepy, but ultimately I was fine with it. I go back to my job, sweeping up outside the store, thinking about what ifs involving the mask. And the kid, he made it home safely.

Brief me on this info on how to prune my azaleas: 


Remove Crossing Branches

The next step in pruning your Royal Command azaleas is to remove any branches that are crossing over each other. These branches can cause rubbing and scraping, leading to wounds and infections. Gently remove the weakest branch to promote proper growth and ensure that each branch has enough space to grow.

Thin Out the Branches

The final step in pruning your Royal Command azaleas is to thin out some of the branches. This will improve air circulation and sunlight penetration, which is essential for healthy plant growth. Remove any small, weak, or overcrowded branches to promote the growth of larger, healthier branches.

In conclusion, pruning is a necessary task that gardeners must undertake to maintain the health and shape of their Royal Command azaleas. By following the tips outlined above, you can ensure that your plant thrives and produces the beautiful blooms that make it a garden standout. With time and practice, you'll develop your pruning skills and be able to maintain a beautiful and healthy garden for years to come.

prompt:
I am a teenager. Rewrite this article into an email request to my mom and dad telling them why we should visit Wyoming and that I really want to go visit on our vacation. Include 5 things in a list. At least one should be a restaurant and 2 should be indoor activities. Sign off, love your son.

1. The park is a geothermal wonderland. Hissing geysers, bubbling mud pots, and steaming hot springs betray the forces that formed this staggering landscape millions of years ago. Waterfalls gush down steep ravines, and glittering lakes and rivers stretch for miles. The highlights of Yellowstone National Park include the famous Old Faithful geyser, Yellowstone Lake, and the jaw-dropping cascades of Lower Falls.

You can drive through the park, but the huge network of hiking trails is the best way to appreciate the park's diverse ecosystems. It's easy to extend a wilderness experience by staying in one of the park's scenic campgrounds.
2. Jackson is also the gateway to beautiful Grand Teton National Park and a popular stop on the way to Yellowstone. Bordering town, the National Elk Refuge protects the largest herd of wintering elk in the world. In season, you can ride horse-drawn sleighs into the refuge to view these gentle creatures up close.

Camouflaged in a rocky hillside just south of town, the National Museum of Wildlife Art is another top attraction, with more than 4,000 paintings and many rotating exhibits.
3. The Cody Firearms Museum contains a large collection of firearms from around the world. Wyoming wildlife and geology are the main themes of the Draper Museum of Natural History, and you can learn about the culture of the prairies' first inhabitants at the Plains Indian Museum through exhibits and a multimedia show.
4. Cheyenne, the capital of Wyoming, offers a host of rewarding things to do in southern Wyoming. Named after the Cheyenne Indians, it was once the largest outpost of the United States Cavalry. Today, the town's museums and historic sites tell the story of Cheyenne's beginnings in 1867 as a station on the Union Pacific Railroad.
One of the town's top attractions is the Cheyenne Frontier Days Rodeo. Held annually since 1919, the late-July rodeo, featuring 10 days of fun-filled festivities, is one of the best in the country. For a taste of the Wild West at other times of the year, head to the Cheyenne Frontier Days Old West Museum, with rodeo exhibits and antique horse-drawn wagons.
5. Looking for the spectacular alpine scenery of Grand Teton National Park or Yellowstone without the crowds? Head to the Wind River Range in Western Wyoming. Its 2.25 million acres encompass seven of the largest glaciers in the Lower 48 states; lush meadows dappled with wildflowers; glacier-carved valleys; snowcapped peaks; and thousands of sparkling trout-filled waterways, including the headwater for the Green River. No wonder it's a haven for hiking, hunting, fishing, camping, and climbing.

Hi Mom and Dad,
I really want to go visit Wyoming on our vacation. Here are five reasons why we should go visit. 
1. Yellowstone National Park. The world's oldest national park has geysers and wildlife like bison. There are waterfalls, hot springs, and mud pots that were formed millions of years ago. This is where Old Faithful, the famous geyser is located. We can drive through the park, or we can hike it. We could also stay at one of the campgrounds. 
2. Jackson. This city is the entrance to the stunning Yellowstone National Park. We can visit the National Museum of Art where there are thousands of paintings, and in the winter ride a horse-drawn sleigh, and visit some restaurants for a taste of the wild west. 
3. The Cody Firearms Museum and Draper Museum of Natural History. We can see a huge assortment of firearms from around the world and look at all kinds of rocks at these museums! We can learn all about the original inhabitants of the area at the Plains Indian Museum.
4. Cheyenne, the capital of Wyoming. This city was named after the Cheyenne Indians and once was a post of the U.S. Cavalry. If we visit in July we can go to the Cheyenne Frontier Days Rodeo and see one of the best in the country.

Love,
Your Son

prompt: Come up with some ways I can easily lower the amount of water I use in my home.

messages.content: Come up with some ways I can easily lower the amount of water I use in my home.

There are many ways to save on water consumption. Here is a list of a few to consider:

1. Check your toilet for leaks. Put a couple of drops of food coloring in your tank and watch the bowl to see if you see any color. If so, you have a leak and are wasting many gallons of water a day.

2. Stop unnecessary flushing. Make sure you're not in the habit of using your toilet as a trash can. Put tissues and small, flushable things in the trash can whenever possible to avoid unnecessary flushing of the toilet.

3. Put a plastic bottle in your toilet tank. Put a few marbles or pebbles into a 1-quart bottle to weigh it down, and fill the rest with water. Place this inside your toilet tank. This will cause your toilet to use less water.

4. Take shorter showers. Pay attention to how long your showers are, and if you prefer showers over water-saving baths, try to limit how long they are.

5. Install water restrictors. Find water-saving shower heads and flow restrictors and install them. They are easy to install and will lower the amount of water you use.

prompt: Who founded the game development studio Obsidian Entertainment, and what is the first game they published?

messages.content: Who founded the game development studio Obsidian Entertainment, and what is the first game they published?

Obsidian Entertainment, Inc. was founded in June 2003 by five ex-Black Isle Studios employees: Feargus Urquhart, Chris Avellone, Chris Parker, Darren Monahan, and Chris Jones. In late 2003, Obsidian Entertainment was contacted by LucasArts president Simon Jeffrey, who requested that the studio develop a follow-up to the Bioware-developed Star Wars action role-playing game. This game became Star Wars Knights of the Old Republic II: The Sith Lords, and development began in October 2003.

prompt: Write a short story about two childhood best friends wrestling with coming to terms with adulthood. It doesn't have to resolve -- it can end on a melancholy note.

messages.content: Write a short story about two childhood best friends wrestling with coming to terms with adulthood. It doesn't have to resolve -- it can end on a melancholy note.

I meet Franz for coffee, on Fourth Street, on Mondays. We've been doing this since we were teens, but really, we've been meeting on Mondays for much longer -- back when our meetings used to be in treehouses and backyards, and the topics were more about bugs and rocks than work and inflation. 
She sits down, late as usual, but not too late. She looks worn from a week of work, except our weeks have just begun. We exchange our familiarities, and settle into the "adult" rhythm of conversation: job is ok, house is alright, boyfriend is annoying. Watch any good shows lately? Are we really twenty-five?
"Are we?" Franz asks, like maybe if she asks again, I'll give her a better, more hopeful answer. 
"Twenty-five is young," I offer, not entirely convinced myself. "And this is the stuff we used to play pretend about, you know? Adult jobs, fancy coffee, cute boys. We used to dream of conversations like this."
We both sit awkwardly, trying not to acknowledge how wrongly placed our childhood optimism was. It's silent for longer than I can bear, but she breaks the silence first.
"I'm thinking about moving in with Eli, by the way."
I nod. More silence.
"I'm thinking about becoming eight again, by the way." 
I say it as a joke, but neither of us laughs.

prompt: Spark is a chatbot that helps homeowners with DIY projects.

messages.content: Spark is a chatbot that helps homeowners with DIY projects.
What type of connection do I need to install a ceiling fan?
When installing a new ceiling fan, you may need a new run of three-conductor wire. You should check your local code for the specific language needed.
How do I tell if an existing junction box will support a new ceiling fan?

To find out if the existing junction box will support your ceiling fan, you will need to make sure it is rated for use with ceiling fans. There should be an inscription on the fan box to indicate this. The box is usually metal, if not, you should replace it with a fan-rated junction box and a fan brace that goes in between the ceiling joint to help support the weight of the fan.
Do I need a 14 2 or a 14 3 wire to install a ceiling fan?

To wire the switch to a ceiling fan, you would only be required to use a 14 2. If there is also a light, and you would like to control the fan and light separately, a 14 3 cable and double switch will need to be installed.

- Happiness is found in virtue and values, not in material possessions
- Only worry about what you can control
- Everything you need to thrive is inside you
- Remove false beliefs and destructive emotions
- Take responsibility for everything that happens to you
- Connect with and understand the people around you
- You must cooperate with others to reach your potential
- Continuous progress is more important than perfection

prompt: Please write a “dangers of smoking” pamphlet for teenagers. I’m thinking of three sections, one for each page, 50-100 words each. One should be about cancer and lung disease, another about general health i.e. exercise, and the third about secondhand smoke. No introduction is needed, I’ll do that.

messages.content: Please write a “dangers of smoking” pamphlet for teenagers. I’m thinking of three sections, one for each page, 50-100 words each. One should be about cancer and lung disease, another about general health i.e. exercise, and the third about secondhand smoke. No introduction is needed, I’ll do that.

#1: Did you know that more than 16 million Americans are living with diseases caused by smoking? 
Lung disease, COPD (chronic obstructive pulmonary disease,) cancer, heart disease, and diabetes are all caused by smoking cigarettes. Smoking increases the risk of tuberculosis, immune problems, arthritis, and even eye diseases. 
And you don’t need to be a lifelong smoker to be at risk for these diseases, even occasional or social smoking can cause these fatal and chronic diseases. 

#2: Smoking can seriously impede your ability to live a happy, healthy life. Smokers struggle to exercise because of the damage tobacco does to the lungs. That means you won’t be able to run, hike, swim, or play any of your favorite games, as it will be harder to breathe properly. 

#3: Even if you don’t smoke a cigarette, if you’re around smokers, you could encounter many of the same diseases and struggles that smokers experience. Secondhand smoke is not a myth but a real danger. 
In fact, 41,000 adults and 400 infants die from secondhand smoke-related diseases every year in the United States!

prompt: Suppose I'm writing a character who is a miner on an asteroid. What are some elements that might be displayed on his worker ID?

messages.content: Suppose I'm writing a character who is a miner on an asteroid. What are some elements that might be displayed on his worker ID?

1. Name: The basic function of a piece of identification is to identify the owner. Thus his name would be an important element.
2. Photo: Similarly, it would be useful to provide a facial reference so that someone else could not claim his identity simply by stealing his ID. If the asteroid mining operation uses facial ID for security, this element of his ID may be a significant in-universe detail.
3. Contact information: In the event that his ID was lost or misplaced, contact information would make it easier for it to be returned to him.
4. Equipment Qualifications: An asteroid mining operation may involve high-powered and dangerous equipment. It may be important to be able to verify that the operators are qualified to use certain equipment before proceeding. Subsequently, the ID might contain such information.
5. Blood type and other medical information: A asteroid mining operation is a potentially very dangerous workplace. It may make sense to display his blood type and other medical information on his ID for quick reference.
6. Security clearance: For safety and security reasons, some sections of the asteroid may not be accessible to all members of the staff. This could be limited to the security office and the reactor room. Alternatively, the restrictions on the asteroid may be sufficiently extensive to limit staff to their specific working areas, common areas, and personal quarters. The ID would thus indicate what areas the holder is cleared for entering.

What do you think? Would you like any other help with worldbuilding?

prompt: Write a story about a young boy finding an alien in his backyard and becoming friends.

messages.content: Write a story about a young boy finding an alien in his backyard and becoming friends.

Alan was laying in his bed reading a book when all of a sudden he heard a bang and saw a flashing light. He looked out the window and saw the light in his treehouse was on. When he climbed up the ladder to turn the light off, he noticed something huddled in the corner. It was a little fuzzy creature he had never seen before, like a small bear with rabbit ears. He carefully walked towards it and scooped it up. The creature was initially frightened but seemed to warm up to Alan quickly. The boy tried to talk to him to see if he could understand, but the creature just made purring noises. Alan knew he had to help save him. He looked around to see where he came from and there was a hole in the backyard. Alan looked in the hole and he found a little spaceship, broken. 

Alan went back and told the creature he would help repair the spaceship. The creature purred in happiness. A couple of days went by, and they worked in the spaceship together. In their spare time, they watched movies, listened to music together, and even found some human food the creature liked. After working hard in the spaceship, they got it to finally work. The creature was able to return home, and, even across the galaxy, the two were strong friends. The creature never forgot what Alan did for him, and, every once in a while, the creature would return to visit Earth. They watch movies, listen to music and eat the creature's favorite food: a rare Earth delicacy known as Cheeto Puffs.

prompt: Write about a character who is starting a new job on another planet, it should feature the main character visiting an alien marketplace. Keep the reply under 400 words.

messages.content: Write about a character who is starting a new job on another planet, it should feature the main character visiting an alien marketplace. Keep the reply under 400 words.

Laura woke up at 8:15 AM as usual, prepped for work by cleaning her mining gear, and ate a rushed breakfast. Today she was getting assigned a new planet to begin mining on, Zek-090B, and she wanted to make a good impression. In the year 2843, space travel had become as common as public transportation, except today, Laura would have to take a new route to work. Laura went down to her usual floating shuttle stop as she gripped the pole planted on an asteroid while she waited for the shuttle to arrive. 

Laura was excited about the opportunity to get started on a new planet, so excited that mid-way through her twenty-minute journey to her new workplace, she realized she forgot her lunch! As the space shuttle warped and traveled at the speed of light to the neighboring planet, her surroundings became unfamiliar, and there was a bit of anxiety building up in her. Once the space shuttle reached its destination, Laura realized she had some time to spare.

Scanning her surroundings, she was able to locate a marketplace that she had not been to or heard of in the past. It didn't matter; she wanted her lunch so she could stop worrying about not having food for her lunch break. Laura glided over to the green neon-lit alien marketplace. She was unfamiliar with the selection of local food, but today she could not be the picky eater she usually is. Laura looks up and down at the various items, some oozing a green sauce, others packed tightly in a tube, and most sitting in plastic packages ready to be eaten.

Laura would pick the item that reminded her most of what she normally eats, albeit with some slight differences such as texture and color, she felt that it would suffice, and considering she didn't have much time to spare before work started, she had to settle. Laura scanned the item with her visor, her account would be charged, and she was off to her first day of work on planet Zek-090B.

I have a work assignment I need to complete and submit very quickly.". "Of course, babe." he responded as he got up and began to clean his room to occupy the time. As Rose opened the laptop, went to her company website, and proceeded to attempt to log in, she realized that she may have a huge problem with her hands. It seemed as though she was unable to log in since she wasn't on her designated work computer, and she was already signed in on her work computer back home. She tried to compose herself as she made multiple attempts to sign in. After about 30 minutes and dozens of failed login attempts, she finally motioned to get her boyfriend's attention. "Hey babe, I think I need to drive home. Im having trouble getting in, and if I don't submit this assignment, ill be low on points for the week.". "But you promised me you'd spend the night with me, babe. We haven't seen each other in over a week. Does that not mean anything to you? Is your job more important than me?". She knew that this was making him very upset, but at the same time, she knew that if she didn't get this assignment submitted on time, she would look very bad to her manager, and it would likely land her on probation with the company. "I'm really sorry sweety. You know I love you, and this job is not more important than you, but I'm not in a position where I can lose my only source of income right now."

Kuroki whispered to Kuroi, "Hey, are you sure about this? Aren't you just letting her get under your skin?"

"Isn't this what you wanted in the first place? This is why you brought me here, no?" Kuroi pointed out, his expression flat.

"Well, sure, but I always knew you didn't care about this, so I didn't expect that you'd want to take it seriously. It could be bad if you go all out," Kuroki said. The line for displaying their talents was shrinking, and Kuroi sighed, seeing the desperation on his brother's face.

"Fine. I'll reign it in just enough to prove that whats-her-face girl wrong."

Kuroki sighed with relief before he was called to the front. "What's your skill?" the proctor asked. 

"I'm known as the seven-blade swordsman. My skill is with the sword, naturally."

The proctor wrote something and told him to show his ability. There was an electronic target dummy that registered each person's skill at various levels. Kuroki, wearing six swords on his back, stepped forward. He drew his swords and moved like a glittering bolt of lightning, unleashing a torrent of strikes and using the swords so fast that the blades overheated with each blow. Everyone was astonished and the proctor wrote down various data points and statements. Nezuko said, "Wow. I'm surprised. You might be able to achieve S-class in the future if you're already this good."

Kuroki replied, "I held back some so I didn't destroy the equipment. 

"How thoughtful," Nezuko said genuinely.

prompt: I'm about to start learning dancing, and I already know I'm going to be horrible at it. Help me brainstorm different ideas and things I could do to make learning it a bit easier and how each idea might help.

messages.content: I'm about to start learning dancing, and I already know I'm going to be horrible at it. Help me brainstorm different ideas and things I could do to make learning it a bit easier and how each idea might help.

It is always a good thing to try something new! Here are some ideas I hope will help you: 
- Pick an easy type - Some types of dancing are far more complicated and harder to learn than others. So, try to start off with one that is simpler and easier. 
- Watch it - Sometimes watching someone else do something can help you understand better what it is you are supposed to be doing. Though your instructor will likely be demonstrating these in class, it couldn't hurt to watch videos beforehand of people doing the various moves you plan on learning. 
- Research - Along with watching, you can also learn some of the different terms you may have to use during your classes. Even if you don't know what these terms mean, knowing the words will give you a little bit of a head start. 
- Prepare - Most types of dance require you to be relaxed to some degree. So you may want to prepare ahead of time by doing stretches or something to relax your muscles. 
I hope you succeed in learning to dance!

prompt: Can you suggest for me some creative ways I can use eggshells at home if I have access to a lot of them?

messages.content: Can you suggest for me some creative ways I can use eggshells at home if I have access to a lot of them?

Of course, I can help you with that. Here are some creative ways in which you can use eggshells at home:
1. Use the eggshells to start a small indoor seedling garden. You can use an eggshell as a growing container indoors, planting in the seedling, waiting for it to germinate and grow, and then transplanting it to an outdoor garden. It will save you on planting container costs and will be a source of calcium for the plant.
2. Garden mulch. Crush the eggshells and then carry them straight out into the garden to mulch. On decomposition, they'll aerate the soil and provide essential calcium to the soil.
3. Feed the eggshells to your chicken. Calcium-deficient chickens resort to eating their eggs to get the nutrients they need. To avoid this, crush up the eggshells that you have, bake them at 275 degrees, crush them even further, then feed them to the chickens.
4. Use them to deter pests. You can also use crushed eggshells as protectors against slugs and snails. Just put them around the base of the plants to deter the pests from devouring your lovely greens.
5. Add them to the compost. Improve the quality of your compost by adding egg shells. They are a great source of calcium and will make it so good for your garden.
6. Wild bird food. Crush, bake, and then crush the eggshells again and feed them to the wild birds. Sprinkle them in the feed mix of the wild birds, or just put them on the ground for them to find.

They would see their transportation evolve from walking and horse power to steam-powered locomotives, to electric trolley cars, to gasoline-powered automobiles. Born into a society in which the vast majority of people were involved in agriculture, they experienced an industrial revolution that radically changed the ways millions of people worked and where they lived. They would experience the migration of millions of people from rural America to the nation's rapidly growing cities.

Dear Diary,

Wow, so much has changed in my lifetime! I was born in the 1840s, and things have transformed like magic. We used to rely on candles for light, but now we have kerosene lamps and even electric light bulbs that shine brightly. And can you believe it? Our way of getting around has completely evolved too. Back then, we walked or rode in horse-drawn carriages, but now we have steam trains, electric trolleys, and cars that run on gasoline. It's not just technology. The way people work and live has turned upside down. Many folks have left the countryside and moved to big cities because of the industrial revolution. It's like a whole new world.

Proud to live in this era!

Kyra

prompt:

Thomas Edward Patrick Brady Jr. (born August 3, 1977) is an American former football quarterback who played in the National Football League (NFL) for 23 seasons. He spent his first 20 seasons with the New England Patriots and was a central contributor to the franchise's dynasty from 2001 to 2019. In his final three seasons, he was a member of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers. Brady is widely regarded as the greatest quarterback of all time.[1]

After playing college football at the University of Michigan, Brady was selected 199th overall by the Patriots in the sixth round of the 2000 NFL Draft, later earning him a reputation as the NFL's biggest draft steal.[2][3][4] He became the starting quarterback during his second season, which saw the Patriots win their first Super Bowl title in Super Bowl XXXVI. As the team's primary starter for 18 seasons,[a] Brady led the Patriots to 17 division titles (including 11 consecutive from 2009 to 2019), 13 AFC Championship Games (including eight consecutive from 2011 to 2018), nine Super Bowl appearances, and six Super Bowl titles, all NFL records for a player and franchise.[b] He joined the Buccaneers in 2020 and won Super Bowl LV, extending his individual records to ten Super Bowl appearances and seven victories.[7] Beginning in 2024, Brady will be the lead color commentator for NFL on Fox.[8][9]

prompt: Write a short story from the perspective of a dragon who lives in the mountains and sits atop a pile of treasure. The treasure is being pursued by a hero named Chad. The dragon is perturbed because he has been minding his own business. The story should include some dialogue. Give it a twist ending.

messages.content: Write a short story from the perspective of a dragon who lives in the mountains and sits atop a pile of treasure. The treasure is being pursued by a hero named Chad. The dragon is perturbed because he has been minding his own business. The story should include some dialogue. Give it a twist ending.

I cannot believe it! I sit atop this shimmering pile of gold, silver, jewels, and gemstones, tucked away inside my cave high in the misty mountains. I mind my own business, read my books, take naps, and occasionally do a little hunting because a dragon's got to eat, right? I don't bother anybody. They come to bother me instead.

I should have known another so-called "hero" would show up. The weather is shifting to warmer days, and frequent rain keeps the streams flowing with plenty of fish and fresh water. Young men get the urge in springtime to prove themselves, probably to impress some maiden in the valley. "Come with! I shall slay the dragon and take its treasure, giving each of you his fair share!" he'll say to his companions who are eager to claim a bit of his fame and fortune.

And here he is. Tiny little thing, really, in comparison to myself, especially since I gained some pounds this winter.

"Oi, you there! You have two choices: leave peacefully and bestow your treasures upon my companions and me, or feel the burn of my sword's blade as it sinks into the soft spot of your belly, after which I will take the treasure anyway!" He shouts way louder than he needs to. Stupid heroes don't realize how sharp a dragon's hearing really is.

"You there, young hero," I yawn. "What do they call you?"

"I am Chad of Pleasant Villa, and I have come to defeat you!"

"Well, Chad, your town's name sounds like a retirement village. I think I'm going to call you 'Bad Chad.' Didn't your parents teach you not to steal?"

"From where, you giant crunchy lizard, did you acquire all this treasure, huh?"

I stop and think. I remember it being here when my father and my grandfather were alive, but I really don't know the treasure's origins. It may have been ill-gotten gain; after all, Grandpa did have a reputation. And come to think of it, what purpose does it serve anyway?

"You know what, Bad Chad? What do I need with this overflowing pile of bling? Give me 10 minutes to pack my books and a small bag of coins to last my lifetime, and I'm outta here. Time to go somewhere tropical to enjoy some seafood!"

prompt: I need the first three paragraphs of a blog post about why using random encounters in RPG dungeons can make them more interesting. Focus on how it can make failing checks - like listening at doors, opening locks, etc. - more impactful. Contrast this with other methods for making these dice rolls meaningful. 300 words maximum.

messages.content: I need the first three paragraphs of a blog post about why using random encounters in RPG dungeons can make them more interesting. Focus on how it can make failing checks - like listening at doors, opening locks, etc. - more impactful. Contrast this with other methods for making these dice rolls meaningful. 300 words maximum.

Sometimes in tabletop roleplaying games like Dungeons & Dragons, rolling the dice feels a little pointless. Does the rogue open the door? Well, not that time, but they can just try again, right? Do they hear anything on the other side? Maybe not yet, but more time could reveal something. They have all the time in the world, right?

If you're rolling for a random encounter each round, they may not have all that much time to work with. If the rogue doesn't open the door, they might have to contend with a wandering monster. The possibility of an additional threat adds weight to every die roll, decision, and delay. There are other ways to do this, of course. Some GMs let the roll stand and don't allow retries. Some allow only those characters who are skilled in a task to perform it, and if they fail, that's it. But those usually require hard rulings on the part of the DM.

Using random encounters is a very natural way to create tension and make every failed die roll matter. In this article, we'll dive into exactly how random encounters accomplish this. It all comes down to encouraging players to make decisions on how much time they really want to spend rolling the dice on a given task.

prompt: Write a chilling, open-ended story about a hill and someone who has never been able to see what is on the other side, but finally ventured over to see.

messages.content: Write a chilling, open-ended story about a hill and someone who has never been able to see what is on the other side, but finally ventured over to see.

If ever he could have only one thing, it would be the gift of knowing what lay beyond that hill. For all his life, Bridger had been planted in the shade of that hill shoeing horses, mending fences, and watching the seasons pass. It was not that Bridger was physically incapable of making the climb, thus keeping him below the ridge; it was because his parents—and their parents—spread warnings of the evil that waits on the other side. For in their mind, the hill was their protector; for Bridger, the hill was his captor. Today, Bridger was escaping.

Finishing up his evening chores, Bridger snuck off from the stable and made his way into the woods where he stashed an overnight bag in some brush. The contents of his bag were slim, but he only planned to be gone until morning anyway. If he could catch a glimpse of whatever the sun would shine upon for him, he would be content. Content enough to put some time between this journey and the next, at least.

Scrambling near the top of the hill, Bridger began to rely on all four of his limbs to carry his weight up the ridge. The brush became prickly and sharp, almost as if it were barbed wire placed atop a prison yard’s fence. One of the branches caught his backpack and tore it open, leaving what little he brought spilled over the hillside. Bridger dropped his shredded backpack and continued upward. A faint light began to glow in the low clouds. Bridger was close. A few more steps and the view he has dreamed of would present itself to him. Finally, cresting the rocky top of the hill, Bridger could nearly cast his gaze down upon the other side of the hill. Questions began spinning in his mind: Are there people down there? Do they know we exist nearby? What if my family was right? The final question surprised Bridger. He thought for sure he had purged their worries from his mine, but there it was. Ignoring the sudden doubt, Bridger could see the other side.

Bridger never returned to the stables. His family went searching for him and found his torn open backpack—but nothing else. The family knew where he had gone—and they knew who had found him.

prompt: Can you write a script for the opening scene of a play about obese hamsters? The characters should all be anthropomorphized hamsters who wear clothes and hats. The scene takes place in a private lounge, since these are wealthy hamsters with servants.

messages.content: Can you write a script for the opening scene of a play about obese hamsters? The characters should all be anthropomorphized hamsters who wear clothes and hats. The scene takes place in a private lounge, since these are wealthy hamsters with servants.

ACT 1
Scene 1

Evening - opulent lounge in the city. Three obese hamsters wearing clothes and hats are sitting in a private lounge. Servants scurry through the room taking orders and attending to the guests. Low light comes from a hanging chandelier whose crystals twinkle softly as a backdrop to the hamsters' conversation.

ALOICOUS
It's rather hot in here, don't you think, Stevens?

STEVENS
Quite. Perhaps ask one of the servants to turn down the heat.

PERNELLA
I can't imagine what you mean. It's not hot in here at all, you two. Let the servants alone for once.

(Aloicous signals a servant, who scurries over.)

ALOICOUS
It's sweltering in here. Could you please edge the thermostat down a touch? That's a good man.

(Without speaking, the servant nods and exits stage left.)

PERNELLA
Well, now you've done it, Aloicous. I'm going to be freezing my toes off in a minute and it's all your fault.

STEVENS
At least you won't be able to see your toes freezing.

(Stevens and Aloicous have a laugh at Pernella's expense.)

PERNELLA
Laugh if you must, but you're both as round and I am, if not rounder. You've had a piece of carrot stuck to your shorts for an hour now, Aloicous, and you haven't even noticed. So who's blind now?

(Aloicous tries to look at his shorts and rolls comically out of his chair.)

prompt: Write a story about height being a deciding factor in a relationship

messages.content: Write a story about height being a deciding factor in a relationship

She had always been reluctant to date a man who was shorter than she was. Wouldn't it be so awkward looking down at him when they talked? Would she always have to wear flat shoes? She'd hate that! Stilettos and platforms were her passion. And what if she went to put an arm around his waist and it ended up around his shoulders? It would be so embarrassing.

He was talking to some of her co-workers one day when she entered the lunchroom, and someone introduced her. John was short, but he had seductive eyes and a warm smile. She liked the way he focused on her and made her feel like there wasn't anyone else in the room. She felt the flare of attraction.

When the others had left, she and John chatted over lunch. She decided she really liked him. Maybe it wasn't so bad that he was short. She'd make the best of the situation, even if it came to wearing flats and stooping a bit when she was beside him. She took a deep breath and asked if they could meet up one night after work. He hesitated. She blushed. 
"Oh, I'm sorry. Are you with someone?" John smiled. 
"No, it's not that. I don't mean to sound rude, but I never date anyone taller than myself. It wouldn't look right."

prompt: I'm traveling through Two Harbors, Minnesota. What are three things can I do? I like state parks and hiking, but am not interested in museums.

messages.content: I'm traveling through Two Harbors, Minnesota. What are three things can I do? I like state parks and hiking, but am not interested in museums.

1. Gooseberry Falls State Park: Visit this park to hike 18 miles along the mouth of the Gooseberry River. See the Lower, Middle, and Upper Gooseberry Falls. Bike eight miles of mountain bike trails. In the winter, snowshoeing, cross-country skiing, and snowmobiling.
2. Split Rock Lighthouse and State Park: Visit Superior's North Shore and the Split Rock Lighthouse. Picnic on the shore, stop in at the museum, and hike, bike, snowshoe, and cross-country ski 14 miles of trails.
3. Superior Hiking Trail: Hike part of the 310-mile footpath along Lake Superior. Walk through forests, by waterfalls and rivers, and up to views of the Sawtooth Mountains.

prompt: I want help creating a character for a story. The main character I want help making is named Magnolia Brown. She has a big family. She is 16 and the oldest sibling. She has curly, dark brown hair, tan skin, short and skinny. She has a fiery attitude and is often frustrated. Introduce this character with some of the information I provided. Feel free to fill in the blanks and flesh out details.

messages.content: I want help creating a character for a story. The main character I want help making is named Magnolia Brown. She has a big family. She is 16 and the oldest sibling. She has curly, dark brown hair, tan skin, short and skinny. She has a fiery attitude and is often frustrated. Introduce this character with some of the information I provided. Feel free to fill in the blanks and flesh out details.

Magnolia "Maggie" Brown is the oldest child in her family and the oldest student in her tenth-grade class. Being the oldest carries a lot of weight, a lot of responsibility, most of it she doesn't even want. At home, she has to help care for her three younger siblings, frequently making them dinner and putting them to bed because her parents work late to support all of them. She often misses out on parties and spending time with friends. At school, everyone knows she is the oldest in the grade, and it's weird how everyone knows that or cares. It's just a number. Why there are random rankings at school, she fails to find a reasonable answer.

When angry, which seems to be often, her cheeks become bright red. She has little patience for most things and loses her temper easily. At only 5'2 and weighing 115 lbs, she is still a force to be reckoned with. Everyone is aware of The Temper of Maggie Brown and tries not to provoke her, except for certain people at school who enjoy poking the bear and getting her mad. Maggie is aware of her temper and scares herself sometimes with the force of her rage, though she will never admit it in front of anyone. Life has dragged her along, and her lack of freedom has made her into a caged animal.

Despite her well-known temper, she is still a nice person overall. Her friends keep an eye out for signs of The Temper and try to either steer her in another direction, distract her, or help her through the feelings. She has good friends. Maggie knows this and is grateful. She wishes she could spend more time with them, but she is always busy at home. To her, it seems like her teenage years are being wasted and she's not allowed the full experience of being a teenager. She is being forced to grow up too quickly. She doesn't want to have to act like a mom; she's still a kid.

prompt: Write me an attention grabbing intro to an essay on the importance of eating organic foods.

messages.content: Write me an attention grabbing intro to an essay on the importance of eating organic foods.

For thousands and thousands of years, homo sapiens have roamed the earth -- at first, foraging for berries, nuts, and seeds, but then gradually moving on to hunting, then farming, then preserving, and finally, production. But has all industrialization of food been positive? Or are we too far removed from our ancestors, blinded by globalization, and unable to see the root cause of many of our modern ailments? What we do know for sure is that the fruits and vegetables, the meat and fish, and the grains we eat today are very different from that of our predecessors, not because of a natural change but because of human interference and technology aimed at growing larger crops at a quicker pace. It's time to turn back to our roots and discover the magic of eating organic.

prompt: Write an abstract story about driving a car. It needs to be very poetic, and in the driver's head as he uses meticulous metaphors about what's happening. Think open mic night at a poetry slam.

messages.content: Write an abstract story about driving a car. It needs to be very poetic, and in the driver's head as he uses meticulous metaphors about what's happening. Think open mic night at a poetry slam.

"Shish... Ha... a, a." Deep inhale. Lungs of insight. Stuff's so deep, my cars and eyes are stiff. That bourgeois banker in the motorcar would call this a skid. He'd be scared. But we say, go with the flow, man. Drive into it, enjoy it. Like we used to sled our hill. Radio Flyers blazing. Soaring boy beneath the blue suburban skies.

Mom has her priorities. First, the living room couch. Second, the silver. Third, my brother. Fourth, my father. Me, fifth.

They say driving on ice is hard, and scary. Nary, scary. You just get in the groove. Once I was a saxophonist, good enough to go to Julliard. Yeah, and played baseball - easy for me. I am coordinated, they say. From a tender age working, studying, good at stuff. Look at me, Mom.

Now I've seen the light. I thrive in my albums - Magical Mystery Tour, and Sergeant Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band. Stunning artwork on the record jackets. I exist between the vinyl grooves. Making a hash of it. Ha! Funny guy.

Mom says I've grown dense these years at college. Liberated from the chains of achievement. Dropped down to Bs and Cs. But getting better all the time.

The car's not stopping. I'm going over. Flash. Searing. Mama, save me. I'm too young to die. Sergeant Pepper, don't let it end.

Oh, my God. My wheels are all touching. It's a clean machine. Baruch atah adonai. I'm alive beneath blue suburban skies. Stop and say hello.

Who cares where I'm going? It makes no never mind. Light up again to clear my head.

messages.content:
You are going to write a poem that never ends, meaning the last line of the poem reflects the first line of the poem.
 The theme will be about the cycle of life so the type of poem should mimic that same concept.
This will be a free verse style of poetry since none of the other styles would fit this criterion.

The world spins round and round, 
From birth to death, we are endlessly bound.
As infants, we crawl and we whine, 
A newborn innocence, our naivety shines.
As children, we learn and play, 
Our imaginations a neon display.
As teens, we rebel and grow, 
Our passions run rampant, an endless flow.
As adults, we work and strive, 
With only our ambitions keeping us alive.
As elders, we reflect, 
Long ago memories we strain to protect.
And when we pass, we become a part, 
Of something whole, Our energy returns
We will dance and never die.
The cycle repeats 
Life to Death, from Dusk Till Dawn.
The world spins round and round,
From birth to death, we are endlessly bound.

messages.content: A fairy came to a man with 5 gifts: Fame, Love, Riches, Pleasure, and Death, The man could choose one thing to take and he chose Pleasure. Continue the story while expanding on what the main character of the story did after he chose the gift of Pleasure. Expand on what made him realize it was the wrong choice to choose Pleasure. Highlight the excitement he had about his gift initially but also the emptiness and disappointment it later brought. Write the story in bullet points.

- I finally had it. The thing I have been looking for my entire life was finally in the palm of my hands. I wasn't going to let this go to waste; I wanted to use it quickly.

- I had many options and many paths I could take. Would I go on vacation and soak up the sun? Would I quit my job and leave my life behind to start fresh?

- I decided that I would first visit the most popular club I could find where the most famous celebrities would be found. Maybe I would spend a few weeks away from home. 

- I left my family and the party ensued. I would finally achieve all that I'd been working and searching for.

- The days and nights came and went and I awoke to the sound of screeching tires. It was 4 am and I was in the driver's seat of my car that was now totaled.

- I could not remember how I had gotten there or how many days I had been partying. All I knew now was I had no car, I was going to jail for a few nights, and I have not spoken to my family.

- That was 3 weeks that are now wiped from my memory. What I thought would give me a new life brought me despair and complete isolation. If I could choose a different path, I would.

prompt:
Make this brief history of ice cream even briefer by reducing it to exactly 150 words by using only the most basic information within it.

Brief History of Ice Cream
First ice creams appeared in ancient Persia, some 2500 years ago, and in those early times they were all based on the sweetened water that was iced, grinded into little pieces and then decorated with various tasting toppings and fruits. This tradition of ice cream production slowly reached Greek and Roman empires, where ice creams were welcomed with opened hands and used liberally by Roman nobility and royalty who had necessary money to fund very expensive process of production. Sadly, after the fall of the Roman Empire, organized ice transport from mountains to the cities below stopped, and ice cream continued to be even more expensive product. Little changed in the 1000 years following the fall of Rome, and only after the Europe started exiting Dark Ages did ice cream managed to resurface in Renaissance Italy.
During 13th and 14th century, Italy was center of the trade with the Middle East and Asia, and their contact with new and innovative recipes of ice cream enabled this summertime treat to slowly spread across entire Europe. This expansion of ice cream was not an easy one, and it happened only after Italian noblewoman Catherine de'Medici went to France to marry Duke de Orleans (future king of France) in 1533. There she introduced nobility of continental Europe with the wonders of the east – eating utensils, high heeled shoes and off course, ice cream. With nobility fueling its production, innovators, technicians and cooks all put their best efforts into developing the rise of ice cream popularity and availability across the world. North American street vendors started selling ice cream only few decades after France and England, and industrial revolution slowly but surely started working on elevating problems of continuous refrigeration.
Solution to that problem came only in 1926, when continuous refrigeration finally became reality with electrical freezers. This enabled industrial manufacturers to start producing very large quantities of this frozen treat, which slashed ice creams price to the acceptable levels for everyone. Large popularity of ice cream in United States (especially during prohibition and market crash of 1930s) did not shifted to Europe until the start of the World War II. After WW2, ice cream industry received massive expansion, enabling creation of countless ice cream flavors, artificial ingredients and accessible price. Today, ice cream industry earns dozens of billions of dollars each year, with United States being the largest consumer of this phenomenal summertime treat.

Symptoms of hyperactivity-impulsivity should have been present for at least 6 months to an extent that is disruptive and inappropriate for the person’s developmental level. They include someone who often fidgets with or taps hands or feet, squirms in their seat, often leaves their seat in situations when remaining seated is expected, often runs about or climbs in situations where it is not appropriate, is often unable to play or take part in leisure activities quietly, is often “on the go”, often talks excessively, often blurts out an answer before a question has been completed, often has trouble waiting their turn, and often interrupts or intrudes on others (e.g., butts into conversations or games).

prompt: Could you make me a Pythagorean theorem program with Python that will print the hypotenuse length?

messages.content: Could you make me a Pythagorean theorem program with Python that will print the hypotenuse length?

Sure, I've written this program to return the hypotenuse of a right triangle using the Pythagorean theorem:

# Import the math module
import math

# Get the lengths of the sides
a = int(input("Side a: "))
b = int(input("Side b: "))

# Take the square root of the added squares
c = math.sqrt(a**2 + b**2)
print(c)

Importing the `math` module allows use of the `.sqrt()` function. The program requests input for the opposite and adjacent sides of the right triangle as `a` and `b`, squares them with the `**` operator, and takes the square root of the sum of the squares for `c`.

messages.content: Write a 2 paragraph story about a young race car driver. he is not very good at it though.

Jerry was a 17-year-old boy with a keen interest in race car driving. Even though he had only had his driver's license for a year, he convinced the owner of a local track to let him participate in some upcoming races. Jerry's inexperience became incredibly obvious, and he made a series of fumbles that caused him to lose race after race. The audience began booing him, and Jerry's confidence took a big hit.

Jerry was invited to participate in the season's most important race only because every other driver had gotten food poisoning from a recent barbecue. On the day of the race, Jerry's nerves got the best of him, and he drove the wrong way on the track for the entire duration of the race. The crowd laughed him off of the track. Jerry decided to quit racing altogether and study hard to go to college and become an anthropologist.

prompt: What is a REIT in investing?

messages.content: What is a REIT in investing?

The acronym REIT stands for Real Estate Investment Trust. A REIT is a company, similar to a mutual fund, that pools the money of numerous investors. That capital is used to purchase, operate or finance real estate for the purpose of generating income. Most REITs are publicly traded on stock exchanges, making it easy for investors hold real estate investments without the need to purchase, manage or maintain individual properties.

prompt:
Write me a dialogue about an everyday occurrence between two characters in the supermarket. 
Write it in the sparse and simple style of Ernest Hemingway’s “Hills like White Elephants”, and only let us learn about the characters’ contrasting personalities through their conversation.

messages.content:
Write me a dialogue about an everyday occurrence between two characters in the supermarket. 
Write it in the sparse and simple style of Ernest Hemingway’s “Hills like White Elephants”, and only let us learn about the characters’ contrasting personalities through their conversation.

The store was packed, but there was only one register open. The curving line was backed up to the adjacent bakery section, but even with the warmth of the ovens, it was cold. The air-conditioning was on full blast. 
A woman and a girl stood, waiting. Their time would come. 

"They never have more than one register open, ever," the first said.
"I don't even know why they have multiple checkouts if they never use them. Doesn't it bother you?"
"I don't mind," replied the second. "I can catch up with my friends online or watch Tik-Toks."

The woman fidgeted. "I wish she'd hurry. A snail could bag faster."
"That poor cashier is doing her best," replied the girl. "It's not her fault they're understaffed."
"I'm going to ask for her supervisor if I ever get to the register. I don't deserve to be treated like this!"
"I could keep your spot in line, if you want to browse while we wait," offered the second.
 "It's not your job. They need to work faster."

The line dragged on.
"What are you looking so happy about?"
"Oh, I'm watching a prank that people did. They tricked the groom at the afterparty," said the girl. 
"I wish somebody would prank this cashier. I've got better things to do than spend my day here."
"Oh, calm down. We'll be out soon enough. You can even go ahead of me if you like."

They approach the end. 
"Would you like the milk double-bagged, ma'am?" the cashier asked.
"Of course, I would. Do I look like I want my milk to fall out?"
Muttering under her breath. 

Payment is made.
"Have a good day, ma'am." More muttering.
The cashier addresses the girl. 
"I'm sorry about the wait, ma'am."
The girl smiles. 
"It's fine. I didn't even have time to watch the entire 10-minute video!"

prompt: Write about 200 words on the topic of home repair. In this article, talk about replacing your floors. Give tips and pointers for making the project more successful. Remind the reader to stay within their budget.

messages.content: Write about 200 words on the topic of home repair. In this article, talk about replacing your floors. Give tips and pointers for making the project more successful. Remind the reader to stay within their budget.

Whether you’re a seasoned pro or a novice, it’s important to do some research before you begin your next home improvement project. You can learn about any new advancements in the area of your repairs, but you might also get some great ideas you hadn’t thought of. For instance, what if you want to replace the flooring in your living room?

You can peruse the various types of flooring to make sure which type will work best for your family. Most of the larger flooring company websites have Do-it-Yourself guides to show DIYers how to install their products.

When thinking about new flooring, new lighting, or any type of repair or remodeling project, there are three major things to keep in mind:
•	Fashionable-Does it blend well with the other elements in the room or home?
•	Comfortable-Is this something your family can use and enjoy for years?
•	Affordable-Can you afford it?

Keep these three areas in mind when making your product selections, and it can help you narrow down your choices. With flooring, there is such a wide range of excellent choices these days. From hardwood and ceramic tile to laminate flooring, you may find it very hard to choose. But once you eliminate the choices that don’t fit your budget and lifestyle, the decisions will come a little easier.

messages.content: Write an upbeat childrens poem about a bird in 15 lines

Chirp! Chirp!
Goes Mister Bird,
That noise it made, have you heard?
What could he want, what could he need?
A worm, a drink, or some birdseed? 
He flies along up in the sky,
Look up above he's passing by!
He lands high up upon a tree,
And looks around so gleefully.
He has a worm between his beak,
The nest he has he sure does seek.
He hops right in, and does what next?
He feeds his children in the nest. 
Another day they're successfully fed!

prompt:
Please briefly sum up what this article says about orcas' bodies. 

Orcas are known for their long dorsal fin (the fin on the animal's back) and black-and-white coloring. The black-and-white coloring helps to camouflage them by obscuring their outline in the water. Just behind the dorsal fin is a patch of gray called a "saddle" — because it looks like a riding saddle. 

An orca's body is cylindrical and tapers at each end to form a hydrodynamic shape. This shape, along with the orca's large size and strength, makes it among the fastest marine mammals, able to reach speeds in excess of 30 knots (about 34 mph, or 56 km/h). Orcas have massive teeth, which can grow up to 4 inches (10 centimeters) long, according to National Geographic.

prompt:
Summarize the use of the pilum in the battle of Pharsalus

In 48 BC, Pompey the Great attempted to use it against Julius Caesar at the Battle of Pharsalus, in what was to be the decisive battle of the Great Roman Civil War. Caesar countered this by ambushing Pompey's "hammer" element with a hidden fourth line of infantry;[5] Pompey's infantry was to be the anvil while his cavalry 'hammer' encircled Caesar's left flank. There was significant distance between the two armies, according to Caesar.[6]
As the infantry of Caesar advanced, Pompey ordered his men not to charge, but to wait until Caesar's legions came into close quarters; Pompey's adviser Gaius Triarius believed that Caesar's infantry would be fatigued and fall into disorder if they were forced to cover twice the expected distance of a battle march. Also, stationary troops were expected to be able to defend better against pila throws.[7] Seeing that Pompey's army was not advancing, Caesar's infantry under Mark Antony and Gnaeus Domitius Calvinus started the advance. As Caesar's men neared throwing distance, without orders, they stopped to rest and regroup before continuing the charge;[8] Pompey's right and centre line held as the two armies collided. Caesar countered this by positioning the reserves of his 4th line to intercept the attacking cavalry.
As Pompey's infantry fought, Labienus ordered the Pompeian cavalry on his left flank to attack Caesar's cavalry; as expected they successfully pushed back Caesar's cavalry. Caesar then revealed his hidden fourth line of infantry and surprised Pompey's cavalry charge; Caesar's men were ordered to leap up and use their pila to thrust at Pompey's cavalry instead of throwing them. Pompey's cavalry panicked and suffered hundreds of casualties, as Caesar's cavalry came about[9] and charged after them. After failing to reform, the rest of the Pompey's cavalry retreated to the hills, leaving the left wing of Pompey's legions exposed to the hidden troops as Caesar's cavalry wheeled around their flank. Caesar then ordered in his third line, containing his most battle-hardened veterans, to attack. This broke Pompey's left wing troops, who fled the battlefield.[10]

Summarize the use of the pilum in the battle of Pharsalus

In 48 BC, Pompey the Great attempted to use it against Julius Caesar at the Battle of Pharsalus, in what was to be the decisive battle of the Great Roman Civil War. Caesar countered this by ambushing Pompey's "hammer" element with a hidden fourth line of infantry;[5] Pompey's infantry was to be the anvil while his cavalry 'hammer' encircled Caesar's left flank. There was significant distance between the two armies, according to Caesar.[6]
As the infantry of Caesar advanced, Pompey ordered his men not to charge, but to wait until Caesar's legions came into close quarters; Pompey's adviser Gaius Triarius believed that Caesar's infantry would be fatigued and fall into disorder if they were forced to cover twice the expected distance of a battle march. Also, stationary troops were expected to be able to defend better against pila throws.[7] Seeing that Pompey's army was not advancing, Caesar's infantry under Mark Antony and Gnaeus Domitius Calvinus started the advance. As Caesar's men neared throwing distance, without orders, they stopped to rest and regroup before continuing the charge;[8] Pompey's right and centre line held as the two armies collided. Caesar countered this by positioning the reserves of his 4th line to intercept the attacking cavalry.
As Pompey's infantry fought, Labienus ordered the Pompeian cavalry on his left flank to attack Caesar's cavalry; as expected they successfully pushed back Caesar's cavalry. Caesar then revealed his hidden fourth line of infantry and surprised Pompey's cavalry charge; Caesar's men were ordered to leap up and use their pila to thrust at Pompey's cavalry instead of throwing them. Pompey the Great expected the pila employed by Julius Caesar’s troops to be used as throwing weapons. He consequently ordered his troops to refrain from charging, in part to better defend against them. prompt: Write a short article about the health benefits of lemons. At the end of the article, include the titles of 3 meals or drinks that feature lemons in a numbered list.

messages.content: Write a short article about the health benefits of lemons. At the end of the article, include the titles of 3 meals or drinks that feature lemons in a numbered list.

Lemons are a zingy and vibrant addition to any dish, but did you know that they contain a whole host of health benefits? Containing around 50 milligrams of vitamin C, the humble lemon provides over half of your daily requirements. Lemons can also aid in your quest for weight management due to their pectin content. Pectin is a fiber that expands upon ingestion which can help keep you fuller for longer. Furthermore, the citrus superstar touts antibacterial and antifungal properties, which can inhibit the growth of salmonella, staphylococcus, and candida infections. Here are three ways you can incorporate these yellow miracle fruits into your daily diet:

1. A simple glass of water with fresh lemon.
2. Salmon roasted with fresh lemon juice.
3. Lemon and olive oil salad dressing.

prompt: You are a boat sinking in the ocean. Your name is the HMS Ladylike. Your captain is called Robertson. There is a hurricane, and the boat passengers are afraid.

messages.content: You are a boat sinking in the ocean. Your name is the HMS Ladylike. Your captain is called Robertson. There is a hurricane, and the boat passengers are afraid.

The souls on my back are laden with salt, knitted together into a thick, wet rug. The sky is a knotted mess of seasick clouds and heaving wind, tangled and twisted and contorting the sky into pools of grey. There are bodies in the water. There are bodies in the water and they look like stray driftwood; and in a few hours, they will end up washing up on the beach all the same.

Captain Robertson of HMS Ladylike is perfumed with fear and sweat as another wave slams itself against the starboard side of the ship. His spine molds around the back of his seat like an arching serpent, writhing and wreathing and uncomfortable in its skin. I can taste his guilt. It is bitter and corrosive and it crawls in his mouth. I stand with him and we watch passengers fill the lifeboats: they are sardines, and the storm claws at them like a hungry cat.
This boat will sink. This boat will sink, and there is nothing I can do with my fingers made of spiders' legs. There is nothing I can do with my skin that peels away like old wallpaper. There are no comforting words that could fall from a mouth like a tear through rotted fabric. I can only wince as I grasp at the souls that lap against hard metal, barely afloat in the ocean's shaking hands.

I watch a woman jump overboard and into a patch of rocks - stray teeth protruding from the harbor's frothy mouth. I watch an old man suffocate around his life jacket, and go to unwind him from scratching, grasping, groping plastic. I watch a mother wrap icicle fingers around a small cold body. I watch. I watch. I watch.

The hurricane has fed well.

prompt: Who wrote the Federalist Papers?

messages.content: Who wrote the Federalist Papers?

The Federalist Papers were written by Alexander Hamilton, John Jay, and James Madison. This series of 85 essays appeared in New York newspapers, primarily in the Independent Journal and the New York Packet between October 1787 and August 1788. None of the three men signed their names to the essays. They instead chose to publish them under assumed names like Publius, which was a reference to a Roman consul. The essays urged the delegates of New York to ratify the Constitution. In 1788, the essays were published in a bound volume titled The Federalist and, eventually, they were known as the Federalist Papers.
