prompt: Could you provide me with three helpful practices to help me regain control of my finances?

messages.content: Could you provide me with three helpful practices to help me regain control of my finances?

Here are some ideas I have for you to get back on top of your finance:

1. Budgeting - this is extremely helpful in gaining an idea of your income and where you're money is going. It will also help you lay out any short or long-term goals you would have regarding your finances. A good rule to follow when it comes the budgeting is known as the 50/30/20 rule. What this means is you should allocate 50% of your after-tax income to expenses you consider essential, then you would want to allocate 30% to the things you want such as amenities in the last 20% should go towards your savings. 
2. Financial safety net - this practice will allow you to have money set aside for emergencies. Doing this will allow you to not rely on using a credit card for paying for major unexpected expenses. It's common practice to save about three to six months of your current living expenses to build that emergency fund.
3. Paying existing debts - existing debt can be a major contributing factor to the drain on your finances especially when faced with high interest rates. It's a good idea to make a plan to know how long realistically it would take you to pay off any loans or debt you may have. Cards that have the highest interest rates are the ones you're going to want to prioritize making extra payments on. You'll want to make sure you're only charging what you're capable of paying each month.

prompt: What is the biggest continent?

messages.content: What is the biggest continent?

There are various ways to measure and compare continents. Asia is the biggest continent on Earth in terms of land mass. Asia's area is 17.2 million square miles. Asia also has the largest population among the seven continents, with over 4.5 billion people. The next largest continent in terms of land mass is Africa. Africa is 11.6 million square miles in area, and is home to 1.3 billion people.

prompt: Write a social media post that talks about the Large Hadron Collider. It should give some general facts about the collider and be written from the point of view of someone who knows a bit about it, but is not an expert. Make sure to include the length of the tunnel in the facts. Give me at least 3 paragraphs worth of information about it. Each paragraph should be no more than 5 sentences long. Make the total length of information about the Large Hadron Collider more than 250 words.

messages.content: Write a social media post that talks about the Large Hadron Collider. It should give some general facts about the collider and be written from the point of view of someone who knows a bit about it, but is not an expert. Make sure to include the length of the tunnel in the facts. Give me at least 3 paragraphs worth of information about it. Each paragraph should be no more than 5 sentences long. Make the total length of information about the Large Hadron Collider more than 250 words.

Do any of you know about the Large Hadron Collider (LHC)? I was aware of it previously, but I didn't look into it until today. This thing's pretty amazing, so let me tell you about it. It's a particle accelerator, and its job is to smash tiny particles together. It's built inside a huge underground tunnel that's 27 kilometers long. The tunnel is a closed loop though, it's not just a tunnel that goes 27 km away from the starting point.

The collider uses magnets and other arrangements to accelerate particles to nearly the speed of light. At this point, the particles are put on a collision course with each other and ultimately collide. The magnets I referred to previously have to be kept at a temperature of ‑271.3°C. There are thousands of magnets in the collider, so it makes sense it's a long loop.

One thing that's amazing about the LHC is the precision with which it operates. It has to collide tiny particles into each other, so you can imagine trying to shoot two needles at each other from 10km apart and trying to make them collide — it's no easy task! The collider is operated by the wonderful people at the CERN Control Centre, and I'd encourage you all to learn more. I know I certainly plan on reading more about this amazing feat of engineering in the future.

prompt: Can you write a silly short story about the planets in our solar system? Assume they are all friends and that they enjoy teasing each other.

messages.content: Can you write a silly short story about the planets in our solar system? Assume they are all friends and that they enjoy teasing each other.

In a land far, far, far away, so far that you cannot even see it, lived a wonderful group of planet friends. They enjoyed playing tag and raced around the ever-glowing and enormous Sun, any and every chance they got. Mercury was the oldest and bravest and raced closest to the hot Sun. Venus tailed right behind with her beauty, and the Earth was the smartest and yet silliest of the group. She loved to pull pranks on the younger planets, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune. Saturn would giggle and spin her beautiful rings as she laughed with glee.

prompt:
Write this from the perspective of F. Scott Fitzgerald.

Amory Blaine, a young Midwesterner, is convinced that he has an exceptionally promising future. He attends a posh college-preparatory school and later Princeton University. He grows estranged from his eccentric mother Beatrice and becomes the protégé of Monsignor Thayer Darcy, a Catholic priest. During his sophomore year at Princeton, he returns to Minneapolis over Christmas break and encounters Isabelle Borgé, a wealthy, young debutante whom he first met as a boy. They embark upon a romantic relationship.

While at Princeton, he deluges Isabelle with letters and poems, but she becomes disenchanted with him due to his incessant criticism. After his prom, they break up on Long Island. Following their separation, Amory graduates from his alma mater and enlists in the United States Army amid World War I. He is shipped overseas to serve in the trenches of the Western front. While overseas, he learns his mother Beatrice has died and most of his family's wealth has been lost due to a series of failed investments.

After the armistice with Imperial Germany, Amory settles in New York City as it undergoes the birth pangs of the Jazz Age. He becomes infatuated with a cruel and narcissistic flapper named Rosalind Connage. Desperate for a job, Amory is hired by an advertising agency, but he detests the work. Due to his poverty, his relationship with Rosalind deteriorates as she prefers a rival suitor, Dawson Ryder, a man of wealth and status. A distraught Amory quits his job and goes on an alcoholic bender for three weeks until the start of prohibition in the United States.

When Amory travels to visit an uncle in Maryland, he meets Eleanor Savage, an 18-year-old atheist. Eleanor chafes under the religious conformity and gender limitations imposed on her by contemporary society in Wilsonian America. Amory and Eleanor spend a lazy summer conversing about their love. On their final night together before Amory must return to New York City, Eleanor attempts suicide in order to prove her disbelief in any deity, and Amory realizes that he does not love her.

Returning to New York, Amory learns that the fickle Rosalind is engaged to be married to his affluent rival Dawson Ryder. A devastated Amory is further dispirited to learn that his beloved mentor Monsignor Darcy has died. Homeless, Amory wanders from New York City to his alma mater Princeton and, accepting a car ride from a wealthy man driven by a resentful chauffeur, he speaks out in favor of socialism—although he admits he is still formulating his thoughts as he is talking.

Concluding his long argument about their time's political and societal problems, Amory emphasizes his disillusionment with the current era. He announces his hope to stand alongside those who would bring forth fundamental changes to the age. The men in the car denounce his views, but upon learning that one of them was the father to one of his old friends at Princeton and that the son had died in World War I, Amory and the man reconcile, acknowledging mutual respect. It dawns on Amory that his time as a young promising Princetonian man has all been but a wasted dream, and he parts ways with his travel mates amicably.

Continuing his lonesome walk towards Princeton, Amory gradually forsakes the final obsessions about times and people that once constituted fundamental ideologies of his old self. Standing alone and musing at the sight of Princeton's gothic towers, Amory ecstatically yet somberly concludes: "I know myself . . . but that is all."

Amory Blaine is my protagonist, a young Midwesterner who knows that he has a future full of potential. Who might that remind you of? He goes to Princeton. As time passes and with distance my protagonist becomes alienated from his mother. He becomes supported and guided by Monsignor Thayer Darcy, a Catholic priest. Upon return home from Princeton over Christmas break my character crosses paths with Isabelle Borgé. I wrote her to be a wealthy, upper-class, and fashionable young thing who first met Amory during youth. A romance develops.

Amory returns to Princeton and they correspond through letters and poems. I wrote in my novel that she soon became disappointed and disillusioned. My characters break up on Long Island after prom. My protagonist graduates and then is off to the Army during World War I. I wrote him to be shipped to the Western front. I also wrote that the mother dies and all inheritance is gone. Amory learns this while overseas.

Our protagonist returns to US soil and resides in New York, set in the early stages of The Jazz Age. I had to write into the plot a hateful Rosalind Connage, full of conceit and self-love. Our boy Amory is looking for a job and ends up at an advertising agency where he is ill-suited. Rosalind prefers the money of a rival suitor along with his status. Our poor boy can't compete. Amory quits his job and goes on a three-week binge fueled by alcohol and despair.

I have our boy then go to Maryland to visit an uncle. I then introduce the character of Eleanor Savage, an 18-year-old atheist. She finds her community, gender roles, and religion too restrictive. Our boy and Eleanor spend their time doing little else besides talking about their romance. To make things interesting I have to add a suicide attempt by Eleanor. Amory comes to his senses at this and realizes that he couldn't love her.

Upon our boy's return to New York, he learns that Rosalind is engaged and that his dearly loved mentor Monsignor Darcy has died. Amory wanders as a hopeless homeless person to Princeton catching a car ride from a wealthy man driven by a bitter chauffeur. He takes this time to share his political thoughts and develop them as he is speaking.

He lists his objections about society's current state peppered with disappointment in an ongoing argument. He hopes to be one along with others to bring about necessary reform to the important issues of his time. The wealthy man who offered Amory a ride along with his chauffeur reject the view held by our protagonist. I wrote for them to part peaceably after learning that Amory knew the man's son from Princeton. The man's son had died in the war.

On a deserted walk toward Princeton, our boy comes to terms with all of his ideologies and obsessions and abandons them. I end my novel with our protagonist standing deserted. I have him conclude, "I know myself . . . but that is all."

prompt: What is the symbolism behind the Hand of Fatima?

messages.content: What is the symbolism behind the Hand of Fatima?

The Hand of Fatima, also known as the Hamsa, as a symbol dates back to cave paintings. The name comes from Mohammed's daughter, Fatima. The five fingers of the hand represent the 5 pillars of Islam. The Hand of Fatima is often decorated with an eye, which represents an eye that sees everything. The Hand of Fatima also represents femininity. In the Jewish tradition, it refers to the "Hand of Miriam," which refers to the sister of Moses and Aaron.

The Hand of Fatima is mainly used as a symbol used for protection against and as a way to ward off the "evil eye." The "evil eye" is a curse that some believe to be cast by an evil glare, usually towards someone who is not aware that it is happening. Therefore, the Hand of Fatima, is used to protect against misfortune, back luck, ill health or even death. Jewelry fashioned in the shape of the Hand of Fatima is said to create positive energy for those who wear it and serve as protection for that person.

prompt: How long is the Nile River?

The Nile River is about 6,650 kilometres (or 4,130 miles) long. It is the longest river in Africa. It begins in the rivers that flow into Lake Victoria and empties into the Mediterranean Sea to the north.

prompt: Write a conversation between a salesperson and a customer that highlights the dangers of miscommunication.

messages.content: Write a conversation between a salesperson and a customer that highlights the dangers of miscommunication.

Salesperson (S)/Customer (C)

C: Hello, I'd like to buy that TV over there.
S: Sure, I can get you rung up on this register over here.
C: Sounds good.
S: So your total will be fourteen hundred dollars even.
C: Okay.
S: How will you pay today?
C: With my credit card.
S: Okay, you're all set!
C: Thank you.
S: You're welcome, have a nice day.

The next day:

C: Excuse me, you're the one who sold me the TV yesterday, right?
S: Yes! Good to see you again, how's the TV looking?
C: Well, that's what I'm here about.
S: Was there a problem with the TV?
C: No, the TV is fantastic...I just don't think it's fourteen thousand dollars fantastic.
S: What do you mean?
C: I was told it would be fourteen hundred dollars, not fourteen thousand dollars!
S: Sorry, I'm pretty sure I told you fourteen thousand dollars when I rang you up.
C: No you didn't! You specifically said fourteen thousand dollars even!
S: I'm sorry, sir, but why would I say that? The price of the TV you purchased is fourteen thousand dollars. It's our top-of-the-line television and the most expensive set we have in our store. The price tag even says "$14,000", see? (points to price tag)
C: I see that, but that's not what you told me. If you told me the correct amount was fourteen thousand dollars, I wouldn't have bought the bloody TV! Now I'm not only broke, but I've all but maxed out my credit card!
S: I'm sorry sir, but I think there was some miscommunication here. 
C: Yes, the miscommunication is that you told me the wrong price and now I'm out thousands of dollars more than I expected. I will be returning the TV and expecting a full refund.
S: I'm sorry yet again sir, but our store policy is all sales are final.
C: This is ridiculous. I'd like to speak to your manager.
S: I would be happy to have him call you at his earliest convenience, he is not working today but he will be in his office tomorrow.
C: No, I will be back tomorrow and I will talk to him in person!

prompt: Write a fictional travelogue about a trip to Paris. The person writing should not enjoy the trip. Limit the response to 5 paragraphs.

messages.content: Write a fictional travelogue about a trip to Paris. The person writing should not enjoy the trip. Limit the response to 5 paragraphs.

I had always dreamed of visiting Paris, the city of love and light. I had imagined strolling along the Seine, admiring the Eiffel Tower, exploring the Louvre, and tasting the famous croissants and macarons. But when I finally got there, I realized that Paris was nothing like I had expected. It was a huge letdown.

First of all, the city was crowded and noisy. There were tourists everywhere, pushing and shoving to get a glimpse of the monuments and museums. The lines were long and the tickets were expensive. I had to wait for hours to get into the Musée d’Orsay, only to find out that half of the paintings were on loan or under restoration. The Arc de Triomphe was surrounded by traffic and pollution, and the view from the top was not worth the climb.

Secondly, the city was dirty and smelly. There was trash on the streets, graffiti on the walls, and dog poop on the sidewalks. The metro was dark and dingy, and the trains were often delayed or canceled. The hotels were small and shabby, and the beds were uncomfortable. The bathrooms were tiny and moldy, and the showers were either scalding or freezing.

Thirdly, the city was rude and unfriendly. The locals were snobbish and arrogant, and they looked down on me for not speaking French. They rolled their eyes when I asked for directions or menus in English, and they ignored me when I said hello or thank you. The waiters were slow and surly, and they charged me extra for water or bread. The shopkeepers were pushy and dishonest, and they tried to rip me off with high prices or fake products.

I was so disappointed by Paris that I decided to cut my trip short and go back home. I felt like I had wasted my time and money on a city that did not live up to its reputation. I realized that Paris was not for me, and that I would never return. Paris may be a popular tourist attraction, but it is not a pleasant destination.

prompt: Write a short story from the point of view of an ant. A human poured water down his anthill home and now he infiltrates the man's house to get revenge.

messages.content: Write a short story from the point of view of an ant. A human poured water down his anthill home and now he infiltrates the man's house to get revenge.

They're gone. All of them. My family. My friends. All of them washed away in a torrent of water and a collapse of Earth. This was not the cruel mistress of weather bearing down on my home with rain. We had defenses and contingencies for that. No, this was the act of one man. A man with malicious intent. With purpose and hate, he walked the hose coupled to the side of his dwelling ut to my home. He held it aloft, pointing the doomsday downward. He let loose the flood of a thousand lives. All are gone. All are lost. All except me. 

My vengeance will not be swift. It is slow. It is methodical. I first must find ingress to the house. It is large and well-protected by barriers of metal, rock, glass, and clay. But I am patient. I know the places to look. Time ruins all structures. Eventually, I found it. It was a crack in the mortar between two rows of packed and fired clay. It was my way in. I took it. 

The inside is enormous and labyrinthine. Though the halls of this structure pale in complication to the once great passageways of my lost home. I take my time again. I scout the building, mapping every corner. I keep to the corners where the ceiling meets the wall to avoid the human's notice. There is danger here, as well. The human's feline companion patrols nightly. Her senses are not only better than the human's but they have also been adapted over thousands of years specifically to find prey. To her, I am prey. Avoiding her, I map the house.

I learn about the man -- my enemy. I learn his patterns and his habits. Every morning is the same. Every evening is mostly the same. I know with reliable certainty when he leaves and when he comes back. I know which television he likes to watch. I know he likes his water filtered. I know where he keeps the filters. I know where he keeps the rat poison. 

The rat poison looks like small granules of green . . . once I break it apart. Ants are good at that. It fits right in with the rest of the filter elements. It will take time. I know that. I can wait.

prompt: Write a short kid's book about an aardvark lost in Chicago. Include Chicago landmarks and escaping from his home at The Wilds Conservation and Preserve

messages.content: Write a short kid's book about an aardvark lost in Chicago. Include Chicago landmarks and escaping from his home at The Wilds Conservation and Preserve

There was once an adventurous aardvark named Ardel who loved to explore new places. He was very eager to wander and explore, his name even meant eager in Latin! He often escaped and led the staff on multi-day aardvark searches. He had become a bit of a celebrity for his antics. So, one day when Ardel stumbled upon the smallest of holes in the enclosure fencing, it was no surprise that away he went. 

But Ardel wandered too far from home this time and found himself in a strange new place - Chicago! He had never seen anything like the tall buildings and bright lights before. As he wandered around the city, he felt new emotions - he was lost and scared. But then he saw something kind of familiar - a statue of a cow! It was the famous Cow on Parade statue and reminded him of home. This made him relax a bit and Ardel explored the city for hours. He came across many of the famous landmarks in Chicago, like a cool shiny ball, the Willis Tower, and the colorful Navy Pier. He even stopped by to visit some of the animals at the Lincoln Park Zoo. 

But as the days passed, Ardel started to feel homesick. He missed his cozy burrow and the warm sun of The Wilds. He longed to return home.

Ardel grabbed a piece of delicious Chicago-style pizza (they didn't have termite flavored) and wandered over to the Shedd Aquarium to think. Watching the penguins frolic in the Oceanarium relaxed him. 

While he was there, a kind family noticed him and they took him in and gave him a warm place to stay. They wanted to get him home to Africa but called The Wilds Preserve for some advice. They found out that Ardel was from there! 

So the kind family took Ardel back to The Wilds. He said goodbye and knew he'd never forget his adventure in Chicago. It was nice being surrounded by familiar sights and sounds of the preserve.

As he looked back on his adventure, he realized that though he had been lost and scared, he learned a valuable lesson - that kindness and friendship can be found all around us, even in those who are very different from us.

The end - for now. (Ardell heard a family talking about how nice Detroit was this time of year ....)

prompt: Where are your kidneys located and how do they work?

messages.content: Where are your kidneys located and how do they work?

The kidneys are located right below the rib cage, and there is one on each side of the spine. A healthy functioning kidney filters about one-half cup of blood every minute. They remove extra waste and water to produce urine. Urine flows through two thin muscle tubes called ureters on each side of the bladder. The bladder stores urine. The kidneys, ureter muscles, and bladder are all part of a person's urinary tract.

prompt:
Classify a series of wine descriptions as red, white or rosé. 

wine descriptions:
1. Pull out this rosé at your next weekend barbecue, and prepare to feel popular. A lesson in balance, this highly aromatic blend from Goose Ridge in Washington State delivers bright berry fruit and refreshing acidity, followed by a creamy finish. 
2. Cooler weather doesn’t have to mean kissing your favorite crisp whites goodbye. Weighty enough to hold its own alongside rich foods and warming enough to deserve a place on your holiday table, this bottle is the perfect cool-weather white. Made from the lesser-known Greek white variety Aidani, expect notes of earthy sage and fennel alongside aromas of flint and struck matches. 
3. Craving red wine on a hot summer day? Say hello to this porch sipper. A 90 percent carbonically macerated red blend, it’s highly chillable, with notes of rooibos tea, bright cherries, and a drizzle of balsamic. The sustainably grown melange includes Nebbiolo, Primitivo, Syrah, Tempranillo, and more. On the palate, sweet fruity notes take a backseat to structured tannins, keeping everything in balance.
4. A sip of Grecian history, Mylonas Rosé offers a unique blend of two native grapes: Malagousia and Mandilaria. The resulting wine boasts slightly earthy flavors, with accents of honeysuckle and Camembert rind. This bottle especially shines alongside food, from green salads to cheese plates. 
5. Think all red blends taste the same? Think again. Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc, Merlot, and Petit Verdot combine to create distinct, structured notes of juicy strawberries and freshly cracked black pepper in this stellar bottling. Prominent tannins make for a slightly drying palate, but well-integrated fruit and acid keep things ultra-drinkable. Far from homogenized, this unique Napa Valley melange highlights how complex and well balanced red blends can be.
6. With ripe berries, cream aromas, and vibrant acidity, it’s not hard to see why rosés made from Pinot Noir continue to gain traction in the States. From Oregon’s Willamette Valley, home to some of the country’s best Pinot Noirs, Stoller Family Estate’s take on pink wine is juicy and refreshing, with enough complexity to grip the palate and pique your interest. 
7. Equally as fun as it is “serious,” this chillable red is a definite crowd-pleaser. It’s from Burgenland, a region in eastern Austria known for its full-bodied reds. For the Gamay lover looking to expand their horizons, this cool kid-approved bottle offers juicy, jammy vibes via an unexpected grape blend: Zweigelt and St. Laurent. A subtly tannic, slightly peppery red, it offers just enough sweetness to keep you coming back for the next sip. 
8. A supple Dolcetto that drinks like a highly expressive Merlot, this soft and juicy red is bursting with aromas of ripe blackberries, damp soil, and blueberry jam. From Massolino, a winery that’s been producing high-quality releases in Italy’s Piedmont region since 1896, this bottling is well structured and drinks like high-end Bordeaux blend, making its $20 price tag even more of a welcome surprise.
9. Bernard Baudry’s Chinon Les Granges arrives on the savory end of the red wine spectrum. Wafts of roasted red peppers and a bright hint of capsicum deliver everything we seek in Chinon, and more. The family-owned winery grows grapes across 79 acres in the famous Loire Valley appellation, producing a range of terroir-driven Cabernet Francs and Chenin Blancs. This wine was made to be drunk young and paired with aromatic, meaty meals like spaghetti bolognese or herb-crusted rack of lamb. 
10. Crafted as an homage to Madame Clicquot, who famously stated, “Our black grapes give the finest white wine,” the La Grande Collection is Veuve Clicquot’s celebration of the Pinot Noir grape in all of its elegance. A blend of 90 percent Pinot Noir and 10 percent Chardonnay grapes from eight of Veuve Clicquot’s historic grand crus, this bottle has an aging potential of 15 years. Rich brioche notes emerge on the palate without overpowering subtle tropical candied pineapple aromas. On the palate, fine effervescence and stunning acidity keep things light and mineral-driven. This is a lively and highly age-worthy bubbly that’s sure to make any occasion feel special.
11. A celebration of an extremely versatile native Greek grape, this bubbly pink wine is as easy on the palate as it is on the eyes. From the tiny town of Amyndeon in the Macedonia region, Kir-Yanni’s sparkling rosé is made from 100 percent Xinomavro, resulting in an ultra-vibrant, almost red hue that nears that of Lambrusco. A refreshing sip with notes of strawberries and hints black licorice, this sub-$20 sparkler is fruit-forward with high acidity and a faint perception of sweetness on the palate. Its active bubbles tickle the tongue and keep the wine light, bright, and ripe for fried food pairings.

prompt:
Explain checks and balances with examples like you're talking to a third-grader.

The ability of each branch to respond to the actions of the other branches is the system of checks and balances.

Each branch of government can change acts of the other branches:

The president can veto legislation created by Congress. He or she also nominates heads of federal agencies and high court appointees.
Congress confirms or rejects the president's nominees. It can also remove the president from office in exceptional circumstances.
The Justices of the Supreme Court, nominated by the president and confirmed by the Senate, can overturn unconstitutional laws.

messages.content:
Explain checks and balances with examples like you're talking to a third-grader.

The ability of each branch to respond to the actions of the other branches is the system of checks and balances.

Each branch of government can change acts of the other branches:

The president can veto legislation created by Congress. He or she also nominates heads of federal agencies and high court appointees.
Congress confirms or rejects the president's nominees. It can also remove the president from office in exceptional circumstances.
The Justices of the Supreme Court, nominated by the president and confirmed by the Senate, can overturn unconstitutional laws.

The system of checks and balances means that if one part of the government tries to do something, other parts have a say. For example, if Congress wants to do something, the President can say no! He can also put people in charge that have a big say too.

Congress can also decide whether they like who the President has put in charge!

And then there are the Justices of the Supreme Court. They can decide if a law is bad for the people of the US and say no to it.

prompt: Can you please make an Acrostic poem for the word "Colorado" that emphasizes some key features of the state, like mountains, hiking, the outdoors, and wildlife?

messages.content: Can you please make an Acrostic poem for the word "Colorado" that emphasizes some key features of the state, like mountains, hiking, the outdoors, and wildlife?

Crossing state lines into Colorado,
On a sunny winter morning.
Leaves have fallen off the aspen trees,
On the ground lay the bright orange remnants of fall.
Rockies twinkle majestically with snow
And as the sunlight catches the twinkle of a snowflake,
Deer run past my car window.
Oh, to hike these lands forever.

prompt: I am so sluggish and slow in the mornings – ugh! What are six ways that I can rev my brain and be more “awake” in the am?

messages.content: I am so sluggish and slow in the mornings – ugh! What are six ways that I can rev my brain and be more “awake” in the am?

Not everyone is an early bird, but many night owls still have AM responsibilities. Here are six ways to rev up your brain to feel more alert and attentive in the mornings when it’s hard to get out of bed! 

1. Take a cold shower with revitalizing scents to jolt your nervous system! 

Most people don’t want to get out of the warm embrace of their blankets, so a cold shower may take time to work up to. The cold water is an immediate wake-up call to your nervous system, but a lukewarm shower with revitalizing scents in shampoo and body wash can be just as effective. The best scents for alertness are spicy or have citrus notes, such as orange, cinnamon, rosemary, and peppermint. 

2. Avoid the allure of sugary cereals and other sweet breakfast foods. 

While it may be tempting to grab a doughnut and a Frappuccino on the way to work, resist the urge. Sweet breakfasts will increase your blood sugar, which can make you feel alert for a few hours before a hard crash of fatigue in the afternoon. 

Stick to a hearty, healthy breakfast with protein and heart-healthy fats instead. Eggs and bacon are a classic, but you could also blend a smoothie, have a slice of avocado toast, or opt for rolled oats with berries and a glass of whole milk. 

3. Drink a glass of ice-cold water before your morning cup of coffee. 

Many people can’t wait to have their cup of coffee in the mornings but steer clear until you’ve awakened your mind and body with a cold glass of water. Dehydration is a common cause of fatigue, so a glass of cold water will refresh your nervous system to get you moving in the AM. 

4. Listen to something upbeat, like a comedic, engaging podcast or your favorite “get up and go” music. 

Putting yourself in a good “go-getter” mood will help you awaken your senses in the mornings. Upbeat music or laughter are both great ways to help you feel more alert and prepped to take on the day. 

5. Stretch and work out fatigue with a quick walk outdoors. 

Not only will a good stretch and regular exercise help you sleep better, but a quick stroll outdoors in the morning is a change of scenery that tells your body and mind that it’s time to wake up for the day. Slow stretches work out kinks that accumulate in muscles while asleep.

6. Allow natural sunlight to permeate your surroundings in the mornings. 

This one may make you groan with dread, but sunshine suppresses melatonin production within your body. Melatonin is the chemical that makes you sleepy, and that’s encouraged in dark environments. Standing in sunlight for a few minutes after you wake up tells your mind and body that the day is getting started.

prompt: Where was the oldest American artifact found in the United States?

messages.content: Where was the oldest American artifact found in the United States?

In western Idaho, at a place named Cooper's Ferry, on the edge of a river fragments of charcoal and bone were found. The artifacts date back over 16,000 years making them the oldest American artifacts found in the United States. They helped reshaped the understanding of early peoples in the United States.

prompt:
What does this entry say about Karrakatta?

Karrakatta is a suburb of Perth, Western Australia, located within the City of Nedlands and 7 km west of the central business district. Its postcode is 6010.

Karrakatta is composed of two distinct areas, due to the Fremantle railway line passing through the suburb. On the south side is Karrakatta Cemetery,[2][3] which began service in 1899,[4] with a small industrial area occupied by monument builders, associated companies and the depot for City of Nedlands.

The other area north of the railway line and Karrakatta railway station is occupied by the Australian Defence Force's Irwin Army Barracks.

prompt:
What character does the story, Attack on Titan, follow based on the text below? When was the first season of the show broadcast and how many episodes long was it?

Attack on Titan (Japanese: 進撃の巨人, Hepburn: Shingeki no Kyojin, lit. 'The Advancing Giant') is a Japanese manga series written and illustrated by Hajime Isayama. It is set in a world where humanity is forced to live in cities surrounded by three enormous walls that protect them from gigantic man-eating humanoids referred to as Titans; the story follows Eren Yeager, who vows to exterminate the Titans after they bring about the destruction of his hometown and the death of his mother. It was serialized in Kodansha's monthly magazine Bessatsu Shōnen Magazine from September 2009 to April 2021, with its chapters collected in 34 tankōbon volumes.

An anime television series was produced by Wit Studio (seasons 1–3) and MAPPA (season 4). A 25-episode first season was broadcast from April to September 2013, followed by a 12-episode second season broadcast from April to June 2017. A 22-episode third season was broadcast in two parts, with the first 12 episodes airing from July to October 2018 and the last 10 episodes airing from April to July 2019. A fourth and final season premiered in December 2020, airing 16 episodes in its first part. A second part consisting of 12 episodes aired from January to April 2022, and a third and final part will air in two halves; the first half premiered in March 2023, and the second half will premiere in late 2023.

Attack on Titan has become a critical and commercial success. By September 2022, the manga had over 110 million copies in circulation, making it one of the best-selling manga series of all time. It has won several awards, including the Kodansha Manga Award, the Attilio Micheluzzi Award, and the Harvey Award.

prompt: My sisters and I want to start a comedy podcast but we don't know how we should do the episodes. There are so many podcasts that do advice and rants and stuff, and we don't want to do that. What are some segments we could have on the podcast?

messages.content: My sisters and I want to start a comedy podcast but we don't know how we should do the episodes. There are so many podcasts that do advice and rants and stuff, and we don't want to do that. What are some segments we could have on the podcast?

Here are some ideas for segments that you and your sisters can bring up on your podcast:

1) Spoiler-free movie reviews. You can talk about films you've seen in the past week, and discuss and review them without bringing up any details of the plot.
2) Weekly goals. You can discuss personal goals you have for yourselves, and invite listeners to participate or follow your journeys.
3) No context news. You and your sisters can each bring a list of news headlines that you have not read the articles to and discuss what you think the articles say.
4) Weekly challenges. Similar to the "goals" idea, you can challenge each other to do different things each week and discuss your outcomes the following episode.
5) Childhood diaries. If you kept diaries as children, you could take turns reading cringy stories. Alternatively, you could find entries on places like Reddit and Twitter and read other folks' entries.

Remember to share it on your socials when you publish your first episode!

prompt: Write about three fantasy witches who each have a different lifestyle. I want one paragraph for each. They don't have to be related. The witches should be shown in a positive light.

messages.content: Write about three fantasy witches who each have a different lifestyle. I want one paragraph for each. They don't have to be related. The witches should be shown in a positive light.

Emma had been a witch in her small seaside town her whole life. The children were all jealous of her broom when she was a kid but then marveled at her whooshing by once they had all grown up. She operated the area's fastest courier service and gave part of her earnings to the local school for young witches. 

Maddy was the kind of witch who only took to the skies at night. She wasn't "out of the broom closet" yet and didn't want everyone to know she was a witch. Anyone she'd ever talked to thought witches were ugly and green, putting curses on people. But she was different. She was nice, and she didn't think she was too ugly. Besides, she didn't know any curses anyway.

Ellard was in his room, practicing making potions from an ancient book when his mother knocked on the door. Quickly, he hid the book and tried to waft the smell out of the window. But, his mom was too smart not to know what he was up to. How many times had she told him that only girls could be witches? No, he was determined to prove her wrong.

prompt: Who is the most famous Magician of all time? And why?

messages.content: Who is the most famous Magician of all time? And why?

The most famous magician on this list, Hungary-born Houdini was part magician and part entertainer, thrilling audiences all over the globe who traveled from far and wide to see him escape from impossible situations.
He was most famous for his ability to escape from what seemed like anything and everything, including ropes, handcuffs, straight jackets, jail cells, water-filled milk cans, and even nailed-shut boxes that had been thrown into a river.
It seemed like there was nothing Houdini could not escape from and nothing he could not make audiences believe. He was even able to make an elephant disappear!
Houdini began to expose the tricks used by mediums. He gave lectures on the topic and often included demonstrations of these tricks during his performances. He joined a committee organized by Scientific American and analyzed claims for a $2,500 prize for true psychic phenomena (no one ever received the prize). He spoke in front of the U.S. House of Representatives, supporting a proposed bill that would ban telling fortunes for pay in Washington D.C.
Even though Houdini brought about some skepticism, it seemed to create more interest in Spiritualism. The result being  Spiritualists were extremely upset at Houdini and he received several death threats.

prompt: Create an idea for a video game based on the main character being a conscious leaf that tries not to fall off a tree.

messages.content: Create an idea for a video game based on the main character being a conscious leaf that tries not to fall off a tree.

The name of the game would be called "Tree Hugger." The plot is that every leaf has the mindset of a human being. They grow up on the tree, go to school just like humans would, and have families based on the branches they are on.  Once a leaf falls off the tree, it dies. The objective of the video game would involve divulging into the individual life of one of the leaves. The main goal would be to stay alive by not falling off the tree by any means necessary.

Several obstacles try to get in your way, such as squirrels, humans, weather, and even other leaves. You can do unique things, such as communicate with other trees and their leaves by using "Acorn Express" which is where you bribe squirrels with nuts to get them to communicate across yards for you. The more you level up your leaf, the different levels you can try and play. You start by only being able to live as a leaf on a lonely tree in Nebraska, but as you progress in the game you'll be able to play in places like a cherry tree in Japan, or a leaf on an elderly tree in the Amazon rainforest. There are multiple ways you could play the game. It would have RPG, open-world elements that would be confined by the outskirts of the tree.  It would also feature a couch co-op mode, where you could team up with your buddy as you control different leaves on the same tree.

prompt: Create an introduction to a campaign I am going to run. The setting is set in the far future where humanity's technology is now so advanced that they can now travel to distant worlds. The theme is sci-fi/horror. There is an unknown entity out in the stars that the group of adventurers will eventually encounter.

messages.content: Create an introduction to a campaign I am going to run. The setting is set in the far future where humanity's technology is now so advanced that they can now travel to distant worlds. The theme is sci-fi/horror. There is an unknown entity out in the stars that the group of adventurers will eventually encounter.

Thousands of years in the future, humanity has flourished. Life is now easier, richer, and more abundant. In a Golden Age of technology and prosperity, mankind has now extended its reach to the stars above. Habitable space stations, mining rockets, and commercial rig shuttles are all now commonplace. The availability of space has now given us new homes and resources; a chance to carve our existence in the universe. But in the pursuit of this cosmic glory, enamored by curiosity, we forget to ask ourselves one thing: Should we? 

Amongst the stars, we have forgotten the old fear, the true fear; the fear of the dark and the unknown. Our universe is old but the dark is much older. We have trespassed upon its domain forgetting it is sovereign. On Earth, we believed the Devil reigned below -- in fire and brimstone, laughing. Only to soon find that he plays in the ether above -- basking in starlight, screaming.

prompt: Sum up the movie “What Dreams May Come.” Who stars in which roles and how does it end?

messages.content: Sum up the movie “What Dreams May Come.” Who stars in which roles and how does it end?

What Dreams May Come is a tragic love and family story about a man named Chris Nielsen and his journeys through heaven and hell to find his wife, Annie. 

Chris originally winds up in heaven, met by a helping angel named Albert that shows him that each heaven is different from others’ heavens. In Chris’s afterlife, everything is made from paints, symbolizing his love for his wife, a renowned art dealer and painter. Chris meets another mentor, Leona, while exploring the heavens. 

Four years before his death, his children were killed in a car accident. When Chris dies too, his wife is left alone. Tormented by the memory of her lost family, Annie commits suicide, but taking her own life is a mortal sin that sends her soul to hell. She is trapped in a nightmarish afterlife of her design, but Chris is determined to save her from the depths of despair. 

What Dreams May Come ends with Chris deciding to stay with Annie in her hell because he loves her too much to abandon her again. She sees through her pain to his, breaking the spell of her nightmare, and the two ascend to heaven together where they are reunited with their children, Ian and Marie. They spend years together in heaven until Chris proposes that the two are reincarnated so that they can live life together again. 

The movie closes with Chris and Annie reincarnated as children, meeting for the first time in a way that mimics their first meeting in life before. 

The cast of What Dreams May Come included: 

Robin Williams as Chris Nielsen 
Annabella Sciorra as Annie Nielsen 
Cuba Gooding Jr. as Albert Lewis 
Rosalind Chao as Leona 
Josh Paddock as Ian Nielsen 
Jessica Brooks Grant as Marie Nielsen

prompt: Write a story about bumblebees in a garden in springtime. Use three examples of alliteration in the story. Also, use one simile. Make the story one paragraph with no more than 125 words.

messages.content: Write a story about bumblebees in a garden in springtime. Use three examples of alliteration in the story. Also, use one simile. Make the story one paragraph with no more than 125 words.

Bumblebees buzzed, buzzed, buzzed around the blooms like a springtime ensemble. Daisies, daffodils, begonias, and pansies dotted the ground, and huge hydrangeas huddled close together in puffs of pink, purple, white, and blue. Rosebushes bore buds waiting to blossom, and snowdrops - contrary to their name - indicated that sunny spring days were coming soon. The bees were content to buzz around these carefully chosen adornments for the garden, but the allure of wild clover and dandelions was even more irresistible.

prompt: Write a fantasy story about Limburgerhof.

messages.content: Write a fantasy story about Limburgerhof.

Fritz Haber and Carl Bosch labored above their glassware mixing chemicals and stirring beakers, measuring time, and checking the soil outside. The fields were bleak and empty. They had nothing to restore but rather they wished to build something new from the rubble and weeds that choked the land.

One day a cow gave Bosch the spark of brilliance he needed. He knew why some patches had more greenery than others. He told Haber who immediately scribbled plans for their contraptions.

They reverently dug into the sand to blow their own glasswork. Their labor of love needed no store-bought products. They would find a way.

Finally, in 1914, they synthesized ammonia using their unique method which kickstarted the age of mineral fertilizers.

In their legacy, the BASF company they left behind found ways to protect the new field they made. New scientists derived anti-fungal applications to prevent mushrooms from plowing through the ground. They found ways to fight weeds and even defend against the ravenous insects that swarmed the treeline.

Their efforts blossomed into a field of red tulips: Carl's mother's name and Fritz's favorite color. And the field is still verdant today, so explore the history and the majesty of nature at Limburgerhof.

prompt: How long does it take Earth to orbit the sun?

messages.content: How long does it take Earth to orbit the sun?
Earth takes 365.24 days (or one year) to orbit around the Sun. The distance is 940 million km at a speed of 108,000km/h (67,000 mph).

prompt:
Do salamanders have pheromones? What do pheromones produced by mother rabbits do?


In the half century since then, as the technology for isolating and identifying trace amounts of compounds has become more refined, pheromones have been found in almost every kind of animal, in squid, lobsters, ants, fish, salamanders, and mice, to name just a few. Although pheromones are important in many species for finding mates for sex, they can have a wide variety of other functions, such as one produced by mother rabbits that prompts suckling by their pups. In many social insects, such as the ants, bees, and wasps, almost every part of colony behavior is mediated by pheromones, from queen signals affecting worker reproduction within the colony to Butler’s "ranke smell" alarm pheromone that activates colony defense against enemies.

prompt: Help me write an email from me (Professor Sal) to my Biology student (John). Tell him his final exam score is 97 percent, good job, and that there's a TA position open next semester with me that he should apply for. It should be a professional, kind, congratulatory email

messages.content: Help me write an email from me (Professor Sal) to my Biology student (John). Tell him his final exam score is 97 percent, good job, and that there's a TA position open next semester with me that he should apply for. It should be a professional, kind, congratulatory email

Hello John, 

Now that I have finally had the chance to grade final exams, I am happy to report your score back to you. You received a score of 97% on your final exam, which is an A. Congratulations on this great feat! Not many people can say they scored so high on my Biology final. It's a tough one.

Because you were so successful in my class, I'd like to urge you to consider applying for a TA position with me. There is a slot open next semester, and I think you would be a great fit for the role! 
Again, great job this semester, and I hope to see more of you in the future!

Sincerely, 
Professor Sal

prompt: Please brainstorm 10 foods that I can deep fry. We're having a deep fried Christmas party at work. The more fattening, the better. haha. It's supposed to be fun and goofy

messages.content: Please brainstorm 10 foods that I can deep fry. We're having a deep fried Christmas party at work. The more fattening, the better. haha. It's supposed to be fun and goofy

Sure thing, here are ten deep-fried food ideas for your party:

1. Macaroni and cheese. Roll macaroni and cheese in balls, then toss them in the deep fryer. You'll end up with balls of piping-hot cheesy goodness.
2. Butter. Bite into a juicy ball of pure fat. You can deep-fry butter in chunks or just throw the entire stick in there.
3. Oreos. It sounds like it wouldn't work, but the fried batter and chocolate cookies create the perfect sweet-and-savory flavor combination.
4. Doughnuts. Turn a ring of sweet dough into a crispy, greasy snack dripping with a sugar glaze.
5. Jalapeno poppers. They're already a fried food classic, but you can deep-fry your cheese-stuffed jalapenos for extra crunch and flavor.
6. Pickles. Deep-frying pickles makes them nice and crunchy like potato chips with a tang.
7. Chocolate bars. This is particularly fun because you can experiment with different varieties: Snickers, Three Musketeers, Hershey's bars, etc.
8. Cookie dough. When you bite into the fried crust, you meet a deliciously sweet center dotted with chocolate chips.
9. Peanut butter. This is a little like a peanut butter doughnut, but it's hot and savory instead of sweet.
10. Bacon. Treat them to a classic with crispy bacon deep-fried until it's crunchy, meaty, and dripping with grease.

Try including a mixture of ordinary and unusual deep-fried foods so that people who don't want to risk it can still enjoy a treat. Deep-fried Oreos are fun, but they're not for everyone!

prompt: Write an informative blog section about nanoparticles and their use in cosmetics. Talk about the health concerns of nanoparticles and that some studies suggest possible carcinogenic effects. Also mention other health related problems linked to it, and discuss the ingredients they usually have. Keep the response under 400 words.

messages.content: Write an informative blog section about nanoparticles and their use in cosmetics. Talk about the health concerns of nanoparticles and that some studies suggest possible carcinogenic effects. Also mention other health related problems linked to it, and discuss the ingredients they usually have. Keep the response under 400 words.

Nanoparticles – used in cosmetics such as toothpaste, lipstick, or deodorant – are tiny particles over a thousand times thinner than the diameter of a human hair. For example, the pigments titanium oxide and zinc oxide are used in sunscreens and stay like a film on the skin to reflect sunlight.

That all sounds positive at first, but the nanoparticles in cosmetics are controversial. Their effect on humans and the environment has not yet been adequately researched, and many meaningful studies have not been conducted. How tiny nanoparticles used in cosmetic products affect our health is completely unclear.

Studies by the Federal Environment Agency on nanoparticles suggest a possible carcinogenic effect of some nanomaterials. These may include carbon nanotubes or titanium dioxide, which should be taken seriously.

Many cosmetic products also contain nanoparticles. Silver nanoparticles in deodorants have antibacterial properties. Other types of particles in creams and lotions help the skincare products get absorbed into the skin more easily. Toothpaste with nanoparticles fills the finest cracks in the teeth. Kohl pencils and mascaras have a longer shelf life, thanks to nanoparticles.

Nanoparticles don't get through the skin if it is healthy. However, they can get into the blood via the respiratory tract. At the beginning of the year, scientists from the Center for Medical Biotechnology shared initial findings on how nanoparticles could influence our stomach and intestinal flora. According to this, nanoparticles can bind to harmful and beneficial bacteria, including probiotic germs.

The immune system can recognize pathogenic bacteria more poorly when covered with nanoparticles. It promotes intestinal inflammation. Certain nanoparticles weaken the infectivity of the Helicobacter pylori germ involved in the development of gastric cancer.

prompt: How many types of Cathode Ray Tubes (CRTs) are there?

messages.content: How many types of Cathode Ray Tubes (CRTs) are there?

The CRT has been a dominant electronic information display unit for over 50 years. The displays used are available in two configurations:
    • Monochrome: These are CRTs used by measuring instruments such as oscilloscopes and high-resolution medical monitors. Also known as single-color CRTs, monochrome CRTs use electrostatic deflection, which scans an electron beam across the screen.
    • Color CRTs: These tubes have three electron beams deflecting magnetically and impinging on three color-producing rays. These tubes help produce images and are most common in computer monitors and televisions.

prompt: Create a sonnet about the sadness the last bite of ice cream causes.

messages.content: Create a sonnet about the sadness the last bite of ice cream causes.

My sweet, frozen cream, once my true delight,
Oh, the last bite, my heart begins to sink,
Sorrow leaves me feeling it's just not right,
That last bite is gone, it's so fast - in a blink.

In my last final taste, I sense it's the end,
The last moment is wonderful and rare,
Such fleeting joy that I comprehend
Is now vanished, leaving behind despair.

They say all good things must come to an end,
Oh, but why not a little longer still,
Fate so cruel, rob me of my tasty friend,
Leave me with such vast emptiness to fill.

Alone I sit, tears streaming down my face,
Forlorn, dreaming of ice cream's final trace.

prompt: My mum's birthday is coming up and I have no idea what to give to her. What should I buy? Give me 10 ideas.

messages.content: My mum's birthday is coming up and I have no idea what to give to her. What should I buy? Give me 10 ideas.

Choosing the right gift for your mum can be tricky. Here is a list of 10 ideas to help you find something she will like:

1. A good quality pan: If your mum enjoys cooking, a good pan can be the perfect gift for her.

2. A necklace: If your mum wears jewelry and likes to include it in her styling, a unique necklace could be just the thing for her.

3. A getaway: To show your mum you appreciate everything she does, you can book a night away for her in a relaxing setting.

4. A flower kit: For a mum who loves plants, a flower grow kit will be just the thing to make her smile.

5. A bidet: If your mum likes practical gifts, a bidet to install onto her toilet seat could be just the refreshment she needs.

6. Makeup: Does your mum enjoy using makeup? Help her feel even prettier with a nice makeup set.

7. A reusable cup or drink bottle: For a busy mum who is always on the go, a reusable coffee cup or drink bottle could be the perfect gift to make life easier for her.

8. A wallet: Who doesn't like a stylish wallet? Treat your mum to a lovely new wallet to suit her taste.

9. A blanket: Help your mum feel cozy and warm by getting her a fluffy new blanket for the cold winter evenings.

10. A nice sweatshirt: A comfortable, cozy sweatshirt with a unique pattern or an interesting picture will make your mum's nights even more comfy.

I live in North Carolina and saw a green hummingbird today. What kind of hummingbird was it?
You might have seen a Buff Bellied hummingbird. That is a green hummingbird commonly sighted in your state.
It was looking at my Scabiosa flower. Do butterflies like Scabiosas?
Hummingbirds love a pincushion flower! They also enjoy snapdragons and sunflowers. I'm not sure about butterflies.
I've heard that GMO flowers grown for places like Home Depot are bad for pollinators. Is that true?
Neonicotinoid insecticides can indeed be dangerous for hummingbirds, as well as bees. I don't know if the plants at Home Depot use that type of insecticide.

prompt: Please write 2 introduction paragraphs for an article on Barry Bonds. The article will focus on his career and the impact of steroids. Make it retrospective and pose the question of steroid use as a question of intrigue.

messages.content: Please write 2 introduction paragraphs for an article on Barry Bonds. The article will focus on his career and the impact of steroids. Make it retrospective and pose the question of steroid use as a question of intrigue.

One of the league's most dominant all-time hitters, Barry Bonds has a career surrounded by controversy. Despite being one of the league's all-time home run leaders, Bonds has struggled to make his way into the Hall of Fame. As with many other great power hitters, Bonds' career is now shrouded in the controversy of steroid usage. Other notable names to have steroids cloud their reputation include sluggers Mark McGwire, Sammy Sosa, and Alex Rodrigues. It is a tough position for Hall of Fame voters and fans alike as they try to separate their feelings about steroids from the players' careers.
 
In his time in the majors, Bonds slugged 762 homers at a .298 average. It is undoubted that Barry Bonds is one of, if not the best, hitter of all time. By all accounts, he should be in the Hall of Fame. His stats are truly remarkable, and we may never see another batter who dominated the game in the way that he did. But should all concerns about steroids be thrown out the window? This article will dive into the career of Bonds as well as the controversy that now surrounds it.

prompt:
Run through this text and make a chronological bullet list starting from most recent of all the prizes that Murakami has won in the format of * {Prize} | {year}


Personal prizes

Haruki Murakami in 2018
In 2006, Murakami became the sixth recipient of the Franz Kafka Prize.[65]

In January 2009, Murakami received the Jerusalem Prize, a biennial literary award given to writers whose work deals with themes of human freedom, society, politics, and government. There were protests in Japan and elsewhere against his attending the February award ceremony in Israel, including threats to boycott his work as a response against Israel's recent bombing of the Gaza. Murakami chose to attend the ceremony, but gave a speech to the gathered Israeli dignitaries harshly criticizing Israeli policies.[66] Murakami said, "Each of us possesses a tangible living soul. The system has no such thing. We must not allow the system to exploit us."[67]

In 2011, Murakami donated his €80,000 winnings from the International Catalunya Prize (from the Generalitat de Catalunya) to the victims of the March 11 earthquake and tsunami, and to those affected by the Fukushima nuclear disaster. Accepting the award, he said in his speech that the situation at the Fukushima plant was "the second major nuclear disaster that the Japanese people have experienced ... however, this time it was not a bomb being dropped upon us, but a mistake committed by our very own hands". According to Murakami, the Japanese people should have rejected nuclear power after having "learned through the sacrifice of the hibakusha just how badly radiation leaves scars on the world and human wellbeing".[68]

In recent years, Haruki Murakami has often been mentioned as a possible recipient of the Nobel Prize in Literature.[15] Nonetheless, since all nomination records are sealed for 50 years from the awarding of the prize, it is pure speculation.[69] When asked about the possibility of being awarded the Nobel Prize, Murakami responded with a laugh saying "No, I don't want prizes. That means you're finished."[15]

In October 2014, he was awarded the Welt-Literaturpreis.[70]

In April 2015, Murakami was named one of the TIME 100's most influential people. In November 2016, he was awarded the Danish Hans Christian Andersen Literature Award, an award previously won by British author JK Rowling.[71][72][73]

In 2018 he was nominated for the New Academy Prize in Literature.[74] He requested that his nomination be withdrawn, saying he wanted to "concentrate on writing, away from media attention."[75]

prompt: What, exactly, is rhetoric? Provide me some information that explains what rhetoric is, where the idea came from, and how it is applied. Do so in a way that a college student would understand using less than 250 words, and using no more than 3 sentences per paragraph.

messages.content: What, exactly, is rhetoric? Provide me some information that explains what rhetoric is, where the idea came from, and how it is applied. Do so in a way that a college student would understand using less than 250 words, and using no more than 3 sentences per paragraph.

Rhetoric was first mentioned by Aristotle in 350 B.C.E. Rhetoric is the act of persuading people in writing or orally to accept the writer’s or speaker’s argument as correct. Rhetoric uses three strategies to persuade: Logos, Ethos, and Pathos. In English, we know them as Logic, Ethics, and Emotion.

Pathos/Emotion means to persuade by direct appeal to a person’s emotions so that they feel what the author wants them to feel. To accomplish this, the author chooses words, examples, and stories that evoke emotion. The ensuing emotional responses such as anger, frustration, or amusement can lead people to become sympathetic to the author’s position.

Logos/Logic means to persuade by direct appeal to a person’s logical reasoning. To accomplish this, the author presents clear, logical connections between ideas, that are supported by facts and statistics or by presenting analogies. If the arguments presented contain unclear or erroneous assumptions in facts or analogic connections, known as logical fallacies, the argument can fail.
 
Ethos/Ethics means to persuade by convincing a person of the author’s inherent credibility based on the author’s credentials and/or the credentials of the sources of facts and ideas presented as part of the argument. To accomplish this, the author presents their own and/or their sources’ academic, professional, and/or authorial history, details their personal experience as it relates to the issue, and demonstrates their complete understanding of the issue’s complexities by using counter arguments to an opposing position.

prompt: What are some other movies like Hunger Games I might like and why? I'm really wanting newer movies and ones with more dystopian or apocalyptic settings

messages.content: What are some other movies like Hunger Games I might like and why? I'm really wanting newer movies and ones with more dystopian or apocalyptic settings

No problem! If you liked The Hunger Games movies, you might like some of these: 

* Snowpiercer: Like The Hunger Games, this is a post-apocalyptic movie based on a book with many of the same themes, including class struggles and a violent revolution. 
* The Maze Runner Series: Like The Hunger Games series, there are multiple installments to watch. This one is set in a dystopian society where teenagers must survive -- much like Katniss and Peeta. 
* The Divergent Series: Here's another set of films set in a dystopian future with teenagers at the center of the plot. The society in these films is divided into factions whereas the society in The Hunger Games is divided into districts. 
* Mortal Engines: This film, like The Hunger Games, features a strong female lead. It's also based on a post-apocalyptic young adult novel where the characters fight for survival and resources.

prompt: Im going to Tokyo next month and I love to try new food.  Can you come up with five affordable (like the price of a typical snack) types of street food I should try there to get the best authentic experience?  I'm okay with weird flavors and textures, but the food has to be sanitary.

messages.content: Im going to Tokyo next month and I love to try new food.  Can you come up with five affordable (like the price of a typical snack) types of street food I should try there to get the best authentic experience?  I'm okay with weird flavors and textures, but the food has to be sanitary.

Absolutely, here are a variety of five different affordably priced Tokyo street foods:

1. Takoyaki - Steamed dough shaped into a ball and filled with octopus. The outside is nice and crispy, and the inside is a savory and gelatinous octopus. Usually costs around 400 yen, the typical price of a snack.

2. Yakitori - Chicken grilled on a skewer with choices like heart, liver, and thigh. This is a classic Japanese street food and will cost you between 100-200 yen.

3. Taiyaki - A fish-shaped pastry filled with sweet red bean paste. This will run you around 250 yen and is a fun street snack with historical significance.

4. Okonomiyaki - A savory cabbage pancake with a choice of additions like noodles, bacon, and shrimp. This one costs a bit more at around 1000 yen, but the delicious umami flavors are worth the splurge.

5. Onigiri - A triangular rice patty normally filled with kombu, konbu, or salmon and wrapped in seaweed. A cheaper option at 100 yen and convenient to eat on the move.

prompt: What did a Tyrannosaurus Rex look like?

messages.content: What did a Tyrannosaurus Rex look like?

A Tyrannosaurus Rex was a massive bipedal creature. It had a powerful tail, a huge head and tiny arms. Scientists struggle to work out what the tiny arms were used for because they were too short to reach its mouth and too weak to be of any use in defence or hunting. It is guessed that they may have counterbalanced its enormous head, or they could have been used in mating rituals.

prompt: Hi I would like to discuss the two main conceptual types of machine learning. Can we start our discussion with a short paragraph of 5 sentences?

messages.content: Hi I would like to discuss the two main conceptual types of machine learning. Can we start our discussion with a short paragraph of 5 sentences?

The two main types of machine learning are supervised and unsupervised models. Supervised models have a target variable they are attempting to build a model around. For example, there are binary classification models that attempt to denote a specific variable either true or not. In unsupervised learning methods, there is no distinction between what variable is the most important. Clustering is a good example, where different instances are grouped but not necessarily for the same reasons.

prompt: Using AutoHotkey v2.0.2 create a map that is stored in a variable called funObj. Add the following to the map: "a", "Don't", "b", "Call", "c", "Me"

messages.content: Using AutoHotkey v2.0.2 create a map that is stored in a variable called funObj. Add the following to the map: "a", "Don't", "b", "Call", "c", "Me"

Here is an example code that creates a map and stores it in a variable called funObj using AutoHotkey v2.0.2:
    funObj := Map("a", "Don't", "b", "Call", "c", "Me")

This code creates a map with three key-value pairs a, b, and c. The corresponding values are Don't, Call, and Me. The map is then stored in a variable called funObj.

prompt: What is the First Amendment of the Bill of Rights?

messages.content: What is the First Amendment of the Bill of Rights?

The First Amendment of the Bill of Rights, also known as Amendment I, ensures freedom of religion, freedom of speech, freedom of the press, and freedom of assembly. The actual text in the United States Constitution for the first amendment reads: "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging the freedom of speech or of the press; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the Government for a redress of grievances."

prompt: From a kindergarten-aged child’s point of view, describe what a day of school looks like to them.

messages.content: From a kindergarten-aged child’s point of view, describe what a day of school looks like to them.

I wake up super early in the morning. Mom makes me brush my teeth and put on my school uniform. Then I help her get my backpack ready. We get in the car and drive to school. We listen to music, which is fun. After Mom drops me off, I go to the cafeteria and get breakfast. I like French toast sticks and chocolate milk. After I eat, I go to my classroom and say good morning to my teacher. My teacher is nice, but sometimes I get into trouble for talking when I’m not supposed to. If I have a question, I’m supposed to raise my hand first and wait for the teacher to say my name. After I sit down at my desk, we listen to the morning announcements and then start learning stuff. Right now, we are working on writing and saying letters of the alphabet. After we do some letter stuff, the teacher will let us sit on the carpet and have story time. I like story time because my teacher reads us a different book every single day! And then, after story time, we go to specials! Sometimes we have P.E., and sometimes we have music. I like P.E. because we get to run around and play games. My favorite is kickball.

After specials, it’s time for lunch. I love lunch because the cafeteria has hot meals, and I get to choose what I want to eat every day. I also get to sit and talk with my friends when we eat lunch. After lunch, it’s time for recess! If it’s sunny outside, we get to play on the playground. I like swinging on the swings or playing tag with my friends. If it’s raining, though, we have to stay inside and play with arts and crafts stuff. Sometimes that can be fun. Then we start learning again. We work on numbers after recess. Sometimes we count, sometimes we write, and sometimes we add small numbers together to make bigger numbers. When it’s almost time to leave school for the day, the afternoon announcements come on. After we listen to them, we get our backpacks ready and walk outside to the pick-up line. Mom is always there waiting, so I say goodbye to my friends and get in the car to head home.

prompt: Write a short story about a Koala named Kevin who has to climb to the top of a tree for leaves. Have him meet his many different animal friends at each new level of branches, and have their names all start with an A.

messages.content: Write a short story about a Koala named Kevin who has to climb to the top of a tree for leaves. Have him meet his many different animal friends at each new level of branches, and have their names all start with an A.

Kevin the Koala is climbing to the highest point of his favorite tree to get the best leaves that are at the very, very top. He is looking forward to this because even if the journey is a slow one, he gets to say hi to all of his friends along the way.
As Kevin climbs up to the first level of branches on this tree, he sees his friend Amelia, the squirrel! "Good morning, Amelia!" Shouted Kevin gleefully. "Hey there Kevin!" said Amelia. "Are you looking for the best leaves at the top of the tree again?" "I sure am!" said Kevin. "Have a wonderful day Amelia. I have to get going!" After that, Kevin continued his journey upward.
As he reaches the next level of branches he spots Arthur the bird! "Hey, Arthur!" Bellowed Kevin. "It's a beautiful day to get some crunchy leaves." "It sure is, Kevin. Good luck on your journey." chirped Arthur. Kevin continued his trek with a smile on his face.
Kevin has now reached the third and final level of branches before he reaches the abundant high-quality leaves that sit above it. He looks over one of the branches and sees his good friend, Andy the caterpillar. "Andy!" shouts Kevin. "It has been a while since I have seen you. How is the family doing?" "They're doing great, thanks for asking, Kevin!" said Andy. "You're almost to your favorite leaves, enjoy your lunch."
Kevin pulls himself up for the final branch and arrives at his favorite spot with the best leaves in all of the forest. He munches down on his meal while thinking about all of his wonderful friends he knows that live here in this very tree. "I have got it good." Kevin thought aloud. "My life really is good." He takes another bite, thankful for everything he has.

prompt: What is the significance of ocean currents in regulating the Earth's climate, and how does this phenomenon function?

messages.content: What is the significance of ocean currents in regulating the Earth's climate, and how does this phenomenon function?

Ocean currents play a pivotal role in regulating the Earth's climate. Acting as a global conveyor belt, ocean currents transport heat from the equator toward the poles, helping to balance the Earth's temperature. This happens through a process called thermohaline circulation, driven by differences in temperature (thermo-) and salt content (-haline). Warmer, less dense water from the equator moves along the ocean surface towards the poles. As it reaches the colder regions, the water cools, becomes denser and saltier, and sinks into the deep ocean. This colder water then flows back towards the equator, where it warms up again and rises to the surface, completing the cycle. This process is critical for redistributing heat around the planet, and disruptions to it due to climate change could have profound impacts on global climate patterns.

prompt: How many bones are in the human hand?

messages.content: How many bones are in the human hand?

The human hand is made up of the wrist, palm, and fingers and consists of 27 bones. The wrist is comprised of 8 carpal bones. These wrist bones are attached to the radius and ulna of the forearm to form the wrist joint. They connect to 5 metacarpal bones that form the palm of the hand. Each metacarpal bone connects to one finger at a joint called the metacarpophalangeal joint or MCP joint. The bones in our fingers and thumb are called phalanges. Each finger has 3 phalanges separated by two interphalangeal joints, except for the thumb, which only has 2 phalanges and one interphalangeal joint.

prompt: Get me started with writing a story about a little girl named Judith who finds a magic wand in an old barn. The audience will be my class of third-graders. End it with a cliffhanger so I can make up the next part of the story.

messages.content: Get me started with writing a story about a little girl named Judith who finds a magic wand in an old barn. The audience will be my class of third-graders. End it with a cliffhanger so I can make up the next part of the story.

Once upon a time, a long time ago, there was a little girl named Judith. She was just about your age and had just finished the third grade. She loved to go to her grandmother's house in the summer, and one of her favorite activities was to play in the big barn her great-grandfather built before she was born.

The barn smelled like old hay and horses, even though there had been no horses there as long as Judith could remember. An old tractor was parked inside, and there were other things scattered around, like old leather harnesses, wooden buckets, and rusty chains. Judith would pretend each of the horse stalls was a room in her grown-up mansion.

One day, Judith was feeling particularly adventurous. She decided she wanted to see what was inside a room in one corner of the barn. The door to the room was held closed by an old padlock. Judith saw the padlock was not snapped shut. It would be easy to remove it and open the door!

Judith was curious and couldn't wait to see what was inside. She easily removed the lock and dropped it on the ground with a thud, then she slowly pulled the old door open. The hinges squeaked, and her heart was beating fast. She was excited and a little afraid, but she couldn't wait to see what was inside.

The inside of the small room was dark, but some sunlight shone through the wooden slats of the barn wall, and she was able to make out the shapes of a shelf with old tools, some shovels and hoes propped up against the wall, and one big, cardboard box that was taped shut.

The box caught Judith's eye at once. She wanted to know what hidden treasures might be stored inside! The tape was loose from years of summer heat, so the flaps of the box opened easily. There was only one thing inside. It looked like a black stick. She grabbed one end of the stick to pull it out of the box and gasped when she saw a cloud of little, white stars come out of the other end! What kind of stick was this? Could this be a magic wand?

prompt: Who painted the Sistine Chapel's ceiling and what does it depict?

messages.content: Who painted the Sistine Chapel's ceiling and what does it depict?

The Sistine Chapel's ceiling, located in the Vatican City, was painted by the Renaissance artist Michelangelo between 1508 and 1512 under the patronage of Pope Julius II. The ceiling's frescoes depict scenes from the Book of Genesis, from the 'Separation of Light from Darkness' at the altar, to the 'Drunkenness of Noah' over the entrance wall. The most iconic image is 'The Creation of Adam,' a fresco painting that portrays God giving life to Adam. It is widely considered a masterpiece of High Renaissance art.
